PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
* That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
* That the right to life to all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
* That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
* That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
* That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
* That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned petitioners draw to the attention of the Senate the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which armed conflict such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should demand that the Australian Government:
(a) outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations: government and private.
(b) lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(c) cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening when we were debating the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill, I made the point that while we have no objection to this legislation-it is something that is necessary to better manage the importation and exportation of our wildlife-nonetheless it is a minuscule step in the right direction in relation to the protection of our wildlife. There are far more serious matters to be dealt with which go well beyond this sort of legislation and which the Government, despite promises to address it, has consistently failed to address over a long period-questions of biodiversity and questions of the protection of endangered species.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday I drew attention to the well-documented fact that Australia has the worst record in the world for the extinction of species. That relates only to those large and obvious species which are in the public consciousness and about which we know a great deal. This legislation totally ignores the loss of vast ecosystems which almost certainly correlate with the damage to soil structure, the loss of soil and the deterioration in the quality of the soil throughout much of Australia. The vast changes in the ecosystems across much of Australia which have occurred in last 200 years have undoubtedly resulted in very substantial change and the loss of many species about which we know very little. Further, one could reflect on the paltry amount of money that is being put into the biological survey program.

As I indicated in a speech some months ago, one very well-known expert on wildlife in Australia commented to me that at the present rate of work on the biological survey it will be the year 3000 before we have a thorough understanding of the species of plants and animals we have in Australia, their interrelationships, and their total ecological needs for long term protection and management. The Budget before us does nothing to address this matter.

Just before I sat down last night I was making the point that the Australian Democrats therefore call on the Government to consider seriously-in consultation with the community, conservation, industry, farm, fishing and forestry groups-a 200-year Australian conservation plan which contains aims, objectives, goals and action plans and which contains funding targets for at least the first 10 years of this plan. It is only if we take that longer term view that we will really seriously address this very threatening problem-threatening in terms of not understanding the life support system without which continuation of human existence in Australia may well be jeopardised. I have already drawn attention to the well established fact that very often species will finally disappear years or decades after the conditions which have led to their slow demise have been set in train. Those processes are very often ill understood and irreversible.

So we are calling for this 200-year Australian conservation plan. If it is good enough for the Government to build this Parliament House to last 200 years, surely it is good enough for that Parliament to prepare a plan to ensure that our environmental heritage is protected for that same length of time; otherwise it is not difficult to imagine standing outside this building in 200 years time and finding that it is indeed the only thing left.

This conservation plan can be implemented through a coordinated strategy of environmental management programs which we have entitled the natural biodiversity program, for want of a better title. It should include both survey research and pro-active measures to identify, protect and repair the habitats that are needed to sustain species. This program has been detailed in the Democrat's alternative budgets, both last year and this year, and I direct honourable senators' attention to that program. It describes the need to integrate the management of all extinction threatening processes. That does not mean looking just at the species which this legislation before us does; it also means looking at the habitat, ecology, the total interrelationships of species and, as several other honourable senators have said-I think Senator Calvert mentioned it last night-protecting endangered species and controlling feral animals.

We support this legislation. We feel it is a small step in the right direction, but it is only a minuscule step. It does not go nearly far enough in terms of addressing the very serious problems of protecting Australia's endangered species both now and into the more distant future. Without a more serious attempt to address that problem, our children and grandchildren will grow up in a very depopulated and a very poor environment. It will be one in which the rich biological diversity of animal and plant species which populated this country 200 years ago, some of them unique, will be very much diminished and the quality of life of our children and grandchildren will be the poorer for that.

We make this plea that the Government address these other issues with much more alacrity than it has with this Bill which has been around for quite some time. The paucity of environmental legislation that comes before this chamber indicates the very low priority that this Government gives to environmental management and environmental matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In summing up the debate on the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1991, without wasting the time of the chamber by reiterating the comments made by speakers in the second reading debate last night and this morning, I thank those people who have participated in the debate. I note that both Senator Calvert and Senator Coulter have made very lengthy and considered contributions, and that is not to denigrate those who spoke more succinctly. I thank all contributors to the debate for their support.

SPEECH.PARA: To the extent that people have damned the Bill with faint praise by saying that it is a small step in the right direction but that it does not go far enough, I do not think at any stage it was considered that the Bill was one of the great leaps forward legislatively. As everybody has said, the Bill was merely a further step in the right direction. No one piece of legislation will deal with all of the questions that have been raised by honourable senators in this debate-the concerns that people have raised about the loss of global and biological diversity, the concerns about endangered species.

This Bill does a number of intelligent things, each one a further step in the right direction, each a part of a network of things which Australia and other countries are doing to enhance the biological diversity of the globe and to make our small contribution to it. As honourable senators who are interested in wildlife protection would undoubtedly be aware-and that would include all of those who participated in this debate-there was a doubling of the Budget allocation for the endangered species program last night.

None of these things, by themselves, will resolve the complex matters that people have raised in this debate, some of them ranging 200 years into the future and others dealing with issues of great immediacy. Each of them, I am sure, is welcomed by all honourable senators. Each of them, combined with the activities of the international agencies and other governments, makes our commitment and concern for the environment and the species that combine to make up our global environment more apparent and effective. Whilst this legislation is a small step, it is, I am sure, a welcome one. I thank honourable senators for their support. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, as I said in the second reading debate, supports the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1991. I draw to the attention of the Committee the fact that this Bill was heavily amended in the House of Representatives by the Government to fix up the mistakes and blunders in it as a result of its being hurried into the other chamber. The Opposition takes the view that it would be a very good idea if the Government, when it is rushing legislation through either chamber of the Parliament, could make the legislation reasonably correct before it introduced the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am grateful that the Government has managed to correct the Bill in the other chamber, after its introduction, before it came here because we seem to waste an awful amount of our time correcting blunders in Government legislation. I put on record that we are quite pleased that the Government has managed to fix its mistakes elsewhere.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator McMullan) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 20 August.
The Bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I have a series of amendments and I am not sure of the best way of handling them. I might start working through my amendments and Senator Spindler can interrupt when it seems to him more appropriate that we deal with one of the Australian Democrats amendments. Some of these have been subject to negotiation in the very recent past, as of a few minutes ago, so we might require some flexibility.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Hill for indicating the process that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats might adopt. I table a revised replacement explanatory memorandum to the Copyright Amendment Bill. It takes account of amendments made by the House of Representatives to the Bill as introduced.
—Senator Hill's suggestion might be satisfactory, except that I do not have the Democrats amendments yet. Let us see how we go with Senator Hill's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first amendment that I have has been circulated and it simply relates to the commencement date. I mentioned this argument yesterday in the second reading debate. We have been concerned that the Copyright Amendment Bill is silent as to its commencement date. Under the provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act, the Bill would commence 28 days after the day on which it receives the royal assent. The Opposition's amendment seeks to extend the commencement date so that it commences three months after the day of the royal assent. That is in order to allow authors, publishers, distributors and booksellers to make appropriate industry adjustments in light of changes to be brought about by the Bill; the making of regulations for the purposes of clause 2(b) of the Bill prescribing countries from which books may be imported; and regulations to be made-and this is an optimistic argument-for purposes of our proposed new part 4 to prescribe the relevant reasonable time for different copyright articles. In other words, it is really to allow a greater period in which to implement the practical matters which follow from passage of this piece of legislation. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 1, page 1, insert the following clause:
Commencement
``1A. This Act commences 3 months after the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this Opposition amendment. It is our view that the Bill has been well and truly on record for a long time and that the level of consultation and submissions from members of the industry indicates that the contents are well and truly known. We believe that the Bill has been delayed long enough and should not be delayed any longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government also opposes this amendment. We believe that book publishers, booksellers and other affected interests have had ample opportunity to consider and adjust to the proposed amendments which were first announced by the then Attorney-General in December 1989 and introduced into Parliament in October 1990. Further, a draft of the Bill was circulated for comment in 1990 and intensive consultations took place prior to the House of Representatives debate in May 1991. It is my understanding that important sectors of the book industry-publishers, booksellers and so on-have already adjusted their business practices as if the changes to the law were already in effect. I believe that we should maintain the usual practice under the Acts Interpretation Act and that this law should come into effect 28 days after it receives the royal assent.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 2 is consequential upon the Senate adopting our new Part IVa which is covered by amendment No. 13 which has been circulated. This relates to the fact that the Government decided to limit these reforms simply to books, whereas the advice of the Copyright Review Committee was that it should cover works generally. As amendment No. 2 is consequential upon the passage of amendment No. 13, I suggest that at this stage I move amendment No. 13, and then we will see whether amendment No. 2 should be moved.
—Is that suitable to the Committee? There being no objection, it is so ordered.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 13. After clause 8, page 5, add the following clause:
Insertion of new Part IVa
``9. After Part IV of the Principal Act the following Part is inserted:
`PART IVa-IMPORTATION OF
WORKS AND SUBJECT MATTER
OTHER THAN WORKS
Application of Part
`113a. (1) This Part has effect notwithstanding sections 37, 38, 102, 103, 132 and 135.

`(2) This Part applies to the importation of works and subject matter other than works but does not apply to a non-infringing book whose importation does not constitute an infringement of copyright by virtue of the provisions in sections 44a or 112a.
`(3) This Part does not apply to the importation of works and subject matter other than works comprised of:
(a) a computer program or a manual sold with a computer program for use in connection with that program;
(b) a book the main content of which is one or more musical works, with or without any related literary, dramatic or artistic work;
(c) a periodical publication; or
(d) a book, the primary purpose of the publication of which is for use by students of an educational institution as a book required for a course of study at that institution.
`(4) Subsection (3), unless sooner repealed, shall cease to be in force at the expiration of two years after the date of commencement of this Part.
Importation for sale or hire not an infringement of section 37 in certain circumstances
`113b. (1) Section 37 is not infringed where:

(a) a person imports an article into Australia and, at the time of the importation, is satisfied after reasonable investigation that copies of the article (not being second-hand copies) or articles substantially similar thereto, cannot be obtained in Australia from the copyright owner or his or her licensee or agent within a reasonable time; or

(b) a person imports an article into Australia and the article is imported pursuant to a written order signed by another person in which it is stated by that person that the article is required otherwise than for the purpose of:
(i) selling, letting for hire, or by way of trade offering or exposing for sale or hire, the article;
(ii) distributing the article:
(a) for the purpose of trade; or
(b) for any other purpose to an extent that will affect prejudicially the owner of the copyright; or
(iii) by way of trade exhibiting the article in public.

`(2) This section shall not apply to an article unless it is made in Australia or in a country specified in Part I or Part II of Schedule 1 to the Copyright (International Protection) Regulations made pursuant to section 184 of this Act as in force from time to time with the consent of, or under licence from, the owner, in the country of manufacture, of the copyright in the work of which the article is said to be a reproduction.
`(3) A person relying upon this section shall carry the onus of proving the matters specified in subsections (1) and (2).

`(4) A person who makes a statement pursuant to paragraph (1) (b) which is false to his or her knowledge is liable to pay to any person who suffers loss as a consequence of the making of such a statement the amount of such loss.

`(5) The amount of the loss referred to in subsection (4) is a debt due to the person who has suffered the loss and is recoverable by him or her from the person making the statement in a court of competent jurisdiction.
Sale and other dealings not an infringement of section 38 in certain circumstances
`113c. (1) Section 38 is not infringed where a person in Australia, and without the licence of the owner of the copyright:
(a) sells, lets for hire, or by way of trade offers or exposes for sale or hire, an imported article; or
(b) by way of trade exhibits an imported article in public;
and either

(c) the person importing it was satisfied after reasonable investigation that, at the time of the importation of the article, copies of the article (not being second-hand copies) or articles substantially similar thereto, could not be obtained in Australia from the copyright owner or his or her licensee or agent within a reasonable time; or
(d) the article was imported pursuant to a written order signed by another person in which that person stated that the article was required otherwise than for the purposes of:
(i) selling, letting for hire, or by way of trade offering or exposing for sale or hire, the article;
(ii) distributing the article:
(a) for the purpose of trade; or
(b) for any other purpose to an extent that will affect prejudicially the owner of the copyright; or
(iii) by way of trade exhibiting the article in public.

`(2) This section shall not apply to an article unless it is made in Australia or in a country specified in Part I or Part II of Schedule 1 to the Copyright (International Protection) Regulations made pursuant to section 184 of this Act as in force from time to time with the consent of, or under licence from, the owner, in the country of manufacture, of the copyright in the work of which the article is said to be a reproduction.
`(3) A person relying upon this section shall carry the onus of proving the matters specified in subsections (1) and (2).

`(4) A person who makes a statement pursuant to paragraph (1) (d) which is false to his or her knowledge is liable to pay to any person who suffers loss as a consequence of the making of such a statement the amount of such loss.

`(5) The amount of the loss referred to in subsection (4) is a debt due to the person who has suffered the loss and is recoverable by him or her from the person making the statement in a court of competent jurisdiction.
Sections 37 and 38 not to apply where copyright only subsists in a label or mark on the article or on packaging or container

`113d. (1) Section 37 and, in so far as it applies to imported articles, section 38 of this Act, do not apply to an article by reason only that copyright subsists in a label or mark (whether a trade mark within the meaning of the Trade Marks Act 1955 or not) which is affixed or attached to the article or to the packaging or container in which the article is packed or contained.
`(2) Subsection (1) does not apply if the owner of the copyright in the label or mark has not consented to or authorised the use of his or her work for the purposes of the label or mark.
Regulations
`113e. (1) Regulations may be made prescribing periods of time which are reasonable times for the purposes of paragraph 113b (1) (a) and paragraph 113c (1) (c) of this Act.

`(2) Any regulations prescribed pursuant to subsection (1) may be made in relation to all reproductions of particular works, or reproductions of particular classes of works or particular articles which are reproductions of a work or works.
Importation for sale or hire not an infringement of section 102 in certain circumstances
`113f. (1) Section 102 is not infringed where:

(a) a person imports an article into Australia and, at the time of the importation, is satisfied after reasonable investigation that copies of the article (not being second-hand copies) or articles substantially similar thereto, cannot be obtained in Australia from the copyright owner or his or her licensee or agent within a reasonable time; or

(b) a person imports an article into Australia and the article is imported pursuant to a written order signed by another person in which it is stated by that person that the article is required otherwise than for the purpose of:
(i) selling, letting for hire, or by way of trade offering or exposing for sale or hire, the article;
(ii) distributing the article:
(a) for the purpose of trade; or
(b) for any other purpose to an extent that will affect prejudicially the owner of the copyright; or
(iii) by way of trade exhibiting the article in public.

`(2) This section shall not apply to an article unless it is made in Australia or in a country specified in Part I or Part II of Schedule 1 to the Copyright (International Protection) Regulations made pursuant to section 184 of this Act as in force from time to time with the consent of, or under licence from, the owner, in the country of manufacture, of the copyright in the work of which the article is said to be a reproduction.
`(3) A person relying upon this section shall carry the onus of proving the matters specified in subsections (1) and (2).

`(4) A person who makes a statement pursuant to paragraph (1) (b) which is false to his or her knowledge is liable to pay to any person who suffers loss as a consequence of the making of such a statement the amount of such loss.

`(5) The amount of the loss referred to in subsection (4) is a debt due to the person who has suffered the loss and is recoverable by him or her from the person making the statement in a court of competent jurisdiction.
Sale and other dealings not an infringement of section 103 in certain circumstances
`113g. (1) The provisions of section 103 are not infringed where a person, in Australia, and without the licence of the owner of the copyright:
(a) sells, lets for hire, or by way of trade offers or exposes for sale or hire, an imported article; or
(b) by way of trade exhibits an imported article in public;
and either

(c) the person importing it was satisfied after reasonable investigation that, at the time of the importation of the article, copies of the article (not being second-hand copies) or articles substantially similar thereto, could not be obtained in Australia from the copyright owner or his or her licensee or agent within a reasonable time; or
(d) the article was imported pursuant to a written order signed by another person in which that person stated that the article was required otherwise than for the purposes of:
(i) selling, letting for hire, or by way of trade offering or exposing for sale or hire, the article;
(ii) distributing the article:
(a) for the purpose of trade; or
(b) for any other purpose to an extent that will affect prejudicially the owner of the copyright; or
(iii) by way of trade exhibiting the article in public.

`(2) This section shall not apply to an article unless it is made in Australia or in a country specified in Part I or Part II of Schedule 1 to the Copyright (International Protection) Regulations made pursuant to section 184 of this Act as in force from time to time with the consent of, or under licence from, the owner, in the country of manufacture, of the copyright in the work of which the article is said to be a reproduction.
`(3) A person relying upon this section shall carry the onus of proving the matters specified in subsections (1) and (2).

`(4) A person who makes a statement pursuant to paragraph (1) (d) which is false to his or her knowledge is liable to pay to any person who suffers loss as a consequence of the making of such a statement the amount of such loss.

`(5) The amount of the loss referred to in subsection (4) is a debt due to the person who has suffered the loss and is recoverable by him or her from the person making the statement in a court of competent jurisdiction.
Regulations
`113h. (1) Regulations may be made prescribing periods of time which are reasonable times for the purposes of paragraphs 113f (1) (a) and 113g (1) (c) of this Act.

`(2) Any regulations prescribed pursuant to subsection (1) may be made in relation to all copies of particular subject matter, or copies of particular classes of subject matter or particular articles which are copies of one or more items of subject matter.'.''.

As I said, this amendment extends the Bill to include a new part which will extend the operation of the Bill to other copyright articles in line with the report of the CLRC. We recognise that the Government has indicated that it intends to propose further legislation in relation to other copyright articles. However, we on this side of the chamber are anxious to accelerate the process of reform bearing in mind, as I mentioned yesterday, that it has already taken eight years to reach this stage of proposed legislation simply limited to books.

I also mentioned yesterday that the extension does not include computer software, in view of the current inquiry of the Prices Surveillance Authority in this area. All the exemptions in this new part, which include the Government's exemptions plus exemptions for computer software and textbooks, are to be subject to a two-year sunset clause.

As I indicated, I move amendment No. 13 to include a new Part IVa in the Bill which would cover the importation of works and subject matter other than works, and allow for a more liberal regime, thus providing greater access to Australian consumers at more competitive prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this Opposition amendment. It is clear that public debate is at a fairly early stage. The Government has made a statement about records and other items of like nature. There has been a response from the industry. The debate is still in full flight. We believe it would be totally pre-emptive and hurried to seek to tack onto this Bill a provision covering records. For that reason, at this stage, we will not support the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not support this particular extension of the subject matter. Quite apart from some awkward drafting of the provisions--
—What do you mean? It is very well drafted.

—That is a matter of judgment. Some of them are very awkwardly drafted. The new part covers amendments for artistic works, dramatic works, musical works, television and sound broadcasts, films and sound recordings. For the reasons given by Senator Spindler, and because the Government is still considering a review of these matters-particularly in relation to sound recording-subject, as we know, to a PSA report, the Government will not be supporting this amendment. Consultations are being undertaken with relevant interests and the issue is about to be considered by Cabinet. It is just too premature for this Bill to be used as a vehicle by which to extend coverage to works other than books.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to reply to the Minister's gratuitous comment on drafting and remind him that he is offending not only the Senate draftsmen who assisted us but also the draftsmen for the CLRC, who played a major part in this drafting also. We could stand here for many hours arguing about drafting techniques or drafting consequences, but nevertheless I recognise that we will lose the amendment, which we maintain is well drafted.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 2, as I indicated, is consequential upon having succeeded with the last amendment, which we regrettably lost. It is to add to the definition of infringing copy in subsection 10(1) of the Copyright Act a reference to our proposed part IVa As that part IVa has not been included, I will therefore abandon amendment No. 2 and move to amendments 3 and 4.
—They are consequential.

—I will take up the interjection of Senator Spindler that they are consequential. Firstly, amendments 3 and 4 run in parallel, the first being in relation to infringement by importation for sale or hire and the second being in relation to infringement by sale and other dealings. I agree that paragraph (a) of each amendment is consequential and therefore should not be pressed. But the constructive knowledge provisions in paragraph (b) in each stand alone. Therefore, they should be pressed.

SPEECH.PARA: They follow from the fact-and, as I recall, this was also a recommendation of the Copyright Law Review Committee-that the offence itself includes language that makes it clear that one can be guilty when one has a constructive knowledge; in other words, adopting the language we have put in this amendment, where a person knew or ought reasonably to have known, as opposed to where a person has within his knowledge, or `where, to his knowledge', to pick up the exact language within the Act. It takes that language out of the offence provisions and brings it back into the substantive provisions of the Bill, in accordance with the recommendation that was made by the Copyright Law Review Committee. It is, therefore, to reflect the fact that constructive knowledge is specified in section 132 of the Act dealing with criminal offences.

I submit that the amendment is logically sound, that it has the support of the Copyright Law Review Committee and that there was no argument to the contrary put before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and I trust that this Committee of the Whole might find that it is able to support the second part, paragraph (b), of both amendments 3 and 4. Accordingly, I seek leave to move the two amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Clause 3, page 2, lines 8 to 10, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Infringement by importation for sale or hire
``3. Section 37 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting `where, to his knowledge,' and substituting `if the person knew, or ought reasonably to have known, that'.''.
4. Clause 4, page 2, lines 11 to 14, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Infringement by sale and other dealings
``4. Section 38 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from subsection (1) `where, to his knowledge, `and substituting' if the person knew, or ought reasonably to have known, that'.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats accept that not passing amendment No. 13 of the Opposition leaves active paragraph (b) of each amendment, and the Australian Democrats will be supporting the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing these amendments. It is true that there was a recommendation of the Copyright Law Review Committee to amend the knowledge requirements in the importation provisions to bring them into line with section 132 of the Act. However, this issue is closely related to the decriminalisation of the provisions, which was also a recommendation of the Copyright Law Review Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will consider both these matters together and in respect of all copyright subject matter, not just books, as the Opposition Bill appears to do. In other words, the Government wants to make decisions concerning the importation provisions and sound recordings; it may also have regard to the CLRC report on computer software. The amendments are not supported because the Government regards it as premature to make amendments in relation to books alone at this stage. It wants to link the whole question to a more comprehensive examination of all copyright subject matter in relation to the decriminalisation of the provisions which was recommended by the CLRC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister may be mistaken. As I understand it, these amendments are really little more than technical amendments bringing the language of the Act into a consistent form. Therefore, I find it difficult to appreciate the merit of the argument that the Minister seems to be putting-that the amendments would be considered at a later date in relation to other areas of copyright which will be part of subsequent legislation. I extend an invitation to the Minister-I do not know whether it is of great consequence-to consider accepting the logic of what I have just put and therefore withdrawing his objection.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5. Clause 5, page 3, proposed subsection 44a (3), lines 4 to 12, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:

``(3) The copyright in a published work (whether first published before, on or after the commencing day) is not infringed by a person who, without the licence of the owner of the copyright, imports a single copy of a non-infringing book into Australia if the importation is for the purpose of filling a verifiable order by a customer of the person and;
(a) in the case of a written order, the order contains a statement, signed by the customer; or
(b) in the case of a telephone order, the customer makes a statement;
to the effect that the customer does not intend to use the book for a purpose mentioned in paragraph 37(a), (b) or (c).''.
Amendment No.5 is one that I claim with great confidence to be soundly based.

TALK.START.PARA: —And well drafted.

—And well drafted. The amendment relates to the limitation of single copy exemption under which a single copy of a book may be imported to fill the written order of a customer. I argued yesterday on behalf of the Opposition in the second reading debate that technology has passed a situation where one must only communicate by written form. The evidence put before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was that there was inconvenience within the industry and from the point of view of consumers in having to provide an order in written form. We are therefore seeking to bring this legislation into line with commercial reality. Many customers expect to be able to make such orders by telephone. Our amendment provides for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The order must be verifiable, whether it is in writing or over the telephone, and the customer must make a statement that he or she does not intend to use the book for prohibited purposes. I trust that the Government will appreciate that what we propose is a sound, constructive improvement to the slightly more liberal regime that the Government seeks to implement through this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting that amendment. We see no reason why telephone orders should be excluded, particularly since there is provision for the customer to make a statement confirming that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed to hear that the Australian Democrats are supporting this amendment. The Government does not support the amendment. The idea that there should be written and signed orders is designed to overcome any possible abuse that might arise if, for example, a bookseller accused of illegitimate importation of copies could assert that the copies he or she had in stock or had sold were to satisfy telephone orders. It is simply a matter of trying to provide a regime which would not tempt perhaps a bookseller to engage in illegitimate importation and try to satisfy an inquiry by saying, `Well, I had a telephone order'.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we also have to take into account that in the modern world a fax order could be placed, or the order could be confirmed by fax. That is now the normal way of dealing with matters. That would certainly satisfy the requirement of the provision. Perhaps the Democrats might reconsider their point of view. As to the fax requirement, I do not think there is any great difficulty with people communicating, and it would prevent that little possibility of abuse creeping into the system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The use of telephone orders was raised at the meeting of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs last Monday week. I found some sympathy with the view that telephone orders should be able to be used. I can understand the concern of someone saying `How do you verify it three weeks or three months later when there is a dispute?' if they say `I did ring up' and someone else says `No, you did not', and there is nothing on the record about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I note the Minister's comments about faxes. Can the Minister assure us that what is written in the Bill clearly, in definition, covers the use of a fax? A fax is a telephonic transmission; it is not a letter. Most people in business these days have a fax. Once the telephone order is made, I do not think it is an unreasonable proposition to then tell somebody that their order is noted verbally but they have several days in which to provide written communication of their order, even to fax it. I do accept the view that, if there is no follow-up paperwork in any form, when two people disagree later on the facts are very hard to prove; there is no evidence at all other than one person's word against somebody else's.

In view of the Democrats' interest in this matter, I wonder whether that amendment can be reworded to make it clear that faxes are acceptable and that a telephone order has to be followed up with some written communication, even if it is by way of a fax. I do not think that is an unnecessary inhibition. The evidence given to us last Monday week was that if a written order is signed by the customer one has to get a signed written order back. In these modern days, that situation can be used by the original publishers of the book as an unnecessary delaying tactic if they choose not to respond or acknowledge receipt of the written order within the day.

The whole operation of the copyright Act should be on the basis of immediacy wherever possible, within reason. After hearing the evidence in the Committee, I have some sympathy for the telephone order, but I do believe it has to be followed up with some written evidence so that there can be no dispute. If there is a dispute at a later date, the facts can actually be verified. I ask the Minister to consider that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht has taken the words out of my mouth. I was going to suggest to the Minister that since, in general terms, there is need for the customer to verify the order this section could be tightened to provide that security. Perhaps the Opposition would entertain an amendment to its amendment which inserts after `telephone order', the words, `to be confirmed in writing or by fax within seven days'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —In some ways it is a pity that amendments were not considered before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. In this instance, it was decided to take the Bill to the Committee before the second reading stage of debate. The exchange that we are having now on the run would have been more productively pursued when we were sitting around the table at the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I hear what Senator Spindler says. What the Opposition is concerned about is that, if an order is specifically required to be followed up by a letter or fax, it is getting close to returning to the piece of legislation the mischief that we are seeking to remove from it and, that is, requiring a specific, formal method other than telephoning. I remind Senator Spindler of the fact that, without defining it further, we do state in the amendment that it must be a specific, verifiable order but we leave it flexible.

With regard to the Minister's argument that in some way we might be opening a floodgate for fraud, I remind him that, at the moment, we are talking about single copies purchased by a single purchaser for private, non-commercial use. We are going to seek to extend that slightly to cover certain library situations but, basically, we are not looking at a major part of the book selling operation. Therefore, we do not want to be proposing amendments that in some way will facilitate fraud. This is a very limited exemption to simply make life easier for the trade.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Government will cop this; let us keep moving. I agree that single orders are quite different to what is proposed in relation to library copies and so on. When we come to libraries we might be thinking in terms of a more formal written order as per the present Bill. But with regard to a person going to a bookseller, finding that a book is not available and the bookseller putting in an order over the telephone to a mate in Boston, or something like that, let us live with that.
—Are you accepting the amendment?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. He may also have been somewhat persuaded by an aspect of Senator Schacht's argument which could have complicated matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 6. Clause 5, page 3, after proposed subsection 44a(3), insert the following subsection:

``(3a) The copyright in a published work (whether first published before, on or after the commencing day) is not infringed by a person who, without the licence of the owner of the copyright, imports a number of copies of a non-infringing book equal to the number of copies of a specific verifiable order for that book from a library.''.

Amendment No. 6 is the library provision that was subject to considerable debate in the Standing Committee. Pursuant to this amendment, booksellers will be able to import a specific number of books without infringing copyright in order to fill the order of a library for that number of books.

As I said yesterday, the reason for this amendment is that, as the law stands, Australian booksellers must treat libraries as any other customer and can only import a single copy of a book for them from a supplier who is not the Australian copyright holder. Libraries have, therefore, formed the practice of ordering directly from large overseas suppliers. The Opposition's amendment allows libraries to order books from Australian booksellers rather than going offshore and, therefore, provides a much needed boost for our local trade in the current difficult economic climate it is experiencing.

The case was put strongly by the industry that Australian booksellers are, in fact, losing for no justifiable reason, because libraries have been avoiding the legislation and dealing directly with the overseas suppliers. We simply want to give Australian industry a fair opportunity to earn its share of the profit out of this particular business. Therefore, this amendment moved by the Opposition provides for greater flexibility in relation to purchases or orders made by libraries.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have one concern about this amendment, that is, that `library' is not very clearly defined. We are concerned that this could create a loophole and invite organisations or booksellers to establish a library for the sole purpose of making use of that exemption. Hence, the Australian Democrats proposed amendment to the Opposition's amendment which seeks to insert before `library' the word `public', and after `library' the words `and the libraries of public educational institutions'. If that is acceptable to the Opposition, the Democrats will support the amended amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the hearing last Monday week, I was somewhat astonished to hear that the present copyright legislation acts to the detriment of Australian booksellers when selling books to public libraries, and encourages our public libraries to buy books direct from multinational book publishing companies from overseas. I would have thought that this is obviously an unintended consequence of the original copyright legislation. I cannot, under any circumstance, imagine that legislation was drafted to prohibit independent Australian booksellers from being able to competitively tender and sell Australian books-whether they are imported books or books published locally-to Australian public libraries, libraries in universities and other educational institutions and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: I found that the evidence given was persuasive that there should be some amendment to allow Australian booksellers to import books and sell them so that they get a cut of the business. Obviously, the business is very profitable and I was not surprised that international book publishers were not very keen on changing it because it gives them an improved ability to supply the market at the expense of indigenous booksellers. I think it is an unintended consequence.

I believe the amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats overcomes a clear loophole that would have existed. In view of the evidence given last week, which I found persuasive, and in view of this suggestion by the Democrats, which I think covers the loophole that could have existed, as a member of the Government I find it very difficult to justify why Australian booksellers should be penalised vis-a-vis international publishers having access to a bigger share of the market of Australian public libraries and libraries in our educational institutions. I think the mixture of both the Opposition's amendment and the Democrats' suggestion, based on the evidence given last week, have a lot of merit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I now know how Senator Gareth Evans feels when he is trying to deal with Cambodia. I thank Senator Schacht very much for that intervention-he has been extremely helpful at the committee stage! The Government does not support this particular Opposition amendment. I have not read the full transcript of the evidence offered at the Committee last week, but my understanding is that there is not a great deal of information available as to the extent to which the provisions affect the supply of books to libraries. It is difficult to ascertain whether a specific exception allowing orders for multiple copies of books for libraries is necessary or justified. Senator Schacht has offered some reasons why he thinks this particular amendment offered by the Opposition is justified.
—And with Senator Spindler's subsequent amendment, which is very important.

—I am coming to that. What we are talking about are institutions which, like private individuals who want to get books from overseas, are not purchasing them for on selling. We are not talking about a situation where libraries are going to get in stock and then sell to the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about these institutions gathering the written cultural or educational text that they then make available to borrowers. We believe that they ought to be able to go overseas very readily in order to enable that to be done. On the question of what should qualify as a library, I have not had a lot of time to look at the Democrat amendments because they have just been circulated. However, section 49(9) of the Copyright Act provides:
In this section, `library'' does not include a library that is conducted for the profit, direct or indirect, of an individual or individuals.

I should have thought that was a sufficient definition for the purposes of the Opposition amendment. I take it that the Opposition amendment picks up that definition if nothing more is done. Is that right?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst the Minister takes advice, I say to Senator Spindler that we do not want to allow a loophole in the form that he is concerned about. We do not want somebody to be able to use this opportunity to purchase books for a commercial library for reselling or whatever. I was concerned about his definition, however, in that it is narrower than he might want to be the case. For example, libraries in Catholic schools do not do it for reselling and are not wealthy, but they may not fall within the definition of `public'.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why I would suggest to him that the language that the Minister refers to in section 49(9) is better. If he were prepared to move that, after the word `library' in my amendment, we insert the words `not being a library that is conducted for the profit, direct or indirect, of an individual or individuals', he might achieve his objective. It might ensure that there is no ambiguity left, as there may be, because I do not know that this provision necessarily picks up section 49, and therefore would better achieve the Minister's objective as well. Can I respectfully suggest that to Senator Spindler as a way of resolving this dilemma, consistent with the sentiment being expressed around the chamber?

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has also been drawn to the fact that the wording `public library' may not include the Parliamentary Library. So I accept the point made by Senator Hill and I would be happy to support the amendment if he amends it in the way in which he suggested.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend my amendment by inserting after the word `library' in my amendment No. 6, which I think occurs only once:

SPEECH.PARA: not being a library that is conducted for the profit, direct or indirect, of an individual or individuals.
Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would suggest that we use the terminology based on section 49(9) but slightly change it to say, `library does not include a library that is conducted for the profit, direct or indirect, of a person'. That would certainly embrace corporations. Why not say, `a person or organisation' so that we cover those non-corporate entities that set up as libraries?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy with that. That part of the amendment will now read:

SPEECH.PARA: , not being a library that is conducted for the profit, direct or indirect, of a person or organisation.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 11. Clause 8, page 5, after proposed subsection 112a(3), insert the following subsection:

``(3A) The copyright in a published edition of a work (whether the edition was first published before, on or after the commencing day) is not infringed by a person who, without the licence of the owner of the copyright, imports a number of copies of a non-infringing book equal to the number of copies of a specific verifiable order for that book from a library, not being a library that is conducted for the profit, direct or indirect, of a person or organisation.''.

I thank the Minister for his constructive assistance on the previous amendment, notwithstanding that he voted against the amendment he constructively improved. Amendment No. 11 is the parallel provision that deals with public published editions of a work. So I have varied it in a similar form to the amendment that we have just carried; in other words, with the restricted definition of `library'.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 7. Clause 5, page 3, proposed subsection 44A(7), at end of definition of `book', add the following word and paragraph:
``or (d) a book, the primary purpose of the publication of which is for use by students of an educational institution as a book required for a course of study at that institution.''.

This is the textbook exemption. The argument that we put briefly yesterday that I would expand upon-and some might argue that this amendment is a little inconsistent with the trend that we are advocating in this industry -is that we have become convinced of the need, and thus moved in the other place as well, for an amendment in this form because of our concern for adverse consequences in the supply of textbooks to Australian students. In other words, we believe that this should be treated as an exceptional case.

It is necessary, in our view, because of the system of marketing of textbooks which is dependent upon teaching calendars. It is unlikely that there will be any demand in Australia at all for most books within 30 days. The 30-day rule is the key; 30 days of the first publication overseas. Normally, textbooks are obtained and read by academics and, if appropriate, will be recommended as a prescribed text for the following academic year. At that point, which is often six to nine months after the overseas publication, a bookseller will place an order. In other words, it is often six to nine months before the Australian rights holder can know whether a textbook first published overseas will be required in an Australian educational institution. The amendment will also allow time for the preparation of Australian adaptations of foreign published textbooks.

Also, as the Prices Surveillance Authority pointed out in its report, its critical comments relating to price and availability of books did not generally apply in relation to price and availability of textbooks. The PSA representatives put that argument to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs last week.

Pursuant to this amendment a new paragraph (d) is added to subsection 44a(7) to provide that a book does not include a book the primary purpose of which is for use by students of an educational institution as a book required for a course of study at that institution.

The definition would not include publications such as English literature or literature in any other language or publications aimed at members of professions which are also of assistance in teaching courses because these are clearly not publications whose primary purpose is for use as a student text. Such books and professional publications are not marketed in the same way as textbooks; that is, approved by academics at various institutions, before the decision to import marketable quantities for the following academic year is made, and sold principally through campus book sellers.

The primary purpose test is used in a number of Commonwealth and State statutes. Thus, we have been persuaded that there should be an exemption to the 30-day rule for textbooks simply because of the nature of the purchasing practices in relation to them. They would be unduly prejudiced, we believe at the moment, by falling within the more liberal regime that applies after passage of the 30-day rule.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have carefully weighed the arguments that were provided by Senator Hill just now and by others before him. We believe that there are factors affecting the supply of textbooks which go beyond price and supply. I refer to cultural factors. We believe that the Australian book industry, particularly in the field of educational books, should be encouraged and furthered. We believe that, at this time of its development, to ease the indiscriminate influx of overseas textbooks would be counter to that cultural objective. Accordingly, on balance, we have decided not to support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a hearing of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs last Monday week I found one of the most difficult areas to make a clear cut judgment, from the evidence put by the various witnesses, related to what one should do with textbooks. I certainly have some suspicion that the evidence put by the Association of American Publishers showed obviously that it had a vested interest in being able to improve its ability to provide the Australian market.

SPEECH.PARA: It is of considerable concern in these sorts of hearings that people argue great matters of principle when we know that the bottom line is really about bucks, dollars, incomes, greed and self-interest. Despite all the protestations from various witnesses about principle, cultural heritage and so on, when we got to the bottom line everyone was arguing about who got what percentage of the dollar, and it is a billion dollar plus market in Australia.

I have a couple of concerns about the textbook matter and they might be taken as remarks sympathetic to the Opposition amendment. I want to come to some suggestions about the Government and the Democrats not supporting the amendment and what that may mean. First of all, I was concerned to have it put to us at the hearing that the book publishers should make judgments on behalf of what they think consumers of textbooks in Australia want.

For example, it was shown to us that there are several styles of textbook with the same content. There are the very well produced American textbooks which are published in America mostly with paperback covers but of good quality, well bound, well printed and on good paper. We also saw textbooks printed in Asia on extremely low quality paper, very poorly bound and of poor colours. Clearly, after a minimum amount of use, they would start to fall apart, but they are sold very cheaply. Quite frankly, I could not understand a word in some of these textbooks. They dealt with high level mathematics and so on, as we would expect of these textbooks.

I do not think that this is a matter for any particular book publisher or even a government to make a decision to say to consumers, and that is students, et cetera, of textbooks that they may have access to only one quality style textbook, and that is a high quality textbook produced in America. Why cannot students, if they want to have a textbook to use for only a limited period, buy the much cheaper version? Even if it does fall apart after a minimum amount of use that may be long enough for their need. Therefore it is much more important for them to spend a lot less money on a book they need for only a short term than to buy a book from America.

As one witness said, American textbooks are sold to people on the basis that they will keep them for their working life, after graduating from college or university. I find it hard to accept that Australian consumers should not have the choice between top quality publications or lower quality publications. Even though the content is the same, the quality of the printing is quite different.

Therefore, I have some concern that we are trying to dictate to consumers in Australia in this specialised market what sort of quality they should have. I am also concerned that the existing clause will be used by the existing publishers to ensure that the market is maintained for them, that there is limited competition and that they can set the price.

We saw scales in the evidence of how prices of textbooks of high quality and sold in Australia from America are much lower than in America. That evidence was persuasive. The books already sold in Australia are much cheaper. There were examples of the other way round. It seems quite idiosyncratic that one book in America which may be worth $200 is worth only $50 in Australia, or vice versa. It seems that that very much reflects the notions of the people who control the market. I am always suspicious that people who control the market can set the price without competition, remembering that most of the people who consume these books are students and, by definition, not exactly well off. I think students should have the choice of the cheaper quality, not content, books.

I am concerned that, therefore, we may still have a situation that despite these changes the international publishers of textbooks will still be able to set the price and control that price even if some competition is allowed. I am also concerned at the ability of these books to be Australianised, which was another issue that came up. It is said that, if a book is published in America in particular and it is clearly a good textbook, when it comes to Australia 12 to 18 months later, after having been widely prescribed, the publisher will make an effort to Australianise the book by using Australian examples within the material.

It was said to us that if we remove this amendment and allow open competition in line with the position of the Opposition that would be the end of the Australianisation of books. I found no proof that that would occur. If the market is big enough in Australia, any publisher commercially will Australianise the books. It will encourage sales because more and more academics, professors and tutors will set a book if it is Australianised rather than if it is left in its American, British, European or whatever style. So that evidence was not persuasive to me.

My final point on this amendment is that I found it very difficult to make a clear-cut judgment on the evidence. My natural instinct is that we should always err on the side of openness and competition. If the amended clause as proposed by the Government goes through, I am concerned that the Government has said it is three years before a review of this Bill will be conducted. That is far too long and it is far too long in relation to this clause.

Within 12 months we will be able to get a good grip on how this clause is operating. Though it is not actually in the Bill, as I understand it, the commitment for review should not be left for three years. The review should begin in some sections, and particularly in this section, within 12 months. Overall, the review of the whole Bill should begin no later than in 18 months to two years time rather than the three years proposed. I raise that point with the Minister. I hope the Government can take that matter on board, particularly as, in my view, at the moment judgment on the evidence regarding this clause-the argument between competition, access to books and so on-is not clear-cut for either side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree that this is a matter which requires some deliberation and judgment. It is not perhaps absolutely clear-cut. The Government believes on balance that it is important that we maintain the general underlying principle of this legislation to make as wide a range of books available to Australian readers as is possible. It is a question of availability and price. Both those matters have been emphasised, particularly in second reading contributions. It is not simply a question of price but also accessibility.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to the Government that educational texts on cultural heritage and the knowledge of various disciplines that is available to overseas students ought to be very readily available to Australian readers of such texts. Therefore, we believe that early availability under the sort of regime put forward by this Bill is of great benefit to the Australian educational community. We believe that it ought to be supported. I am pleased that it appears that that will be the case.

I understand that Senator Schacht has nevertheless expressed misgivings about how this might work out and the real advantages and detriment that will be revealed even in a fairly short time. I will certainly take his point to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) because it was intended that the Prices Surveillance Authority should conduct the review after three years. As far as both those Ministers need to be consulted, I will certainly do so with a view to trying to bring forward the review. I will particularly emphasise the points Senator Schacht made about the way in which the review could be staged, which was to pick up some of these matters more quickly than others. Nevertheless, perhaps the review should be conducted at the outer within two years rather than three. Perhaps some phases of the review could be undertaken sooner than that.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition needs to move a number of amendments which are parallel to some that have already been dealt with. I believe that applies to amendments Nos 8, 9, 10, and 12-12 being the textbooks amendment which we have just dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have come so far with the Opposition amendments, I suggest that we complete them and then turn to Senator Spindler's amendments.
—It being so agreed, we will continue with the Opposition's amendments.

—I suggest that we do so, particularly as some of Senator Spindler's amendments have not yet had long attention. Amendments Nos 8 and 9 are the companion provisions of amendments Nos 3 and 4. Because of the failure of another amendment of mine, paragraph (a) in each of those two amendments had to be deleted. They were no longer appropriate. I therefore wish to move paragraph (b) in amendments Nos 8 and 9, which is the constructive knowledge argument that I put earlier and which the Committee adopted. I seek leave to move amendments 8 and 9 in a form which deletes paragraph (a) from each.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 8. Clause 6, page 4, lines 1 to 3, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Infringement by importation for sale or hire
6. Section 102 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting `where, to his knowledge,' and substituting `if the person knew, or ought reasonably to have known, that'.''.
9. Clause 7, page 4, lines 4 to 7, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Infringement by sale and other dealings
``7. Section 103 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from subsection (1) `where, to his knowledge,' and substituting `if the person knew, or ought reasonably to have known, that'.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I recall correctly, the Government lost on this matter of constructive knowledge earlier in the committee stage. Therefore, we recognise that we ought to deal with this speedily and have the matter put to a vote.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 10. Clause 8, page 5, proposed subsection 112a (3), lines 1 to 10, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:

``(3) The copyright in a published edition of a work (whether the edition was first published before, on or after the commencing day) is not infringed by a person who, without the licence of the owner of the copyright, imports a single copy of a non-infringing book into Australia if the importation is for the purpose of filling a verifiable order by a customer of the person and;
(a) in the case of a written order, the order contains a statement, signed by the customer; or
(b) in the case of a telephone order, the customer makes a statement;
to the effect that the customer does not intend to use the book for a purpose mentioned in paragraph 102 (a), (b) or (c).

This amendment is a companion provision to amendment No. 5. In this instance, the amendment deals with telephone orders of a published edition of a book. As you would be aware, Mr Temporary Chairman, the law divides copyright in that way. This part deals with published editions. The arguments are exactly the same as those put for amendment No. 5 and which, I am pleased to say, were accepted by the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not support the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 11 has been dealt with. Amendment No. 12 applies the same argument that applies to textbooks except this time it applies to published editions. Therefore, I should not press that in light of the vote on the textbook amendment. I use this opportunity to express my disappointment at that vote because we had support a little earlier. I will not press that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 13 has been dealt with. Amendment No. 14 is consequential to amendment No. 13. In the copy that you have, Mr Temporary Chairman, it has been wrongly labelled with No. 12. It is actually No. 14. As it is consequential upon No. 13, I do not press it either. That completes consideration of the Opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 5, page 4, after proposed section 44A, insert the following section:
Tribunal may extend 30 day period
(a) a work was first published, on or after the commencing day, in a country other than Australia; and
(b) it is likely that the work will not be published in Australia before the end of the period of 30 days after that first publication;
the owner of the copyright may, before the end of that period, make a written application to the Tribunal for an order suspending the operation of subsection 44A(l) in accordance with this section.
`(2) If, after receiving an application, the Tribunal is satisfied that:
(a) all reasonable efforts were made to ensure that the work was published in Australia before the end of the period of 30 days after that first publication; and
(b) in the ordinary course of events, the work would have been so published;
the Tribunal is to suspend the operation of subsection 44A(l) in relation to the work in accordance with this section.
`(3) Subsection 44a (l) does not apply in relation to the copyright in the work while an application in relation to the work is pending.

(4) If the Tribunal suspends the operation of subsection 44a (l) in relation to the work, subsection 44a (l) applies in relation to the copyright in the work as if the reference in the definition of ` `overseas work'' in subsection 44a (7) to 30 days were a reference to 60 days.'.''.

This amendment deals with the 30-day requirement and introduces the so-called slip rule, which enables the person or organisation concerned to bring to the tribunal a special case where the 30 days could not be adhered to due to circumstances or events entirely beyond that person's control: for example, a strike on the waterfront or other delays in obtaining the copies to be published.
I believe, as a matter of equity, that we should accept this exception. The procedure is provided in the amendment and I commend the amendment to the Committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have given consideration to this amendment. We accept that it is certainly arguable. The issue was put before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. On balance, we believe that it is an unnecessary reform. Thirty days, in this time of rapid air transport, is sufficient time to bring in books from overseas. On the one hand, therefore, we doubt that it is necessary and, on the other hand, we are concerned that it would simply become a de facto extension of the provisions as they are included. We do not like de facto extensions. We would prefer a more liberal regime than the one the Government is giving us, but we do not want to achieve that objective through a de facto mechanism. So, on balance, we have decided against supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The period of 30 days, we believe, is the longest that consumers in Australia should be asked to wait for new overseas titles to appear in bookshops in Australia. I believe that the proposed slip rule would raise several practical problems. It is not clear who would have a right to put a case before the relevant tribunal to consider the extension. The problem is only likely to occur infrequently.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Hill has well pointed out the easy ability to get books into Australia given the modern forms of transport. If experience shows that 30 days is a tight period within which to be certain of effecting delivery for publication in Australia, an overseas publisher who values the Australian market for a particular book will, no doubt, take action in advance of overseas publication to ensure that Australian publication is accomplished in time. The Government does not support the slip rule.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Clause 5, after proposed new section 44B, insert the following section:
Applications to Tribunal relating to Australian versions
`` `44c. (1) If the owner of the copyright in a work that:
(a) has been first published, or is intended to be first published, on or after the commencing day in a country other than Australia; and
(b) is not intended to be published in Australia before the end of the period of 30 days after that first publication;

has made contractual arrangements to publish an Australian version of the work in Australia, the owner may, before the end of that period, make a written application to the Tribunal for an order that this section applies to the work.
`(2) If, after receiving an application, the Tribunal is satisfied that:
(a) the owner of the copyright genuinely intends to publish the Australian version in Australia; and
(b) the proposed version amounts to or constitutes a substantial revision or modification of the work for Australian consumption;
the Tribunal is to make an order that this section applies to the work.
`(3) Subsection 44a (l):
(a) does not apply in relation to the copyright in the work while an application under subsection (l) in relation to the work is pending; and
(b) does not apply in relation to the copyright in the work if an order is made.

`(4) Subject to this section, the copyright in a work in respect of which an application under subsection (l) is pending or an order is made is not infringed by a person who, without the licence of the owner of the copyright, imports a copy (in this subsection called the `imported copy') of a hardback or paperback version of a non-infringing book into Australia for a purpose mentioned in paragraph 37(a), (b) or (c) if:
