(a) the person had ordered in writing from the copyright owner, or the owner's licensee or agent, one or more copies of that version of the book (not being second-hand copies or more copies than were needed to satisfy the person's reasonable requirements); and
(b) when the person ordered the imported copy, the original order mentioned in paragraph (a) had not been withdrawn or cancelled by, or with the consent of, the person and:

(i) at least 7 days had elapsed since the person placed the original order and the copyright owner, licensee or agent had not notified the person in writing that the original order would be filled within 90 days after it was placed; or
(ii) at least 90 days had elapsed since the person placed the original order and the copyright owner, licensee or agent had not filled the order.
`(5) Where:
(a) a book is imported into Australia for a purpose mentioned in paragraph 37 (a), (b) or (c); and
(b) the importation does not, under this section, constitute an infringement of copyright in a published work;
the use of the book for any such purpose does not constitute an infringement of the copyright in the work and subsection 38(1) does not apply to the book.

`(6) For the purposes of paragraph (4) (b), a copyright owner, licensee or agent is not taken to have filled an order by a person for one or more copies of a version of a book unless and until the copyright owner, licensee or agent sends the copy, or all of the copies, as the case requires, to the person.
`(7) In this section:
`book' does not include:
(a) a book whose main content is one or more musical works, with or without any related literary, dramatic or artistic work; or
(b) a manual sold with computer software for use in connection with that software; or
(c) a periodical publication:
`commencing day' means the day on which the Copyright Amendment Act 1991 commences.'.''.

This amendment seeks to provide the opportunity for Australian publishers to produce a substantial revision or modification of an overseas publication, sometimes called an adaptation. We believe that the 30-day cut-off period does not give our local industry sufficient time to take the steps necessary to enable it to bring out a substantially revised or modified version of an overseas publication.

The amendment covers the situation where the owner of the copyright of a new overseas title, who has made contractual arrangements to publish an adaptation of the work for Australia, can satisfy the Copyright Tribunal that the intention is genuine and that the proposed adaptation amounts to, or constitutes, a substantial adaptation of the work for Australian consumption. During the period that the adaptation is being dealt with, the original work will be freely available on the Australian market-our amendment takes care of that. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are prepared to accept the amendment of the Australian Democrats. It is, in a limited way, a fall back from our unsuccessful amendment in relation to text books. It does not address the question of publishing, but it will mean that the copyright is not lost forever if an Australian adaptation is taking place. We support that and, therefore, as I have indicated, we are prepared to agree to this Democrat amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government certainly opposes this amendment and I hope that the Opposition will consider the matter further. The whole purpose of this legislation is to try to ensure that Australian readers have access to the world body of published written material. I believe it is absolutely intolerable that we are here in the Senate contemplating a situation where an overseas publisher can say, `I am going to adapt the book for the Australian market-those people down under' and because of that signal of an intention to modify the book in some way for the Australian market, Australians are prevented from getting hold of a very important text which they want to get hold of in numbers.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Committee meeting an example was given of a publication called The Chronicles of the 20th Century which is, I believe, a United Kingdom publication. Obviously, it is a very comprehensive attempt to portray the history of this century so far. If it were suggested that Australians should wait for an adaptation-a modification-of The Chronicles of the 20th Century to have, perhaps, a chapter or two included highlighting Australian history in the twentieth century, then we would be prevented from getting hold of that important text in the bookshops in the normal way.

Whether or not it is an important publication is beside the point, I suppose. The spirit and purpose of this legislation are to make overseas books more readily available in Australia so that people have access to that great mass of publications overseas without the constraints of somebody else saying, `You are not going to get hold of it until we give you an edition which we think you down under should read'. It is absolutely incredible.

I am quite sure that Australian adaptations-if they are made-will be able to compete with the original book. I can give an example of this. I notice a former distinguished secretary to the Attorney-General's Department in the gallery. He will know of the famous text book on contracts by Cheshire and Fifoot. Pat Higgins, who was a senior lecturer at the University of Tasmania when I was a student, produced an Australian edition. That edition competed very successfully with the original Cheshire and Fifoot and I have no doubt that it must have outsold it many times over in Australian university bookshops.

I am quite confident that a well-made Australian adaptation will be able to compete with an overseas publication. People will make their own judgments-and ought to be able to make their own judgments-as to whether they buy the overseas book or the Australian adaptation. I think it is intolerable that somebody else should dictate to Australians that they shall not read a particular publication until it comes out in a version suitable for Australian eyes.

I cannot believe that the Opposition, on further consideration of the matter, will not wish to modify its original indication of some agreement with this particular proposition. I know it was not said with great enthusiasm and I do not think it would involve any humiliation or loss of face if the Opposition were to allow this original spirit and purpose of the legislation to be carried through in this area. I can assure the Opposition that Australian readers would be forever grateful if it were able to support us in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the motives and the good intentions of what Senator Spindler is trying to do on behalf of the Australian Democrats to encourage publishing in Australia of adaptations. However, from my observations of this industry, the evidence before it is that this is a device that will not be used, in Senator Spindler's terms, to encourage, through goodwill, Australian publishing; it will be used as a device to control the importation of books that ordinary Australians, in my view, should have access to.

SPEECH.PARA: I argue very strongly to Senator Spindler that although his motives are absolutely pure-we cannot argue against encouraging the Australian publishing industry-the effect of this amendment would be to give the multinational publishing companies a control over the Australian market. They could put up some book, of which we had examples given by the Minister, and say, `You cannot import that book because we have employed an Australian author who will come up with three extra chapters'. For example, the author could be giving the Australian version of what happened in the Napoleonic Wars or something. This would be a device to control for a long time the importation of books, which would be cheaper and more efficiently provided to the Australian public.

In this area and in other areas, we have to stop falling back on devices supposedly to support Australian industry when, in fact, foreign owned companies will use those devices to protect their interests, their markets, and to make larger profits at the expense of the Australian public. The devices will be used to restrict Australians' access to books which in cultural terms, in a democracy, they have every right to have access to.

I have spoken several times in the committee stage today. I have made remarks that may, at some stage, have been more encouraging to the Opposition than to the Government. I say to Senator Hill that, if he votes for this amendment, he will vote contrary to everything else he has been putting up in all of his other amendments to this Bill and to what he has spoken about in the second reading debate. If Senator Hill votes for this, he will abrogate everything else he has argued for and voted for during the rest of the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not on textbooks.

—I know, but I am saying that Senator Hill has argued everywhere else-even when he has lost an amendment-for a more open market. I have actually, from time to time, encouraged the Government to adopt some of his themes. But, if Senator Hill votes for this, he is actually doing a 180-degree turn on the whole principle that he has been arguing.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret that at the hearing of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs last Monday we did not get down to dealing with the amendments before us. If we had, it would have saved a lot of trouble today in the chamber; we could either have saved a lot of the time here or not had the hearing last week and done something else. This is one of the problems.

I certainly support the Minister in imploring the Opposition not to support the amendment. Even though Senator Spindler's remarks are well-intentioned, I do not believe that the people he is dealing with have the same good intentions. They will use this device to protect their markets and their profits at the expense of Australian consumers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response, I draw to the attention of the Minister and Senator Schacht the fact that our amendment includes provisions which do not in any way impede the importation of the original work; that is why the application is in progress. I believe that may assuage some of their concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In leading for the Opposition on the Crimes (Aviation) Bill 1991, I make the opening statement that the Opposition supports the legislation before the Senate this morning. The purpose of this Bill, which applies to all aircraft in Australia, is to consolidate the provisions of four existing Acts which form the current aviation crimes legislation package. The aim of the Bill before us today is to simplify the legislation and to remove any uncertainty in relation to it.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, the Opposition will be supporting the passage of this Bill. The four Acts to be consolidated are the Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act 1972, the Civil Aviation (Offenders on International Aircraft) Act 1970, the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973 and the Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963. With the passage of this legislation these four Acts will, of course, be repealed.

The Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act 1972 implements the Hague Convention. The Hague Convention is the convention for the suppression of unlawful seizure of aircraft and was ratified by Australia on 9 September 1972.

The Civil Aviation (Offenders on International Aircraft) Act 1970 implements the Commonwealth's obligations under the Tokyo Convention. The Tokyo Convention relates to offences and certain other acts committed on aircraft. Australia acceded to it on 22 June 1970.

The Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973 implements the Montreal Convention and its protocols. The Montreal Convention is the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts against the Safety of Civil Aviation and it was ratified by this country on 12 July 1973.

The major public law conventions presently in force between ICAO-the International Civil Aviation Organisation-member states are the three that I have already mentioned: the Tokyo Convention, the Hague Convention and the Montreal Convention. They all deal with the subject of crime relating to aircraft and have generally been adopted because they respond to three basic requirements: firstly, the elimination of jurisdictional uncertainties in respect of crimes occurring on board aircraft in-flight; secondly, the securing of effective national laws against hijacking and other acts endangering civil aviation; and, thirdly, the definition of the powers of aircraft commanders to deal effectively with inflight disturbances. Given the mass transit of people which occurs around the world these days, especially in international traffic, some degree of disturbance is sadly an inevitable part of travel.

By the time Australia became a party to the conventions that I have outlined, Australian law in the area of crimes on aircraft was already well developed. The conventions implemented by the first three Acts consolidated in this Bill are contained in the schedules to the Act. The fourth Act to be consolidated applies strictly within Australia and is known as the Aircraft Act-the Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963, which was the earliest Australian enactment to deal specifically with the problem of crimes occurring in aircraft. I note in passing that the conventions overlap to some degree, as do the Acts which implement them and the Crimes (Aircraft) Act.

The Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963 is, as I have said, domestically oriented. It governs behaviour on board certain aircraft and prescribes offences in relation to aircraft. One of the difficulties we have is that aviation came along after the Constitution was drawn up. So there is no specific reference giving powers to the Commonwealth in relation to aviation. Broadly, the only way the Commonwealth can legislate in respect of aviation, and it has a genuine interest in controlling aviation in so far as one of the characteristics of aviation is its flexibility and range of operations-therefore it is quite national in character-is with the full cooperation of the States. By and large, the States have cooperated very well. The legislation that I referred to in the earlier part of this speech has always been matched by complementary legislation being put down by the States.

In general, the legislative powers of the Commonwealth cannot extend to flights made within State boundaries, except to the extent authorised in section 51(i.), (xxix.) and (xxxix.) of the Constitution. Basically, the law is contained in the fourth Act to be consolidated-the Crimes (Aircraft) Act. As I said before, most of the States have enacted complementary legislation. I will digress for a moment and make a personal observation on the legislation. I have a private concern that the legislation could have been written in a more direct way with respect to offences against aircraft themselves. Clause 25(1) of the Bill states:
A person who commits an unlawful act of the kind mentioned in subsection 10(1) is guilty of an offence if any of the following applies:
The important part of that clause is `of the kind mentioned'. `Of the kind mentioned' relates to an earlier clause in the Bill-clause 10(1) (a) (ii)-which states:
destroys an aircraft in service, or causes damage to such an aircraft which renders it incapable of flight or which is likely to endanger its safety in flight;

My comment on that is that the Commonwealth has taken unto itself, through the Civil Aviation Authority and its predecessors, very stringent powers in relation to maintenance and what can be done to aircraft. No un authorised people can touch an aeroplane, other than to clean it or, maybe, to change the spark plugs if they know what they are doing. Any dismantling of an aeroplane, any maintenance activity, has to be signed out by an authorised person. Any components put onto that aircraft must have release notes, certificates of authenticity of some sort, attesting to their origins and their quality. In short, the Commonwealth has taken very stringent powers over what can be done to an aircraft.

I would have thought it was reasonable in this legislation to have had just a blanket proposition that anyone who interferes with an aircraft with malicious intent is guilty of a crime. While intent is always hard to establish, it is certainly part of our legal system. For example, premeditated murder is a much more serious crime than accidental death which carries the charge of manslaughter. Given the powers that the Commonwealth has had before in relation to the maintenance of aircraft, this provision could have been spelt out more simply, rather than as it appears in the Act that `it is likely to endanger the safety of an aircraft in flight'. I assume, though, that the courts would take a pretty liberal interpretation of what is likely to endanger the flight of an aircraft.

To return to the Bill: the Tokyo Convention adds little to the Crimes (Aircraft) Act while the Hague Convention has slightly more impact, but in a rather restricted sphere. The Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act makes some further amendments to the Crimes (Aircraft) Act particularly in relation to hijacking. The Crimes (Aircraft) Act contains two principal parts. The first of these, Part II, is concerned with the criminal character and consequences of any act done on board an aircraft in flight and the second, Part III, deals with acts specifically affecting the safety of the aircraft and passengers. Both these parts apply to aircraft engaged in flights in relation to which the Commonwealth's jurisdiction is constitutionally authorised. Two broad bases of jurisdiction are adopted: firstly, in relation to Australian registered aircraft and, secondly, in relation to foreign aircraft on their way to and from Australia.

This Act, the Crimes (Aircraft) Act, was being debated in Australia at the same time as the ICAO-sponsored Tokyo Convention was agreed upon. The need to have precisely formulated legislation on the books was in response to the increased incidence of hijacking world wide. The Minister for Civil Aviation at the time was Senator the Honourable Sir Shane Paltridge. In his second reading speech, he referred to the Tokyo Convention with its emphasis on the jurisdiction of the State in which the aircraft was registered.

Australia's first hijacking incident occurred on 19 July 1960 when a passenger on board a Trans-Australia Airlines Electra flying between Brisbane and Sydney threatened to blow up the aircraft unless he was flown to Singapore. He was subsequently overwhelmed on the aircraft and served 10 years imprisonment after being convicted. The interesting thing about it is that there was quite a protracted legal trial before his conviction. That led to the setting up of the legislation. That first conviction for hijacking under Queensland law was quashed by the Supreme Court of Queensland owing to uncertainty as to whether the offence occurred before or after the aircraft left the State of Queensland. Following this incident, the Federal Government introduced provisions into the Air Navigation Regulations. However, those measures were seen purely as an interim measure pending the introduction of legislation which was the Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963.

The Crimes (Aviation) Bill 1991, which we are discussing, contains five parts and five schedules. Part 1 deals with definitions and interpretation. It defines terms such as the meaning in relation to this legislation of the oft-used word threatened. It defines hijacking and all the other parts of the Bill. This legislation and the provisions of the Tokyo Convention are not limited to Australian territory or citizens, but ensure that the Commonwealth, in accordance with its international obligations, may prosecute an offender within its jurisdiction no matter where the offence occurred.

Part 2 deals with offences and covers in division 1 hijacking and other acts of violence aboard aircraft. Hijacking is outlined in subsections (1) and (2) as punishable on conviction by imprisonment for life. Acts of violence against passengers and crew are also made punishable. Division 2 relates to other offences on board aircraft engaged in certain flights. It applies to aircraft the criminal law of the Jervis Bay Territory, which is Commonwealth territory, and so on through the various divisions of part 2 of the Bill. Part 3 covers the provisions giving effect to the Tokyo Convention, which forms schedule 4 of the Bill, and parts 4 and 5 of the Bill are really the administrative and procedural measures for the application of this Bill. Part 4 covers restoring control of the aircraft and dealing with offenders, and part 5 is mainly of an administrative nature.

In summary, therefore, the Bill before the Senate today brings together necessary legislation in relation to crimes and offences against aircraft and passengers in the one Act and simplifies and dispels in some areas the uncertainty about the application of existing law. We wish this Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Crimes (Aviation) Bill 1991, which is designed to consolidate the provisions of four Acts forming the current aviation crimes legislative package-that is, the Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act 1972, the Civil Aviation (Offenders on International Aircraft) Act 1970, the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973 and the Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an unfortunate fact that the hijacking of aircraft has become one of the risks of travelling in today's world. The Australian Democrats welcome the consolidation of the laws relating to it as well as the provisions that are made. I note that in part 2 a series of offences is created under universal jurisdiction, which is nevertheless limited to the involvement of Australians. We note that in part 3 the authority of the aircraft commander, in accordance with the Tokyo Convention in relation to acts done on board an aircraft, is provided for. In parts 4 and 5 administrative and procedural matters are set out. I wish to confirm that the Australian Democrats will be supporting this Bill unamended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in welcoming the Crimes (Aviation) Bill into the Senate and in supporting its passage through this chamber. I say that because it seeks to address a major problem in the world today, which is the rise of international terrorism. Terrorism has posed for some time now a major threat to established governments and to the legal systems that attempt to punish crime. There is a very simple reason why this is so. Terrorists frequently plan their crimes so that those crimes are transnational-that is, a portion of the crime is committed in one state and a portion in another state or the crime is committed, for example, in the case of an aircraft, when the aircraft is outside the boundaries of any particular state and may be flying over the high seas. Therefore, it becomes very difficult to punish terrorists and to deter acts of terrorism unless every nation in the world is willing to take a tough stand against terrorism.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw some attention to the provisions of division 3 aircraft, as they are defined in clause 3 of the Bill, and the offences contained in clauses 16 through to 24 inclusive. The definition of a division 3 aircraft is such that it covers a foreign aircraft when its flight commenced in Australia or when the aircraft was intended to fly to Australia.

Section 12 of the Bill, which has to be read in conjunction with that definition, gives jurisdiction over people who commit offences on those aircraft, even if the people in question are not Australian citizens. Basically, this Bill seeks to extend territoriality, albeit to a limited extent, so that more nations are in a position to try to punish terrorists for the crimes that they commit against innocent passengers aboard aircraft. This is very important because there are many acts of terrorism that go unpunished.

In the last three years alone, some 12 Australian citizens have been the victims of political unrest overseas-12 Australians killed in politically motivated violence. In May this year alone, we saw the death in Peru of Sister Irene McCormack and we saw the killing in Lebanon of another Australian citizen, Mr Ali Chahine. We can do nothing but condemn the evil nature of these acts and the evil people who perpetrate these acts, because these acts of terrorism are committed with one intent, and that is to inspire fear in innocent people; for political purposes, they turn ordinary innocent people into scapegoats and political pawns. I do not care what nationality people belong to or where they are-in this day and age, people have a right to travel free from fear and intimidation and free from the threat of murder, kidnapping or maiming. Unfortunately, terrorists do not see it that way.

Therefore, I wish to urge the widest possible interpretation of the provisions contained in this Bill, if unfortunately they ever have to be interpreted by an Australian court, because we cannot allow terrorists to escape on technicalities. We cannot allow them to take advantage of loopholes in laws between one country and another, because while we do that-while any nation in the world does that-we give a green light to terrorists, and we give a green light to the use of fear and repression against innocent people for political ends.

In this respect I draw the Senate's attention to the seventh report of the Draft Code of Crimes Against the Peace and Security of Mankind, which was prepared under the auspices of the United Nations General Assembly. In particular, I draw the Senate's attention to the consideration in that report of what constitutes a crime against humanity. For some time a crime against humanity was only considered to be a particularly despicable act that was perpetrated in the course of a war. But as international events change, as the circumstances in our world change, we find more and more politically motivated acts designed to target individuals from particular races or religions or political groups. I do not believe that this is the sort of world we wish to encourage.

That is why I believe that it is necessary for all nations to give the widest scope to the definition of crimes against humanity and to adopt laws that will let any nation punish people who commit these crimes against humanity. I note that at paragraph 35 of the report it says:

In 1943 the United Nations Commission then proposed to term such breaches `crimes against humanity', considering that they represented breaches of a particular kind which, even though committed during the War, had original characteristics which set them apart, in certain aspects, from war crimes.

In other words, as far back as 1943 we recognised that there were certain offences which should not just be war crimes but, much more than that, should be considered crimes against all of humanity. Once the international order accepts that basic premise, there is a consequent obligation upon every nation to recognise that crimes against humanity can also occur outside war. Terrorism is clearly one such crime. Of course, the question is: what motives make an ordinary offence such as murder more than just murder but make it a crime against humanity? This is deserving of consideration. It is a matter that has not clearly been decided yet, but I think we ought to turn our minds to it.
Paragraph 65 states in part:

Only crimes which either by their magnitude and savagery or by their large number or by the fact that a similar pattern was applied at different times and places endangered the international community or shocked the conscience of mankind warranted intervention by states other than that on whose territory the crimes had been committed, or whose subjects had become their victims.

That says that there are certain crimes so heinous, so despicable, that every nation should have a right to put the perpetrators on trial and, if they are found guilty, to punish them. It is almost a recognition of an international duty to put those people on trial. I will come back to that matter later because there is an important distinction to be made.

Clearly, there is a recognition that there are some acts that are so evil, so violent, that any nation should have a right to put the people responsible on trial and to punish them. That leapfrogs many of the ordinary tests of jurisdiction which have existed previously in international law, because in 1935 the Harvard Draft Convention on Jurisdiction with respect to Crime recognised the existence at that time of six different principles, one of which was rejected when the draft was prepared.
That sixth principle of jurisdiction which was rejected in 1935 is called the `passive personality principle'. That principle says that any nation has a right to try a crime--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a bit erudite for us, isn't it?

—It may be a bit erudite for Senator Button but I cannot help that. It said that any nation had a right to put on trial a person who committed a crime against its citizens. At that time the United States and the United Kingdom opposed that passive personality principle and so it was not accepted. In the intervening period, however, we have seen the United States and the United Kingdom become the most strident advocates of tougher measures to fight terrorism and of the passive personality principle. In the United States this has been embodied in what is called the `Anti-terrorism Act'. In the United Kingdom it was recognised in 1946 in DPP v. Joyce, in which a sort of extraterritoriality based upon the passive personality principle was accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: So the big stumbling block that existed in 1935 has now been moved out of the way. The way is open for international efforts to bring about a strict order to fight terrorism and a new reality in international relations that will say, `We will punish terrorists. No matter where you are, no matter where you run, we will hunt you down and we will try you to the full extent of the law'.

This is something that I believe we in Australia have a responsibility to do. Many Australian citizens travel overseas regularly. Many of them go, for example, to Latin America or South East Asia, or to Holland-I will turn to Holland shortly-where they can become the victims of terrorism--

TALK.START.PARA: —In Holland they were shot down by the IRA.

—As my friend and colleague Senator Patterson says, they can be shot down by the IRA. My concern is that there were two Australians who died at the hands of IRA terrorists in Roermond last year who never had justice done because of a loophole, a technicality in the law, because one country was not willing to do the right thing to fight against terrorism and was willing to go soft on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The courts took particularly lenient interpretations of the law that allowed four admitted IRA terrorists to walk free. Even if they were not going to be convicted of the murder charge, they should have been convicted on a charge of belonging to an organisation for the purposes of committing a crime. But they walked free-because we had one nation that was not willing to do its bit to uphold the safety of people overseas.

That is why I say that we can no longer entrust the safety of Australians abroad to a foreign court. We have to recognise that we have an obligation to protect our innocents abroad and we have to give warning to terrorists, no matter where they are, that if they attack an Australian, they will be hunted down to the full extent of the law, that they will not be allowed to take advantage of loopholes in the laws of other countries, and that we will not tolerate these sorts of despicable acts being done to our citizens. That is why I believe the provisions contained in the definition of Division 3 aircraft in this Bill and the provisions of sections 16 to 24 are particularly important.

Another important matter when we consider aircraft is the international crime of piracy. Piracy was recognised in international law as a crime as far back as at least the eighteenth century. By that I mean that, as far back as the 1700s, international law recognised the right of every nation to put pirates on trial and to punish them for the acts they committed on the high seas. Of course, in the eighteenth century there were no aircraft, and crimes such as hijacking did not exist.

If I have a criticism of this Bill and if I have a criticism of the international conventions to which it gives effect, it is that it does not go far enough, because pirates are not only punishable by any nation in the world whether or not its citizens were the victims, but moreover, international law recognises a duty upon states to try to punish pirates. As far as I am concerned, there is very little difference between sinking a ship and killing the people on it and blowing up an aircraft and killing the people on it.

The fact is that a pirate and a terrorist both commit their crimes with the single intention of spreading fear to achieve a political end. That is why I believe that, ultimately, the international law must evolve to a stage where terrorists are treated in the same way as pirates.

There was a problem for some period of time with an exception to piracy, which was the case of insurgents. This matter was considered by the Supreme Court of the United States in a case called United States v. The Ambrose Light. The justices considered what was an insurgent and whether it was appropriate for insurgency to be an exception to the rule of piracy. They said in the judgment of that case that an insurgent, `had not obtained any previous recognition of belligerent rights either from their own government or from the political or executive department of any other nation'. So they were saying that, at that time, a nation could attack a ship containing innocent people for the purposes of prosecuting a war but that an insurgent who was not recognised as a nation could not do so. The court, however, rejected that and said in part:

. . . that in blockading ports which all nations are entitled to enter, they attack the rights of all mankind, and menace with destruction the lives and property of all who resist their unlawful acts; that such acts are therefore piratical, and entitle the ships and the tribunals of every nation whose interests are attacked or menaced, to suppress, at their discretion, such unauthorised warfare by the seizure and confiscation of the vessels engaged in it.
That, of course, also gives those nations a right to put the particular pirates on trial.

Since then we have seen the development of the concept of war crimes and the development of a concept of crimes against humanity, so that not even a nation involved in a war is allowed to do these acts. Therefore, there is very little reason why insurgents or terrorists-call them what you will-should be given that immunity as well.

In conclusion, I am glad that this Bill has been introduced. I have great pleasure in supporting it. I hope, however, that it signals an intent on the part of the Australian Government to punish acts of terrorism most stringently and that our courts will give the widest possible scope to their interpretation of the offences contained in this Bill, because we cannot allow terrorism to flourish any longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to discussion of this Bill relates to some more technical aspects of it. Suffice it for me to say that I agree with what my colleagues have said, particularly Senator MacGibbon in his introduction and steerage of this Bill through the Senate on behalf of the Liberal and National parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Regrettably, there has not really been sufficient time for the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and its Secretary to discuss this matter fully with the Government. At the meeting of that Committee this morning, it did appear that there were some unintended consequences of what a couple of sections of the Bill actually mean. I rise to put these on notice and, if appropriate, to seek a response from the Government so that the matter may be cleared up.

I accept that this is a consolidation of previous Acts and that, accordingly, it is drafted, one hopes, in a way that encompasses what was-and hopefully what was was correct-but it is being put in a simpler form. It did appear to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee that there were some particular problems. Those problems relate to clauses 39 and 40.

I draw the Senate's attention to clause 39, which says that where a person is brought before a magistrate under this Act and a warrant has not been issued- that is, if a person has been arrested without a warrant-then the magistrate must, if satisfied that more time is reasonably required for deciding whether criminal or extradition proceedings should be started, remand the person, either in custody or on bail, for a period of not more than seven days.

The Act goes on to provide that if a person is remanded and within seven days the prosecuting authorities have not yet made up their minds, then that person can be remanded in custody for a further seven days-and so it appears it can go on ad infinitum, so that every seven days one could come back and keep in custody a person who had been arrested without warrant. That is what section 39 appears to say.

However, section 40 then goes on to say that where a person remanded in custody under section 39 is still held in custody at the end of the prescribed period, which we will come to later, then that person may apply to the Supreme Court for an order that he or she be released. Where, on application by a person, the Supreme Court is satisfied that the Attorney-General has been given reasonable notice, the Court must, unless reasonable cause is shown for delaying that person's release, order that the person be released. But a person could be in this seven day, seven day, seven day retention in custody without warrant until the end of the prescribed period.

Section 40(3) defines `prescribed period' in relation to a person as meaning two months after the date of the order under section 39 under which the person is held in custody. The order under section 39 appears to refer to the remand but, as I have mentioned, the remand can go on before a magistrate for seven days, seven days, seven days, ad infinitum.

However, section 40, which is meant to give the person a chance to go before the Supreme Court and get released, says he can only do that two months after the date on which the order is made. But the order can keep on being made, so it is not a finite period. Maybe the prescribed period should be amended to say it is two months from the date of the original order under section 39. That may be worth having a look at.

That is one particular problem: it appears that a person who has been arrested on warrant can be kept in custody indefinitely on the order of a magistrate, who keeps extending it for seven days after seven days after seven days. The relief that is apparently there to allow someone to apply to the Supreme Court after two months, does not appear to ever start because the starting date for the two months does not seem to be finite.

The other aspect is that the `prescribed period' is defined also, if the person has applied for a writ of habeas corpus, as two months after the day on which the application, or the appeal relating to it, is finally determined. One would think that if he has applied for habeas corpus and has been successful, he is out of gaol anyhow. Does this suggest that this legislation, by implication in a very offhand way, is to overcome or to militate against the benefits given to us by habeas corpus, which of course have been with us since the very early days of Western civilisation?

If that is intended, it should be expressed in a more appropriate way rather than in an offhand way at the edge of this sort of Bill. The only other interpretation there could possibly be is that if a writ for habeas corpus is made but is unsuccessful, then the two months starts from that day. But again, one would think that if the writ for habeas corpus has been unsuccessful, then it is unlikely that the application to the Supreme Court to be released under section 40(1) would be successful, because without going into the intricacies of habeas corpus and what section 40(1) means, it would seem they are the same thing. In both instances they are an application by a person to the Supreme Court to be released from custody, after having been held in custody by order of a magistrate on this seven day, seven day, seven day period.

Whether that is right or wrong, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee was unclear. It certainly seemed, from our reading of it at the Committee meeting this morning, that that is an interpretation. If that is the interpretation, it seems unfair, and, I would suggest, unintended, and it should be looked at. There may, however, be some explanation by the Minister or the Department to suggest that the interpretation that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has put on it is not correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this legislation. I say to Senator Macdonald that while I think it would be the Government's view that the interpretation he seeks to put on this is correct and is reflected in the Bill, we agree with him that it may be desirable to have a small amendment to clarify it. An amendment is being prepared. It is a very small amendment, based on the draftsman's advice, which will supplement, as it were, the amendment which the Government has already signalled its intention to move. I am assuming that that amendment will be here by the time we reach the committee stage of the Bill-which may be a false assumption. If it is a false assumption, I will keep talking for a minute or two.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very interesting topic. Senator O'Chee related the history of the matter going back to 1945. I interjected and said it was an extraordinarily erudite performance, and I think he took it as being a criticism. It was not at all. Erudition in these matters is very important for the Senate. An historical perspective and a degree of outrage, real or synthetic, are important in considering these issues. So I welcome his contribution and all the other contributions that have been made to this important piece of legislation because this is a matter of great concern and Australia's attitude on the issue should be quite clear.

I thank all the honourable senators who have contributed and I commend the legislation to the Parliament. Having made those views available to the Senate, I now commend the second reading to the Senate. If necessary, we can consider any more controversial issues in the committee stage of the Bill.
