PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I deal with Senator MacGibbon's question, I will table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government's amendments and new clauses to be moved to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As I indicated earlier, there is a small amendment to be moved in relation to the search powers. I now have a copy of that amendment and I understand it is to be given to honourable senators shortly. The first Government amendment is necessary to ensure that there is a complete consolidation of provisions in the four statutes comprising the existing Crimes (Aircraft) Act. Senator Macdonald touched on this point in his remarks. One of those provisions, section 26 of the Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963, empowers an aircraft commander or a person authorised by the Minister for Aviation to search the aircraft and any person, luggage or freight on board the aircraft or about to be put on the aircraft, if that aircraft commander suspects that an offence is being or might be committed. This search power, which is an important part of the security network ensuring aviation safety, was overlooked in the development of the Bill currently before the Senate. Of course, this search power is essential.
Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I shall report progress.

—My question, which relates to the Soviet Union, is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Australian Government prepared to show the same level of support for democratically elected representatives, such as Boris Yeltsin, as is being demonstrated by the governments of the United States and Britain? What has the Australian Government done in support of courageous individuals and republics such as the Baltic states in their opposition to the dictatorship?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have made it perfectly clear, publicly and privately, that we do very strongly support Mr Yeltsin as the freely elected President of Russia and the most credible voice in the Soviet Union in opposition to the new regime. We strongly support his declared goal of the restoration of Mr Gorbachev as President of the Soviet Union. I put that very firmly on the record lest there be any possible cause for doubt about that.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of other kinds of support, there are obvious limitations on our capacity as a nation to influence the situation. As for various economic assistance measures which were in place or about to be put into place, we have made clear that we regard ourselves as having no option but to put those on hold for the moment, in line with our other Western partners and like-minded countries. We will, of course, be keeping the situation under close review in that respect.

The measures in question have comprised not only the provision of credit facilities, which are on hold on the basis that was described by Senator Button in his very detailed press release yesterday, but also the Australian program of training for the Soviet Union. A new program announced in yesterday's Budget-$4.5m over three years, intended to provide advanced postgraduate training in business skills for Soviet managers-premised as it was on support from the Soviet Government for the market reform process, which must now be regarded as very much in doubt, is clearly on hold until the situation clarifies and hopefully improves.

The remaining demonstration of overt support for the Soviet Union that we had made in recent times was our commitment to subscribe some $45m over five years to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. We have made known our view-we may not have yet; I have instructed this to be done-that the Soviet Union at present, in our judgment, does not meet the test of political conditionality which is associated with support from the EBRD. I do not think there will be much difficulty in persuading the EBRD to that effect, but we have made it perfectly clear that we do not want any money being spent by the EBRD in the present circumstances.

Beyond that, we have followed up our representations to the Soviet charge yesterday with specific contact now achieved in Moscow with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Again, the Australian position has now been placed on record. I do not know what Senator Hill wants us to do beyond all those various measures, but I think that represents a realistic response by Australia in a situation that manifestly we all deplore.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that the Government has decided to legislate for a prescribed level of superannuation support which employers should provide for their employees? Can the Minister advise the Senate as to the social and economic significance of this decision for all Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is a fact, as announced in the Budget yesterday by the Treasurer, Mr Kerin, that the Government will legislate for a 5 per cent superannuation provision from 1 July next year, with a 3 per cent provision for employers with payroll bills of below $500,000. Senator Foreman asks me about the significance of this decision by the Government. It should be said at the start that this is one of the greatest social advances by this Government or any other government in the history of the federation of Australia. Indeed, the people who complain about this are the people who have complained about every significant social reform in this community. They are direct line descendants of those who complained about taking children out of the mines and of doing all the other significant and social reforms which we now look back on as major achievements for ordinary people in the community.

ANSWER.PARA: I should also say that the Government is faced with a political and economic imperative. The population of this country is greying. We are getting older and before much longer more people will be retired. Provision for retirement with dignity is a necessity that has to be faced up to. It is a necessity that we have faced up to and will not walk away from because it is our responsibility to plan now and make prudent provision now to ensure that people, when they come to retirement later, can do so with dignity. There may be some who wish to run away from it, but the Government does not. We have faced it in this Budget.

The criticism of this measure suggests or implies that it will apply immediately but, of course, it will not. It will apply, by legislation, on 1 July next year. Therefore, the stable recovery of the economy, which this Budget has provided for and which will not overheat the economy, can proceed in its early phases without this being an impost on business and, as the recovery quickens and picks up next year, this provision can be met.

As well as that, there is an assumption that no-one seems to be paying superannuation now and that a 5 per cent surcharge is to be levied on everyone. That, of course, is not true. Most employers have an award requirement to pay at least 3 per cent superannuation. Therefore, when the impost comes, it will be only an impost of an extra 2 per cent and, indeed, is a year off. It is even less than that for small business and maybe will be no impost at all. Small business for this purpose has been defined as companies with about 24 employees which, by any definition of small business, is middle to medium size in an economy like Australia's.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—Let me make two other points in conclusion. It has been said that this is bad for business. There is no estimate available from Treasury as to what superannuation funds will be worth by the turn of the century under our scheme, but private sector estimates, based on a 9 per cent outcome, are that, by the year 2000, the total holdings of superannuation funds in Australia will be between $300 billion and $600 billion. That is money held by Australian working people in their superannuation funds for investment in Australian industry. This must be a significant pool of investment because, while on the one hand it is a cost, on the other hand it is also a benefit. These funds need to be invested to maintain their value and what better source or what better target for investment than the economy of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The final point I make is that we have set a target of 9 per cent by the end of this century. That is a target which, as we travel towards it, could be 12 per cent with employee contributions or some consideration on tax. It is a target of 9 per cent, but it is a target related, importantly, to the wage outcome performance every year. As we perform through accords in achieving moderate wage outcomes, thus we will perform in putting in place the cornerstones of this significant social advance. But if the wages target were to blow out, obviously that would be a consideration as to how quickly we would move to the target on superannuation. This is a major social advance. It should be recognised as that. It is also a significant investment boon to the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Treasurer will be aware that the Budget Papers show that total public borrowings are expected to blow out to $17 billion, or 4.3 per cent of GDP, this year. Is the Minister aware that this wantonly irresponsible plundering of the nation's already depleted savings pool represents the largest collapse in public savings ever recorded? Does the Minister agree that there can be no sustained lift in employment until national savings are substantially increased? Given the Government's voracious demand for funds, is there now any way that a rise in interest rates can be avoided, apart from very short term political manipulation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly have not heard those views expressed before, other than the views expressed by Senator Short.
—Why don't you take the Kerin line-`I would not have a clue'?

—There is an old adage about the pot calling the kettle black. Senator Parer is the pot in this case, I have to tell him. I have not heard any comments of the kind contained in Senator Short's question. Certainly I agree with the figures. Senator Short described them as `wantonly irresponsible'. Looking back over the history of this country, I cannot agree with the assumption that there can be no sustainable lift in employment with that level of public borrowings because there have been very high levels of public borrowings accompanied by increases in employment.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Short will realise-and we have debated this issue before-that the Budget is now in deficit for the first time for several years. I have consistently maintained in this place that it is a structural deficit caused by the recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even the Treasurer admits that you have a structural deficit.
—Yes.
—Not cyclical, structural.

—Yes. We have talked about the structural integrity of the Budget at Question Time on numerous occasions when Senator Short has asked me questions on this issue. The fact of the matter is that it is believed that the Budget will be in deficit for a relatively short time. With an improvement in the economy, the deficit will return to a surplus and the borrowing requirement will not be as great.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister deny that if the Government had exercised more self-discipline in yesterday's Budget, rather than use the Budget to pay off the debts owing by the Prime Minister following the recent challenge to his leadership, then interest rates would be lower than they now inevitably will be?

—If there had been by this Government a display of fiscal rectitude as Senator Short's party now advocates, and continually psyches itself up in order to persuade itself that it would have the guts to do, the answer to that question may be yes. But the fact of the matter is, as the Treasurer said in his Budget Speech and elsewhere, this Budget is about medium term management of the Australian economy and we are not going to produce instant solutions in terms of a Budget.

—My question is directed to you, Mr President. In view of the continuing crisis in the Soviet Union and the determination of honourable senators to remain informed, can you advise the chamber whether steps are being taken to provide senators' offices with a 24-hour news service? What arrangements have been made and when will they become effective?

—Senator Loosley raised this question with me earlier today. Since then a number of honourable senators, including Senator Lewis, and, I believe, the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade have asked me whether, given the events in Russia, the international Cable News Network service which was provided to the Parliament during the Gulf crisis could be reinstated. Officers of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, of which the Sound and Vision Office is an operational unit, are discussing with CNN the possible reconnection to the Parliament, perhaps by late this afternoon or early this evening. When I have further information I will advise all honourable senators.

—I preface my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer by noting the recent comments by Minister Dawkins that the trend in Europe has been for governments to be re-elected despite high levels of unemployment. Given that the Government yesterday budgeted for a million unemployed throughout 1991-92, is the level of unemployment irrelevant to this Labor Government as long as it can get re-elected? How high does unemployment have to get before the Government changes its commitment to free market ideology and intervenes in the economy to boost investment and job opportunities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler has asked me this question in numerous guises over two or three years. First of all, I repeat some of the things I have said in the past. Of course the Government deeply regrets the current level of unemployment. It is higher than any of us would wish. In saying that I remind Senator Spindler again that it was the Government's view in 1990-91 that spending growth was unsustainably high and we would have been in much greater difficulty if we had not taken steps to slow demand in the economy. That contributed significantly to unemployment.
—That is a result of your wages policy.

—Not wages policy; monetary policy. I say that for the enlightenment of Senator Alston, who interjected earlier with a suggestion that, if he understood it correctly, wages policy had contributed to unemployment.
—Wages policy has.

—It has not. Those opposite are the experts on this. Wages policy contributed to unemployment in 1982-83 because they had no wages policy. Those opposite are the experts on that. Let me say, Senator Spindler, for the purpose of helping the kinder, as they call them in Germany, understand the answer, that Government policy in 1990-91 was a contributing factor to higher levels of unemployment. In terms of sustainable employment in the future, we have greatly reduced inflation and reduced the current account deficit, which is the basis for sustainable growth and the creation of new jobs in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that Senator Spindler is concerned about a transition period to recovery. I will make one or two comments about that. If one looks at the Budget, the key measures, together with the package announced in the March 1991 economic statement, provide for an increase in expenditure on labour market programs from $399m to $598m, which is an increase of 50 per cent. An expansion of the job skill program to provide training and work experience for 9,000 long term unemployed people was announced in March. A further $15m was made available for the training program and skills program. About $420m has been allocated to TAFE, including $40m in 1991-92 for extra TAFE places. One hundred and eighty million dollars has been allocated to entry level and skills training, including $12m for measures to keep apprentices and trainees in employment.

These measures are not put as any solution to the problem of significant unemployment, but they are designed to strengthen the skills base of job seekers and workers, thereby hastening their return to employment and ensuring that skill shortages do not emerge during the recovery period. For those in extreme financial crisis, the Government in the Budget has allocated an additional amount of money for emergency relief over the next two financial years. The Government has also reduced waiting periods for rent assistance for the unemployed. All those measures contrast with the policies of the Opposition as enunciated by its present leader.

The present Leader of the Opposition has said that clearly most of the long term unemployed will be expected to accept jobs that they would otherwise find unacceptable or live by their own means. The programs enunciated in this Budget and in the March statement do not require people to live by their own means, whatever that phrase means in the minds of those opposite. I could go on and say a few words about other proposed economic policies of the Opposition, which would only enhance in the present circumstances the difficult situation which the unemployed face.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am grateful that the Minister has stated that the measures he has rattled off are no solution to the present level of unemployment. I would have been much more impressed if he had suggested that the Government was going to reconsider public investment, since private investment is shown to be collapsing in the Government's own Budget Papers. I also refer to some comments by the present Treasurer, Mr Kerin, who seemed to indicate that at some stage-at least before he was pulled into line-he was prepared to take a more interventionist line.
—Order! Senator Spindler, this is becoming a speech, not a supplementary question.
—I am finishing. My question is: since this was largely a Keating Budget, will Mr Kerin be given the opportunity to provide a supplementary Budget and when?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, there are no proposed or intended areas of significant public sector investment to replace, as it were, in the terms of Senator Spindler's question, a fall in private investment. It is not anticipated or intended by the Government. We think that private investment will pick up as the economy picks up.
—You have been saying that for years. You were telling Fred Chaney that when he was here, when the pipeline was blocked. I remember that question. They are not going to believe you any more.
—Nothing would unblock your pipeline.

—I would be helped in dealing with Senator Vanstone's interjection if my colleague Senator Evans would be kind enough to shut up. We have been saying these things for years, and until the recession came along--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they will. Senator Vanstone makes rude gestures at me in the Senate chamber and I cannot respond to them. I cannot find words adequate to deal with Senator Vanstone. But let me say this: if the honourable senator looks at the investment figures, which I think are what she is making noises about, she will see that the investment performance in 1988, 1989 and 1990 was the best this country had seen for years.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite any one of those opposite to come in tomorrow with the figures. This is a hopeless, pathetic, noisy Opposition. I invite Senator Vanstone to come into the chamber tomorrow with the figures. I invite her to bring in the figures and put a question to me. If I am wrong, I will make a gesture at Senator Vanstone which will shame her.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections from both sides of the chamber.

—I have to deal with an Opposition in here; when the polls go up, the noise goes up and the intellectual content goes down. That is the problem which this country is confronted with. I challenge those opposite to come in tomorrow and advance their argument. Those opposite-the whole 30 of them or however many there are-have a big chance to do me over on the basis of fact instead of noise. None of them will wimp in here to do it because they will not be able to. Let us come back tomorrow and have the argument.

ANSWER.PARA: I can inform Senator Spindler that there is no program of replacing private sector investment with public sector investment. As I said to him, private sector investment will recover in the medium term. The honourable senator asked about Mr Kerin. A refreshing characteristic of this Budget is that it is a medium term Budget. Mr Kerin has articulated that view very clearly and if the honourable senator goes to the Budget Papers he will see the argument advanced there on numerous occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It relates to the coup d'etat and the state of emergency in the Soviet Union. I refer to reports overnight of widespread civil disobedience in the USSR in reaction to the coup, some accounts of violence, and even suggestions of desertion in the Soviet military. Can the Minister give an updated assessment of the situation in the Soviet Union, including the Government's present judgment of the likelihood of the coup being sustained?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are both positive and negative elements in the reports that we are receiving and it is very difficult at this stage to balance them out in any very credible way. On the negative side, we remain very deeply concerned at reports-some unconfirmed-that Soviet armed forces are using force in various parts of the Soviet Union. We now have reports-I think this has been in the media-of four civilian deaths now in Moscow resulting from clashes with the military. Moreover, the military has moved large reinforcements into Moscow and it appears to be using tanks against barricades around the Russian Parliament. The most recent reports in that respect are that those tanks stopped some 500 metres short of the Parliament building with a massive crowd intervening.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been further unconfirmed reports in the last hour or so-in fact, rather flimsy ones-that there may be some withdrawal of troops and equipment from the centre of Moscow, but it is simply too early to make a judgment about the veracity of those reports. There was also shooting this morning in the vicinity of the Parliament building.

Again, there are some quite disturbing reports coming from the Baltic states following the seizure by Soviet forces of strategic targets, including broadcasting stations. The military has been threatening to assault the parliaments of both Lithuania and Latvia, although we have not had confirmation that that has actually happened. Moreover, very recently there has been a further assault in Estonia on the radio and television station in Tallinn and an occupation of that. In Latvia, troops have delivered an ultimatum to the defenders around the Parliament to disarm. On the reports available to us, Soviet troops have in fact arrested Latvia's Prime Minister, Mr Ivans Godmanis.

Those are the negatives. On the more positive side, it is still unclear that this bid for power will succeed. As I said yesterday, we should not rush to the judgment that the coup is irreversible. Overnight there has been considerable turmoil in the membership of the so-called State of Emergency Committee. Three of its members have resigned or, for some other reason, relinquished their positions. One of them, Prime Minister Pavlov, seems on reports available to us to have been genuinely ill with some kind of heart attack. But as to Defence Minister Yazov and KGB chief Kryuchkov, although stated also to have been ill, such illness as they have had seems to be more of the diplomatic variety, and possibly based on their concerns about whether massive force should be used to consolidate the coup.

It is also obvious that the coup is encountering very clear opposition in other ways. President Yeltsin's call for strikes, anti-coup demonstrations and general resistance has been heeded in many parts of the Russian federation, with over 100,000 people rallying in Moscow last night our time and up to 200,000 in Leningrad.

A number of Soviet military units have gone over to supporting the populace. Just who and where they are is a little unclear in terms of a tally at the moment, but there are significant movements of that kind occurring. Moreover, the leaderships of the Soviet Union's two key republics after the Russian federation, the Ukraine and Kazakhstan, have assured President Yeltsin of their support.

It is not possible to give any balanced judgment, as I said, as to what is likely to happen. The most important thing right now is that the Soviet authorities not step over the precipice and attempt to use force against the populace. If that occurs, needless to say it will have the most profoundly negative implications for Australia's relations with the Soviet Union, as it will for the USSR's relations with all civilised countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I draw the Minister's attention to the Treasurer's statement in yesterday's Budget Speech that `wage outcomes must be more directly linked to improvements in labour productivity'. What is the Government's forecast for labour productivity growth in the coming year, given that growth in GDP per hour worked has not exceeded one per cent in any one of the last six years? Will he agree that the Government's wages target of 4.5 per cent growth in the forthcoming financial year is, therefore, likely to be well in excess of labour productivity growth? What are the implications of this for business profit and employment opportunities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let me remind Senator Vanstone that under this Government real unit labour costs have decreased in each of several years.
—It has done a lot for employment!

—Senator Kemp, who flops out of the right wing think tank in Melbourne and comes up here full of new ideas, says that it has done a lot for employment. Senator Kemp should get together with some of his brighter colleagues and work out what unemployment in this country is currently about. It is not about wages policy. This is the loopy view that emanates from sections of this Opposition day after day with noisy interjections and no analysis, as with everything else Opposition members say. That is what happens here. A few weeks ago it was good enough for Senator Kemp to come here to argue that interest rates were responsible for unemployment. He was more right then than he is today.

ANSWER.PARA: Coming back to Senator Vanstone's question, let me say that it is very difficult to measure productivity movements, but in the case of an economy coming out of a recession productivity figures always improve, because there is an increase in use of capacity and a variety of other factors, such as increased production, which contribute to productivity figures. All one can say with a degree of certainty is that as this economy comes out of the recession there will be significant increases in productivity, as happened when the economy came out of the Liberal Government's recession. That will happen again on this occasion.

In response to Senator Vanstone's suggested point about wage outcomes, I am not able to say what the wage outcomes will finally be. But let me say that this Government, in terms of its record on wage outcomes--

TALK.START.PARA: —If you don't have a wages policy, you cannot run the economy.
—Precisely, Senator.
—Order! Senator Vanstone asked a question and Senator Button will be permitted to answer it.

—Senator Kemp has learnt from the Fraser Government experience at last. He just said, by way of interjection, `If you haven't got a wages policy, you cannot run the economy'. That is precisely a description of the Opposition. Our record on wages policy has been very good. I do not know whether the wages outcome will match exactly productivity increases, but I bet they will be pretty close. Come back in a year and ask me.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As I understand the Minister's answer, what he is saying is that, because we are now in a recession, he expects productivity growth to be better in the forthcoming year than it has been in any of the last six years, when it has not exceeded one per cent. I would be grateful if the Minister could indicate whether he did mean to give that as an answer. Secondly, the Minister said that he cannot say what the wages outcome will be. Despite the fact that the Government estimate is a 4.5 per cent growth in 1991-92, Senator Button says that he cannot really say what the wages outcome will be. I suppose it is a bit like the Treasurer saying, `Your guess is as good as mine'. Then, at the end of Senator Button's answer-I hope he will forgive me for being confused--
—Order! Senator Vanstone will ask the supplementary question.

—I am asking for an explanation of what the answer means. At the end of his answer, having said that productivity will increase and that it will be far better than it has been in the last six years, and having said that he could not say what the wages outcome will be, the Minister brought those two together and said, `Well, they'll be pretty close. Come and ask me in a year'.
—Order! Ask the supplementary question.
—The supplementary question is this: would he have another crack at answering the question because he has evaded it thus far?

—Let me make two points, Senator. All sorts of factors bear on productivity. Many of them are probably beyond Senator Vanstone's comprehension. I will give Senator Vanstone a prepared answer on this. When Senator Chaney was a member of the Senate and the Opposition had a leader in the Senate who understood some of these issues--
—Don't exaggerate.

—It is true; he understood some of them. When Senator Chaney was in the Senate I used to get regular questions about productivity. I will give Senator Vanstone a prepared answer about that which will answer her later question. Wages outcomes are, of course, always more difficult to determine when one has a less centralised system. Under the centralised system which has operated largely during the life of this Government, wages outcomes have been very predictable and have been met. But the Opposition wants a totally decentralised system. There is no such thing as estimating wage outcomes under a totally decentralised system such as the Opposition wants. I think Senator Vanstone should have a look at the Opposition's own policy before she asks some of these questions.

—I address my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. In the light of the Budget delivered by the Treasurer yesterday, can the Minister inform the Senate what steps the Federal Government is now taking to further ensure that legal aid and legal advice continue to be made available to those most in need, particularly in rural areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Reynolds takes a particular interest in this matter as she moves in the outback areas of north Queensland and, indeed, in the major provincial towns north of Brisbane, particularly around Townsville. She has taken a major interest in the recent establishment of the community legal centre in Townsville. In this Budget the Government has tried to provide more resources for community legal centres and legal aid commissions around Australia to ensure that persons have access to legal advice, despite the fact that they do not have sufficient financial resources to purchase that advice from private practitioners in the normal way. The Commonwealth Government has almost doubled the money available for community legal centres, as stated in the Budget delivered last night. This is in recognition of the very valuable service-and I see Senator Vanstone is nodding in approval-provided by those centres.

ANSWER.PARA: The centres are invariably well situated in those areas, quite often in the inner city, where the income level of households is low and where the advice that is sought is very appropriate to the sorts of problems facing the inhabitants of those areas, tenancy law being just one example. There are many other examples.

I believe that the community legal centres which attract the voluntary service of legal practitioners-in a study given to me a few months ago it has been estimated that about $2m worth of such advice is given free of charge by lawyers attracted to serve in these community legal centres on a voluntary basis-ought to be encouraged. We will be taking steps to ensure that this extra money not only reinforces some of the existing centres but is provided to set up new centres in provincial and rural areas of Australia.

It is also a fact that the Government has provided an extra $8.4m in one-off funds for legal aid commissions over the next three years in order to enable those commissions to deal with the increase in demand that they have faced, and in particular to deal with the costs of significant criminal cases where tremendous resources are required in order to provide a defence for those who are charged, for example, in relation to conspiracy to import drugs. Very long and complex trials of many defendants can drain a legal aid commission of much money that can be better made available for the many cases that come through its doors seeking aid.

Altogether, the total Commonwealth allocation for legal aid in this year's Budget is $126m. I believe that, with a matching response from the States, either out of their own treasuries or out of Westpac moneys, we can ensure that legal aid is provided to those who have a real need in our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate or the Minister for Social Security-whoever is responsible for or knows the answer, if either. What is the peak number of unemployment beneficiaries, including Newstart and Job Search beneficiaries, expected by the Government during 1991-92, as indicated by the 50 per cent rise to about $7 billion in the Budget cost of unemployment benefits?

—The question is probably best directed to another Minister altogether who is responsible for unemployment beneficiaries. If one looks at the past few months experience, the unemployment figures in the Budget probably do not reflect with great precision the number of likely unemployment beneficiaries. But there has to be a forecast in the Budget, and I do not know at the moment precisely what that is. I will get Senator Baume the figure and provide it to him as soon as possible.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to the recent declaration under the Prices Surveillance Act relating to towage operators in major Australian ports. Does this declaration have any implication for the Government's reform program for the maritime industry? If so, do these implications extend to any Queensland ports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government deliberately involved the Prices Surveillance Authority in the reform process in the maritime area to ensure that the productivity gains that result from that program are passed on to the users. The answer to the second part of Senator Colston's question is yes, the major Queensland port of Brisbane is included in this reference. The Authority has conducted a number of inquiries into the area, including an inquiry into coastal shipping freight rates, an inquiry into charges by the stevedoring container depot industries and this inquiry into towage charges.
—And redundancy packages.

—Senator Macdonald's would be the first to be organised, if I had a say in it. The Authority found that the tugboat industry is inherently monopolistic, with only a single operator providing towage in many ports. The inquiry concluded that port users may not receive the full benefits of the Government's reforms unless the competition is increased and the charges subjected to surveillance. The Government agreed with that view. The Authority recommended that it place the prices of towage services in major ports under formal surveillance and that it monitor charges in some smaller ports.

ANSWER.PARA: Towage charges, in fact, represent a very significant part of the total cost of getting a ship in and out of port-about 10 per cent. The Minister assisting the Treasurer announced last week a formal declaration under the Prices Surveillance Act of towage operators in six major shipping ports-Sydney, Melbourne, Fremantle, Brisbane, Newcastle and Adelaide-and the monitoring of prices in smaller ports. The declaration requires that the towage companies concerned notify the Authority and obtain endorsement for the proposed increases in their charges.

The Authority will review the impact on towage charges of major crew reductions on tugs and reduction in the number of tug crews, brought about by the Government's maritime reform program. I notice that not only did the shipping industry and user groups welcome this reference but also one of the major towing companies in Australia has welcomed this scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the recent letter of the Minister for Social Security to the Prime Minister-one of the most notorious documents in modern political history-in which the Minister so eloquently complains that the Government's decision to contract out computing operations of the Department of Veterans' Affairs to the private sector will effectively prevent the Government from countering the Opposition's plans to contract out welfare services. Does the Minister agree that the move will result in a more effective payments regime with consequent benefits for pension recipients? In view of his comment in the letter that `If a government can contract to the private sector for computing of payment of pensions there is nothing in the whole area of administration that cannot be outsourced', why would even dramatically greater efficiencies not be derived from contracting out social security payments? Finally, what is the basis of the alleged fundamental principle that payments of pension should be done by the private sector, other than `we have lost our best weapon in the argument with the Opposition'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have several advantages over Senator Alston, and one is that I am in the Cabinet while he cannot make the shadow Cabinet. I have to concede to the Senate that I have not won every argument; there have been times-it does happen-when I have been defeated. Like any other Minister, when defeated, if I consider something has not been sufficiently taken into account in a Cabinet debate or to which not sufficient weight has been given, I am entitled to write to the Prime Minister-and I did.

ANSWER.PARA: Neither the Prime Minister nor the Cabinet accepted my view. As a member of the Cabinet, I therefore accept the Cabinet's view. I put a view. The Cabinet believes that the outsourcing of that particular function will not in any way lead anyone to believe that social welfare services generally can be contracted out. I accept the Cabinet view. I am glad that no-one there believes it can be interpreted in that way.

As to why we should not contract out the other services, I can recall that-and in fact I referred to this just the other day-when Senator Alston addressed that social policy research conference he was laughed at by the welfare agencies for suggesting that they could take up any of these services, because they know that they are severely under stress now and cannot do it. I suggest to him, too, having read his press releases of late, that he please understand that relief for community welfare agencies is not handled by my portfolio but by the portfolio of my colleague Brian Howe. He should please also note that the increases which occurred last year and this year are far greater than those which he has acknowledged in his press releases. I wish he could read them and get the figures right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I regret the fact that the Minister was not at the conference because in fact I made no such mention of any possibility of contracting out such services. Does the Minister stand by the contents of his letter-in particular when he says, in relation to it being possible to outsource almost anything, that not even Mrs Thatcher gave serious thought to going down this path? More importantly, does he acknowledge, the decision having been taken by the Government and those services being contracted out in Veterans' Affairs, that there is no logical reason why the same could not be done in his own Department? Finally, why did the Minister leave it so long to write to the Prime Minister? Is it because he could no longer expect any special favours, even early morning golf invitations from the present incumbent, or has he been too preoccupied with his duties as campaign manager for the former Treasurer?

—This is a top question. I wrote to the Prime Minister within a week or two of the Cabinet debating the issue. I thought that was very soon thereafter; I did not think that there was a long break. Naturally enough though, I do not like the fact that the letter was leaked more than anybody else does, but I do accept the Cabinet decision. As a Cabinet Minister, I accept that you win some, you lose some. Fortunately, I have won a lot more than I have lost and I can live with the odd defeat.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I preface my question by saying that the Minister will be aware that Westpac Banking Corporation, which has been implicated in the notorious Westpac letters saga and subjected to court action regarding its foreign currency loans management, has gained widespread influence in Australian media through its ownership of Channel 10, its board positions at Consolidated Press and Prime Television, and being banker to Capital Television, the Perth West Australian and Murdoch's News Corp, plus its broking arm, Ord Minnett, being the underwriters to one of the Fairfax bidders. I ask: given Westpac's involvement in the foreign currency loans fiasco, if it is found guilty, does its board positions on Channel 9 and Channel 10 leave it open to fit and proper questions, as happened to Alan Bond recently? Does the Minister believe that Westpac's dual board positions on Channel 9 and Channel 10 are consistent with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's responsibility to ensure that banks do not unduly control media programming, even though they have special exemptions as bank lenders? Does the Minister believe that Westpac's domination of the Channel 10 board, with all board members being Westpac directors or executives, is consistent with Westpac Chairman Sir Eric Neal's views that boards should have significant outside membership and that outside directors are necessary `to blow the whistle'?

—I do fully understand the frustration that people feel about the deficiencies of our legal system-its slowness, cost and so on-but I do not actually think that summary trial by the Senate is a particularly good substitute. In terms of Senator McLean's invitation to me to be the judge, jury and executioner of Westpac before the matter has in fact been heard, I decline. In respect of the second part of Senator McLean's question about the fitness of people, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is the appropriate body to determine this. Not only does it have sufficient legislative means to do so, but it has a demonstrated capacity to do so. In respect of the last part of the question as to the consistencies of Sir Eric Neal's views on anything, that question would be more appropriately directed to Sir Eric Neal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and refers to the March industry statement where the Industry Commission was to be asked:

QUESTION.PARA: to review measures used by our major trading partners to promote export and import replacement activities, the implications of the measures for these countries and Australia and the extent to which the measures are consistent with GATT obligations.

As US wheat sales increase in our traditional markets as part of the US-EC trade war, as food imports of $2.1 billion severely damage our agricultural and processing industries, and as no government agency collects information on subsidies provided by our major trading partners, can the Minister advise whether this review has commenced, whether it will be able to provide total subsidy levels on imports and when the results will be released?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure it is correct to say that no government agency collates information on overseas subsidies and so on. As I recall it, a very well documented report which was prepared, I think, by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics on levels of subsidies on agricultural products was published in Europe. That was two or three years ago. So I think there are collections of information on overseas subsidies and hidden industry support measures of one kind or another.

ANSWER.PARA: The inquiry by the Industry Commission, which Senator Boswell referred to, has now commenced. This inquiry relates to Australia's trading partners' promotion of exports and import replacement activities. The Commissioner has been asked to report to the Government by 8 April 1992. In May 1991 an issues paper identifying the central issues in relation to this inquiry was released by the Commission. I am sure that will be available. Senator Boswell might be interested to see it and, if I can, I will facilitate his getting one.

The Commission has called for submissions. It expects to release a draft report in October 1991 and hold public hearings in November 1991. What it intends to do is cover a wide range of measures used by other countries including export subsidies, export financing, tax incentives or concessions for exports, subsidised infrastructure and export processing zones. The countries included in the study are the United States, Japan, European Community members, New Zealand, Taiwan, the Republic of Korea, China and Singapore, as well as Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand. There will be an opportunity for Senator Boswell to see the issues which are being considered and they will be subject to public hearing in November.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. It concerns the $3.50 patient co-payment under Medicare. Given that this charge is to reduce patient demand and indirectly to address doctor over-servicing, can the Minister say what impact the introduction of the co-payment will have and how the Government intends to measure it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a national health strategy paper prepared by Professor Richardson which showed that co-payments could have an impact on demand and, in the absence of measures to deal with supply, doctors would generate more services to reduce the impact. That seems to be a straightforward and evident proposition. The Government will consult with the profession to address both the supply side and the quality of care and time. These measures are consistent with the findings of the national health strategy. I know that the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Brian Howe, intends to engage in that consultation to get this comprehensive approach to the problem.

ANSWER.PARA: Research has also indicated that there is no link between health status and the number of GP consultations attended. Health is much more than the absence of disease; it is also affected by a range of financial, environmental, housing and community service factors. Accordingly, public health should be seen in the wider context of health and community services and facilities. Rather than lowering the level of public health, the major reforms affecting the provision of primary health care services from 1 July 1992 have the potential to substantially improve health care at lower overall costs. This requires patients to assess their situation wisely to determine whether or not a GP consultation is warranted. By choosing a doctor who direct bills, non-card holder patients can limit their out-of-pocket costs to no more than $3.50 per visit. Of course, most financially disadvantaged persons should be protected by the exemption provisions for card holders and pensioners, while substantially improved Medicare safety net arrangements come into effect for everyone.

Over the last six years, Medicare has succeeded in containing the community's health care costs but this trend cannot continue indefinitely without significant damage to the quality of care available to the public. The Government therefore proposes changes to current benefits arrangements, which take effect from 1 July 1992, to encourage higher quality of care in general practice. As I say, these changes will be discussed with representative medical professional organisations over the coming months.

The aim of the discussions will be to enable both the profession and the Government to pursue their legitimate roles, while ensuring that there is a greater synthesis between the two. It is the responsibility of the profession to set and supervise standards. It is the responsibility of the Government to ensure that financing mechanisms permit access to necessary medical services while constraining costs to ensure the long term sustainability of Medicare and assisting the profession to provide high quality care.

The Health Insurance Commission records details of the fee charged and whether the service was bulkbilled or patient billed for every Medicare claim. It informs the patient when the threshold is reached and the patient is eligible for 100 per cent rebates. This data will be used to monitor the effect on patient out-of-pocket costs and whether there is a move away from bulkbilling. In addition, Medicare claims provide comprehensive data on utilisation patterns. These data will be used to examine the effects of the changes on service use overall and, for example, by region or by age group.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and follows his earlier protestations and apparent pride in his Government's investment record. I ask him quite simply: does he deny that new capital expenditure as a proportion of GDP that has gone into the tradable industries has been falling under his Government since 1986-87?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on what Senator Vanstone means by new capital expenditure. Let me bring the figures tomorrow.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I happened to mention the honourable senator's capacities in this regard. Senator Vanstone knows that there are a number of categories of investment. For example, new capital expenditure includes expenditure on non-dwelling construction.
—It has a pretty common meaning.
—It does.

—On a point of order, Mr President: I do not mind if Senator Button cannot answer the question but he need not pretend that it was not asked clearly; it was. The Minister was asked about new capital expenditure as a proportion of GDP in the tradable sector.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Senator Vanstone has now come back with a reference to the tradable goods sector.
—That is what she said.
—She did not say that.
—She did.
—She talked about investment. That is what she talked about in the first question.
—Look at the question I asked.

—I am not going to engage in this gabfest with Senator Vanstone. I will provide Senator Vanstone with the figures tomorrow. I said that the investment figures for this country in 1987-88, 1988-89 and 1989-90 were higher than they had been for years and years and years. That is true.

ANSWER.PARA: I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President--
—Mr President, I asked that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Senator Button has helped himself out, Mr President. I was going to ask whether you would help him out of his dilemma by saying he could simply refuse to answer the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Patterson asked me about physiotherapists and the ordering of X-Ray services. I seek leave to incorporate a response in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows-

Since 1 May 1991, the payment of Medicare benefits for diagnostic imaging services (diagnostic radiology, CT scanning, ultrasound, magnetic resonance imaging and nuclear scanning) has been dependent upon the service being provided by a medical practitioner at the written request of another practitioner who has no financial interest in the provision of those services. With a few exceptions, the requesting practitioner must be a medical practitioner. For X-rays of the head, the requesting practitioner may be a dental practitioner and for X-rays of the spine, the requesting practitioner may be a chiropractor.

With certain exceptions, the new written request requirement for imaging services applies to all services which are classified as ``R-type'' [requested/referred] services. Services not subject to the request requirement are classified as ``NR-type'' [unrequested/unreferred] services. For some services there is one ``(R)'' item and a corresponding ``(NR)'' item. The Schedule fees for ` `(NR)'' services are approximately 75% of those for the corresponding ``(R)'' services.

The X-ray services which are classified as ``NR-type'' services are mostly those relating to examinations of the extremities, e.g. X-rays of the arms and legs. These items are not subject to the written request requirement and, as such, have no restrictions on the payment of benefits related to who orders them.
If the medical practitioner who renders an ``NR-type'' service is prepared to accept responsibility for the medical necessity of that service, Medicare benefits would be payable.

Concerning the non-payment of Medicare benefits for ``R-type'' services (e.g. X-rays of the spine) ordered by physiotherapists, the new benefits arrangements for imaging services place referrals for these procedures on the same footing as referrals for other specialist services. This means that they are required to be rendered subject to a formal referral process and, generally, at the request of a medical practitioner.

The Australian Physiotherapy Association (APA) has raised a range of issues about the impact of this legislation on physiotherapists. It also lodged a submission seeking to have the legislation amended.

I recently met with representatives of the Association and gave them an undertaking that I would seek, at the earliest opportunity and within certain parameters, an amendment to the legislation which would make provision for the requesting of ``R-type'' X-rays by physiotherapists. The parameters which were accepted by the Association's representatives were that physiotherapists would be restricted to the requesting of the same ``R-type'' X-rays as chiropractors, viz. X-rays of the spine and pelvic area.
I hope to be able to introduce the requisite legislative amendments during this Session of Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I draw your attention to the continued premature departure of Ministers from this chamber. I understood that you indicated last week that you would take into account the fact that your rulings had been ignored. I note that today two Ministers left before Question Time had even finished, let alone the moment that it finished, as most of them have been prone to do.

—Order! Senator Alston, if you had been listening more carefully, you would have noticed that I also said that if a member of the Opposition had a question that had not been answered in 30 days that senator should tell me and I would inform the Minister to make sure that that Minister was here.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis, who unfortunately left the chamber before the end of Question Time, asked me a question without notice on 16 August 1991 on whether the ABC was going to continue coverage of church services. I indicated that I had some sympathy with the position put by Senator Lewis, and I am pleased to be able to give him the following response which has been given to me by the ABC.

ANSWER.PARA: The ABC has advised that there will continue to be a program of worship and devotion at 11 a.m. on Sunday mornings. While the program will continue to be of one hour's duration, the ABC has not yet determined the precise nature of the program. However, it is planned that some direct broadcasting of church services will continue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 June 1991, during the committee stage of the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, I gave an undertaking to Senator MacGibbon to re-examine at a later stage the level of penalty associated with a breach of subsection 32ab (2) of the Civil Aviation Act 1988. Advice received from the Attorney-General's Department indicates such re-examination not to be necessary. I have written to Senator MacGibbon explaining this and I seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for Shipping and
Aviation Support
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Australia
15 August 1991
Senator D J MacGibbon
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator MacGibbon

You will recall that on 21 June 1991, during debate on the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, I gave an undertaking to re-examine the level of penalty associated with the breach of subsection 32AB(2) of the Civil Aviation Act 1988.

Section 32AB deals with the issuing of identity cards for Civil Aviation Authority investigators. Specifically, subsection 32AB(2) provides that a person who ceases to be an investigator must return his or her card as soon as is practicable, and subsection 32AB(3) provides that if this is not done (without reasonable excuse) then that person is guilty of an offence punishable on conviction by a fine not exceeding $100.

During the Committee stage, you expressed the opinion that the $100 fine was not a sufficient deterrent to prevent ex-investigators, who had not returned their identity cards, from using their cards to pass themselves off as investigators. I gave an undertaking that together we would reexamine the level of the penalty at some later stage and, if necessary, work towards a future amendment to increase it to an appropriate level.

Advice has been obtained by my Department from the Attorney-General's Department that a person who fails to return his or her identity card and uses it to personate a Civil Aviation Authority investigator would breach section 75 of the Crimes Act 1914. Section 75 of the Crimes Act essentially provides that any person who personates any Commonwealth officer or falsely represents himself to be a Commonwealth officer is guilty of an offence and is subject to a penalty of 2 years imprisonment and or a fine of $1,000.

The Attorney-General's Department has also confirmed that subsection 32AB(3) of the Civil Aviation Act provides merely for the failure to return an identity card and advises that, given section 75 of the Crimes Act, there is no need to increase the penalty associated with this provision.
I trust that these comments satisfactorily address your concerns.
Yours sincerely
(Bob Collins)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-When I was absent from the chamber on Tuesday, 13 August, Senator Coulter made what could be described as a speech in which he referred to the subject of the Industry Commission inquiry into motor vehicles. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is about time that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, as the Minister responsible, began to properly discharge his duty in directing the Industry Commission to carry out its function properly under its Act and so far Senator Button has failed to do that.
He continued:

The IC has one commissioner appointed to its commissioners and it has totally inadequate staff . . . Again, I point to the Minister responsible, Senator Button, who is not properly discharging his responsibility as the Minister and not seeing that the IC is properly discharging its responsibility under its Act.

I wish to point out two things to Senator Coulter. The Industry Commission is established by its own statute; it is an independent authority. It is not susceptible to the direction of any Minister in terms of its inquiry. If it were subject to any directions in relation to matters of staffing and things like that, it would be subject to the direction of the Treasurer not to me as the Minister for Industry. That has been the case for four years.

I draw that to Senator Coulter's attention as a courtesy to him as the Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats. I extended the same sort of courtesy to his predecessor and I will extend it to his successor after the Democrats have dealt with this matter.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! During Question Time in the House of Representatives today the Speaker was asked a question about the industrial dispute and, therefore, I will make exactly the same statement. A lot of people do not quite realise how big the Murray-Darling basin is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell us?

—It would be a good idea to tell people because about two million people are dependent on the Murray-Darling basin's resources for their livelihoods. It just so happens that I live in the Murray-Darling basin, and it is a great area of Australia in which to live. Around 1.8 million people live in the basin. It is sustained by its agricultural, forestry, service and mining industries. About 0.4 million people live outside the basin, but are supported by the resources from within it.

SPEECH.PARA: Water is exported from this catchment to supply most of the developed area of South Australia. I am quite sure that those South Australians in the chamber at the moment would want to receive good water and we want to send good water down to them. We want to make sure that it is not taking a lot of our soil, which is definitely the lifeblood of our country for it grows our crops and produces our grasses which produce beef, wool and all the other things that come from agriculture.

There are about 1.6 million hectares of land irrigated in Australia in total and 1.2 million hectares are located within this basin. The land produces about 90 per cent of Australia's irrigated field crops-wheat, coarse grains, sorghum, oilseeds, rice and cotton-about 80 per cent of its pasture and lucerne, 70 per cent of its fruit, and 25 per cent of its vegetables. The basin actually supports about one-half of the total number of sheep in Australia, one-half of Australia's cropland, one-quarter of its dairy farms, and onequarter of its cattle. The annual value of primary and secondary production in the basin is about $10,000m which, together with associated value added components of the economy, accounts for something like 30 to 40 per cent of the total production from Australia's natural resource-based industries.

I believe that this report is well set out. But one of the things that concern me about bodies such as the Murray-Darling Basin Commission and other such bodies is the top heaviness of the operations and whether money is sometimes wasted there. I think that is something which needs to be looked at in the future. I believe that the Commission does a good job and the report highlights the importance of this area.

One of the things about the water supply in South Australia which must be of concern to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, is the algal blooms. Last year the algal blooms caused big problems for water storage and water quality. It is something that will have to be looked at in the future because of the quality of water that is needed for the people of South Australia.

As I have said, I commend this report to the Senate. I believe that all of us who live in the big Murray-Darling catchment or in other catchments have to be ever-mindful of the need to look after the resources in that area. That is where land care, total catchment management or whatever it happens to be has to be conducted on a sustainable basis with a view to the future. Whilst always trying to maximise our use of this resource in our own lifetimes, we must make sure that we do not leave it in a worse state for future generations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the annual report of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission for 1990. The report states that more than 2 million people or about one-eighth of the people of Australia are dependent on the Murray-Darling Basin for their livelihood. I commend the map on page 6 of this report to honourable senators for careful examination. The map shows that this basin extends over most of Victoria and New South Wales, the southern part of Queensland and much of the south-eastern corner of South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Its size is not the most important feature. It is the most fertile part of Australia. It consists of 75 per cent of the irrigated lands. It produces 90 per cent of Australia's irrigated field crops. It produces 80 per cent of Australia's pasture and lucerne. It produces 70 per cent of Australia's fruit, and 25 per cent of our vegetables. It is not only the salad bowl of Australia, but it provides at least half of every meal that we eat. It supports 50 per cent of Australia's sheep, 50 per cent of our crop land, 25 per cent of our dairy farms and 25 per cent of our cattle.

The annual value of primary and secondary production in the Murray-Darling Basin is about $10 billion, which accounts for 30 to 40 per cent of Australia's primary production. I urge honourable senators to take a careful look at the map on page 6 because this region, which is so crucial to Australia, may be dying. Deserts are advancing at an incredible rate into the farmlands of the world. Australia is already largely desert. It is the driest continent in the world and has fragile soils and major salinity problems. The Murray-Darling Basin is under imminent threat from the ever-encroaching desert. It has been predicted that the Murray-Darling Basin could become desert within 90 years if something is not done. The Murray-Darling desert will become a reality if we do not act immediately and change our land management practices.

What has caused these problems? The basin sits on an ancient seabed, which still contains large deposits of salt. Extensive land clearing and the irrigation of large sections of the basin have raised the watertable, and large areas of arable land have become saline. If this process is not stopped, large areas of the Murray-Darling Basin will become wastelands. The only way that the deserts will be held at bay is if there are massive changes in land use practices.

The Murray-Darling Basin Commission was created in 1988. This 1990 annual report is its second report and begins by identifying three areas of concern for the management of the basin. They are, first, inappropriate land management. There has been extensive clearing and extensive irrigation, and this has adversely affected the land and water in the basin. Secondly, water quality is poor and this is exacerbated by salinity and nutrients. Thirdly, there is growing degradation of the natural environment, including rivers. On page 8 of its report the Commission spells out these problems:

Pressing salinity and waterlogging problems are developing in the Basin. These are a major threat to irrigated land and streams, lakes and wetlands. Some 720,000 hectares of irrigated land have watertables that have risen to near the land surface and this is expected to increase to 1,300,000 hectares in the next 50 years.

I commend the report urgently to the Senate. A number of programs have been developed to check further problems and to reverse the degradation, but there is increasing urgency for more to be done-for the planting of trees and natural vegetation; for a switch to more dryland farming; for soil conservation; and for incentives for farmers and horticulturists to take urgent action on their own farms. Above all, there is an urgent need for the Government to commit money and resources into measures that will save billions of dollars in lost rural production in the long run and head off the greatest threat that faces the Australian environment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
