DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In speaking to the 1990-91 annual report of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, I would like to remind those in the chamber today that it was only yesterday in this Parliament that the Australian people received a document of doom and gloom, and I refer to the Budget. By the Government's own admission, its predictions for our economic growth have been tragically wrong. The Government's ability to manage our economy has shown to be non-existent. The Budget introduced yesterday was framed on an unemployment level of 10.8 per cent and a massive 1.3 million Australians who are now either unemployed or underemployed.

These are indeed very difficult times for the man and woman on the street. They are even more difficult times for those who are trying to raise a family or for those who are trying to find work. It is fitting therefore that, whilst the rest of the country struggles, I use some of the time available to me to speak to this report to highlight the blatant waste of taxpayers' funds which is being perpetrated by this Government whilst the overwhelming majority of Australians in these difficult times have been asked to tighten their belt or go without. That is certainly not evident in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. In particular, I refer to the use of consultants-a use which, in this Department alone, cost the Australian taxpayer almost $2m this last financial year.

So what have been the areas that have required the use of taxpayers' funds? I am sure that many taxpayers would be very interested to know that $500,000 has been spent on a study of the living and work standards across our country. Why half a million dollars should need to be spent on such an exercise is certainly beyond comprehension. There surely can be very few-except obviously those associated with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet-who are unaware of the very clear fact that living and work standards are decreasing rapidly. I suggest that, rather than wasting half a million dollars on a study which could have been completed by a very brief reading of the major suburban newspapers on any day of the week, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet would have been better off allocating $500,000 towards assisting those Australian families who are currently living in poverty.

The report makes it clear that poverty is not something with which our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is familiar. Whilst tonight thousands of Australians will be going to bed without a roof over their head, substituting instead any temporary shelter which they can find, the Prime Minister has seen fit to spend $97,000 on advice on architectural engineering and building matters in relation to the Lodge and Kirribilli House. I suggest that comes on top of quite a few million dollars spent renovating the places over the last few years.

The Prime Minister has spent the equivalent of what many people would spend on providing a roof over their head on simply getting advice on how he can renovate his. This is a disgraceful waste of taxpayers' money and, once again, it demonstrates the lack of real concern by this Government and the Prime Minister. I note on page 219 of the report that $152,000 has been spent on maintaining a multicultural Australia and immigration studies database. For the life of me, I cannot see why this work could not have been done by one of the many government bureaucracies dealing with such matters.

But it is not just big ticket items about which I believe the taxpayer has every right to be concerned about in this report. There are many smaller items too. For example, $10,000 has been spent on research and written material for a publication on multicultural aspects of the food and wine industry; and $5,500 has been spent simply to develop a multicultural poster. Spending $5,500 to develop a poster is a disgraceful priority in my book. An amount of $53,000 has been spent by the Office of the Status of Women to investigate the subject of women and ecologically sustainable development. Personally, I must admit that I have a great deal of difficulty in seeing how the two issues are in the slightest way related. Secondly, why should Australian taxpayers have to spend $53,000 of their money trying to find out why they are? Nor should Australian taxpayers have to pay $4,000 so that the Office of the Status of Women can employee a consultant to evaluate its own newsletter. If the officers from the Department could not have completed that exercise themselves, one wonders what they were there for in the first place.

Once again, I stress that this report shows how the Government clearly has its priorities wrong. It is time that the Government became more concerned with the real issues facing the Australian community, rather than the many fanciful whims which are referred to in this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to say a few words about the annual report of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and to endorse very strongly the words of my friend and colleague Senator Calvert. Many of the points that he made are very important and I will just supplement his remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The use of consultants coincides with significant increases in the actual staff of the Department. For example, in 1990-91, the year to which the annual report relates, there was an 11 per cent increase in the staff of the Department, excluding the growth in the number of consultants. From the Budget Papers yesterday we learned that there will be another 4 1/2 per cent increase in the staff that will be employed by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in 1991-92.

Those staff figures for the year reflect also, at least to some extent, the increase in the actual cost of running the Department. In 1990-91 the cost of running the Prime Minister's Department was $63.8m, an increase of 30.6 per cent on the preceding year. That is an extraordinary increase in the cost of departmental administration in one year. The 1991-92 Budget Papers which were released yesterday show that at a time when we are in the midst of the deepest, most protracted recession in the last 60 years in Australia-due to the mismanagement of this Government and its economic policies -when more than one million people are unemployed, there will be another 13.3 per cent increase in the cost of the administration of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, taking the figure to no less than $72.3m.

It is interesting, in the context of the financial integrity of the Department, to note that the Auditor-General has given a qualification in his audit of the Department. His note appears on page 279 of the report and says that certain fixed assets at Admiralty House, Sydney, have been excluded from the Statement of Supplementary Information provided by the Department. The Auditor-General's note goes on:

The financial statement guidelines made by the Minister for Finance require that the value of certain fixed assets be included in the Statement of Supplementary Information including the assets of the type excluded by the department. The value of the excluded assets could not be determined.
That certainly requires an explanation by the Department.

Finally, I just make the point that this report-and I welcome the promptness of its availability to the Parliament-is nothing more than a taxpayer funded indulgence of yet another super ego trip by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). There are no fewer than 15 action shots of the Prime Minister in this document. The summary of the Department's highlights for the year at the start of the report is almost exclusively that the Prime Minister did this or the Prime Minister did that-virtually nothing about the highlights of the Department itself.

Indeed, even in looking at the situation with regard to the Prime Minister, there seem to me to be two very important highlights in the year relating to the Prime Minister that are excluded from this report-inadvertent, I guess-and I hope that next year there will not be similar exclusions. For example, there is no mention under the monthly highlights for June 1991 that the Prime Minister survived a leadership challenge, nor is there any mention that at the end of year the Prime Minister presided over the worst collapse in the Australian economy in 60 years. I hope that deficiency is rectified next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak on the annual report of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and particularly on the 12 pages covering the Office of the Status of Women. I was interested in the comments of my colleague Senator Calvert about the Office of the Status of Women. He referred particularly to the consultant's report on the newsletter. I would have thought there was no need for a consultant's report at all, because the purpose of the newsletter appears to be entirely one of pushing the Government as being deeply caring about women. All it is doing is pushing the Government for vote winning purposes. I do not think it is failing in that exercise, although I question whether that should be the purpose of the newsletter.

SPEECH.PARA: The report mentions the national working party on portrayal of women in the media. What it fails to say is that the Government has not picked up the problems being faced by women in the area of 0055 telephone numbers. It seems to be more concerned about the portrayal of women as bimbos selling soap powder than the portrayal of women in pornography. The National Committee on Violence Against Women is also referred to in the report. Once again, the head of the Office of the Status of Women is a member of that Committee, as she is of the working party on the portrayal of women in the media. I would have thought that issues of major concern to mainstream women such as pornography would have been dealt with by one or the other of those committees, but they have not been.

I am also concerned that the same Office of the Status of Women appears to have been responsible for the Women's Budget Statement which has just appeared in the Parliament. It is 414 pages long, and nothing but a propaganda exercise. It is full of puffery and fudging. It draws in programs from all the departments, many of them with no special relevance to women. Occasional programs for women are tucked in here and there within a mass of paper. I compare that with the same document produced for the Budget last year, which managed to get by with 240 pages. That in itself was too large. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) managed to put out a Budget document yesterday on health reform implications. They were all contained within 12 pages, and I wonder why the women's budget, if there needs to be one at all, cannot be contained within such a space because all we need in a Budget document are the initiatives for the coming year.

The Government should take the scissors to this so-called women's budget, bring it down to size and save the trees, which are needed. Then we might see something about women and sustainable development. What the Government did not put in the Women's Budget Statement is the fact that the Government has slashed the budget of the Women's Bureau in the Department of Employment, Education and Training, which over the years has done some first rate work in research on women and employment. I point out that it was implemented by a Liberal government back in the late 1960s. Needless to say, it has been of good practical purpose.

From the puffery in the Women's Budget Statement we would have no idea that approximately six people have been left to do lines and lines of work, although the key words are `they will focus on'. Clearly, that is all they will be able to do. I would say that they will only be able to read the newspapers; they will have no time to do anything meaningful with the number of people left to do the job.

It is proper that we in the Parliament should get a report on the expenditure of the previous year, but the proper place is in the annual report. In the case of the Office of the Status of Women that responsibility is properly within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The other initiatives that may be of some special interest to women should properly be covered in the annual reports of the departments-not put into this 400-page blockbuster about how marvellous the Government is. Many of the programs covered in there have no special relevance or importance to women. They are put in that document to increase its size. The Budget document should be restricted to the initiatives for the coming year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald indicated this morning in debate on the Bill that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, after examining the Bill, had queried the application of the definition of `prescribed period' as contained in clause 40. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the amendment proposed by the Government to clause 40(3) (a) would satisfy the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. However, I believe-and I have spoken with others about this-that the amendment still does not make the legislation as good as the piece of legislation that it is trying to amend and improve. Clause 40(3) (a), as amended, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . or, if there is more than one such order, the date of the first such order.

As I pointed out to the Minister's staff over the lunch break, that is referring to the order under which the person is held in custody. The person is held in custody under the order then current, so there is not a first, second or third order. It is the period under which the person is then being held in custody. If he has been there seven days and is remanded for another seven days, it is that second seven days order under which he is being held; not the first one. So the amendment which says, `or, if there is more than one such order, the date of the first such order' is irrelevant, in my submission, because there can be only one such order under which he is currently being held. Maybe the Minister's speech as to the interpretation provisions will be sufficient to clarify that, but the clause just does not seem to me to be getting to where the Government wants it to be. It is not tidy, in my view. I simply make the suggestion to the Government, in case it may be interested in trying to improve the wording of the clause.

There is reference in this Bill to the order in clause 39 under which a person is held in custody. If one refers to clause 39, one finds that the only order that is mentioned is that where a magistrate, not being satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for holding a person, may order that the person be released. That is the only reference to `order'. I would have thought it would have been better to refer to the remand, which is in fact what is intended in clause 39(c). It is the remand which the amendment intends to deal with. This clause leaves the way open for confusion and legal argument at some later date.

It appears that it is the intention of the legislation to allow two months from a certain action so that, as the Minister has just said, no-one can be incarcerated for more than two months without having the opportunity to apply to the Supreme Court. If we read the current description of `prescribed period', we find:
Where a person remanded in custody under section 39 is still held in that custody at the end of the prescribed period, the person may apply to the Supreme Court . . .
`Prescribed period' is then defined in relation to a certain matter. In relation to habeas corpus, the Bill states:
``prescribed period'', in relation to a person, means 2 months after:
if the person has applied for a writ of habeas corpus-the day on which that application, or any appeal relating to it, is finally determined;
whichever is the later.

The scenario could be that a person is taken into custody today; in 10 days time he applies for habeas corpus; he gets a decision the next day, on day 11 or 12, that he has missed out on that application; he appeals and the appeal is not heard for three months. Then his right to apply under clause 40 is not a period of two months, but 15 days, plus the three months for the appeal period which is when the matter is finally determined. Then it goes for another two months. So if one dares to apply for habeas corpus and then dares to appeal and misses out, instead of being in custody for only two months, one could be in custody for a considerable period. I am confident that that is not what is intended. I would have thought that the provision would say at the end, `whichever is earlier' rather than, `whichever is later'. I raise that point in case the Minister wants to look at it.

Finally, as I understand it, the purpose of newly re-drafted clauses 39 and 40 is to incorporate provisions similar to those that were in the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act, the Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act and the Civil Aviation (Offenders on International Aircraft) Act. The old legislation- the three Acts are all practically identical-took 13 lines to state very clearly what that provision was all about. The new, amended, improved, clearer-to-understand version takes 18 lines to say the same thing. It says it in a very convoluted way and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee had great concern about it. I would like to point the draftsman to a comparison of the old provisions with the new ones.

The matters that I have been talking about-which, I admit, are very technical, legal and some might even say pedantic-are much more clearly stated in the old legislation. With regard to the point I made about whether it should be `order' or `remand', if one goes to the old Act it states quite simply:
Where a person remanded under subsection 2 of section 13-
that would, in effect, be clause 39 (1) (c)-
is in custody at the expiration of two months after the date of the order of remand by virtue of which his period on remand commenced . . .

That wording overcomes all of the problems that I have raised and that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has, and I suggest that that is the wording which should be used. The rest of the section goes on more or less to say what is said in the new, revised, short and supposedly clearer version but in fewer words.

The concern I raise about habeas corpus and the fact that it may be up to four or five months before there can be an application for release under subsection 40(1), is the same in the old legislation as it is in the new. Again, I suggest that the Minister look at the old legislation but even if he were inclined to adopt the old clause-which, as I say, is much clearer-it should be whichever is the earlier event rather than whichever is the later event. That is all very technical and some might say pedantic but I raise these points for two reasons: first, in the hope that it may make things clearer and, secondly, to raise the matter that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee was concerned about-which the Government accepts and has tried to correct by the amendment, but which I do not think it has corrected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald has certainly indicated some dissatisfaction with the drafting of these particular amendments. I do not believe he has raised anything substantive to indicate that the attempted consolidation in any way changes the law which is presently operating in a way that has proved to be satisfactory in relation to the sorts of liberties with which I know he is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: As to his first point about the amendment to clause 40(3) (a) that I have just moved on behalf of the Government-which I have done in response to Senator Macdonald raising the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee report on the matter-I agree with his analysis of the currency or potency of the current order. But it is a fact that a succession of orders is envisaged and the expression `first order' makes sense, speaking chronologically, even though it might be exhausted at the end of its first seven days.

TALK.START.PARA: —First order under which he is remanded. He is not remanded under the first order. He is remanded under the order then current. So there is no first or second; there is only one.

—But in reviewing the history of the matter, one would be able to point to an order that related to the first seven-day period, and I think that is what that is referring to. Senator Macdonald also raised the question of whether the term `remand' rather than `order' might have been better, given the link to 39(1) where the term `order' is used in relation to release from custody. In clause 40, `order' is linked to the idea of custody and, therefore, that is quite a clear provision. For example, 40 (3) (a) says:

SPEECH.PARA: the date of the order under section 39 under which the person is held in custody.

When one reads the totality of that particular paragraph, it makes very good sense. As to the question of habeas corpus, I dealt with that in my original remarks. This is virtually a transcription of the present section which has not given cause for alarm. Whilst taking Senator Macdonald's point that a different draftsman could have tackled this matter somewhat differently, I believe that the chamber can accept these clauses.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we finish the committee stage, I meant to table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the additional Government amendment moved to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

Debate resumed from 14 August, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition is not opposing the Crimes Amendment Bill 1991, which amends the Crimes Act 1914 in order to give the Australian Federal Police an express power to search aircraft, vehicles and vessels without a warrant in emergencies. Such a power already exists in relation to some Commonwealth legislation, which confers emergency search powers upon various officials including the police. However, there is no such specific power in relation to the vast majority of Commonwealth offences. It has hitherto been considered that the Federal police could rely on the emergency search powers conferred in State and Territory legislation, and applied by section 9 of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979.

SPEECH.PARA: A decision in the Adelaide Central District Criminal Court in April last year threw this into doubt. The case, R v. Barritt, is an unreported decision of Mr Justice Greaves. It indicates that State law cannot be applied in that way because section 10 of the Crimes Act covers the field. However, section 10 provides only for searches authorised by warrant. The question at issue in the case of Barritt was whether the search of a car by the AFP was lawful. His Honour said that section 10(1) of the Crimes Act:

. . . must be strictly construed in so far as the power of search provided therein by the Commonwealth Parliament is expressly subjected to certain conditions precedent, those conditions with the protection they afford to the individual must be strictly enforced . . . I see my way clear to reject the proposition that those conditions can be circumvented in a particular State by the operation of section 9(1) (c) of the Australian Federal Police Act just because the local legislature has decided to grant greater powers of search to its local police force for the enforcement of the law of that State. Such a local dispensation with the protection afforded by the conditions of section 10(1) of its Crimes Act would require clear expression or implication by the Commonwealth Parliament and this has not occurred.

He was of the view that the police officer in this case had no power to search the car without a warrant. The argument thus is that State law cannot be applied, as has been assumed in the past, because section 10 of the Crimes Act covers the field. The requirements of section 10 cannot be excluded by a combination of section 9 of the Australian Federal Police Act and section 69 of the Summary Offences Act. Therefore, the Federal police have no power to search without a warrant in relation to the majority of Commonwealth offences.

Under this Bill, the AFP will have a limited power to make emergency searches of conveyances defined to include aircraft, vehicles and vessels. The new section 10a provides that the power to search without a warrant in emergencies applies when the police reasonably suspect that a thing relevant to an indictable offence is in or on a conveyance, and it is necessary to stop and search the conveyance in order to prevent the thing from being concealed, lost or destroyed.

Paragraph 10a (1) (c) explicitly provides that the power must only be exercised where the circumstances are sufficiently serious and urgent to justify a search without a warrant. Subsection 10a (2) provides for the power to stop, detain and search the conveyance, and to seize the thing relevant to a indictable offence if it is found during the search. Other things relevant to an indictable offence or a summary offence found during the search may also be seized, if the police reasonably suspect that it is necessary in order to prevent their concealment, loss or destruction.

New section 10b specifies limitations on the exercise of a power under section 10a. The conveyance must be searched in a public place, and must not be detained for any longer than is reasonable and necessary to search it. The police may use such force as is necessary, but must not damage the conveyance or any receptacle in or on it by forcing open a part of the conveyance or receptacle, unless the person in charge of the conveyance or receptacle has been given a reasonable opportunity to open that part themselves.

Proposed new section 10c expressly provides that the power to conduct emergency searches without warrant set out in sections 10a and 10b is not intended to limit or exclude the operation of a Territory law relating to the searching of conveyances in connection with offences against the law of a Territory. A thing seized under this Bill may be kept by the police for 60 days, unless it is required in evidence or the police are authorised by law to retain the thing or destroy or dispose of it. The police may also apply to a court of summary jurisdiction for permission to keep the thing for a further period.

We are not opposing the Bill because we believe that it is reasonable; the safeguards in it are adequate; the powers given by it are explicit; and it can therefore be useful in playing a vital role in the detection of crimes particularly relating to the trafficking of drugs while not on the other hand being unduly intrusive into the normal rights and privacies of individuals. We are therefore prepared to support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Crimes Amendment Bill 1991. The Bill seeks to amend the Crimes Act to empower police to search aircraft, vehicles and vessels in emergency situations without a warrant. Commonwealth legislation currently confers such emergency search powers on a wide range of officials including police. However, no such powers are conferred on police in relation to the vast majority of Commonwealth offences.

SPEECH.PARA: The emergency search power which is provided in this Bill is limited. It will only apply in a public place or in some other place to which members of the public have ready access. The amendments will enable a constable to stop, detain and search a conveyance and to seize any item found in the search which it can be reasonably suspected has been used in the commission of an offence.

The Australian Democrats do not oppose the Bill. However, even at this stage there is a question I should like to direct to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate). I refer to the provision whereby police may retain an item for up to 60 days without a court order or authorisation; in other words, they require a court order or authorisation under some other law to release an item or to keep it beyond the 60-day limit. If the person concerned wishes to make application to have the item released in less than 60 days, is that possible either under this legislation or under other provisions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank those honourable senators from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats who have indicated their support for what I believe is a very important amendment to the Crimes Act. It provides police officers with powers to search aircraft, vehicles or vessels in emergency situations. There has been sufficient discussion on why this was required. However, there is always concern in the community. I know that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, as chairman of the caucus legal committee, have always been extremely vigilant about the question of vesting emergency search powers in police or indeed in any other Commonwealth officers. It is because of your concern that I restricted some of the requests for search powers that have been made.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in this case we are asked to agree to giving the Australian Federal Police powers, which they have always been able to exercise, to search aircraft, vehicles or vessels in emergency situations where it is impossible to get a warrant, at least in a timely way, to ensure that possible evidence was not destroyed and, therefore, a prosecution of criminal offenders could not be mounted with success.

It is worth noting that the search power will only apply to a vehicle, vessel or an aircraft in a public area or places to which members of the public have access. The police officer must have reasonable grounds for his or her suspicion that an item relevant to an indictable offence is in or on the conveyance and that it is necessary to carry out the search in order to prevent what might be evidence from being concealed, lost or destroyed. Also, there has to be an urgency about the matter such as would not give the police officer time to obtain the authority of a search warrant.

This is particularly important in relation to the work of the Australian Federal Police in combating major criminal activity right across Australia. One may particularly think of the investigation of drug offences. Quite clearly, in order to distribute and market those drugs which are forbidden to be circulated in our community under pain of law, it is important to ensure that if a movement of drugs is taking place, for example, by car along a street in Sydney and the police do not have time to get a search warrant, they be able to carry out a search of that vehicle.

But this amendment will prove to be extremely useful not only in relation to drug trafficking. One can think of other various indictable offences where this could be very useful. For example, the Federal Police have a particular responsibility through their international obligation to ensure the physical safety of internationally protected persons, as one can imagine especially here in Canberra, the national capital, where we have so many diplomatic missions. There are also international obligations relating to hijacking and in relation to the protection of Commonwealth premises. It may be quite plausible that there could be circumstances where there would be a need to stop and search a vehicle for firearms or explosives in order to protect the community against some politically motivated violence in relation to those matters which I have described.

It is also clear that one could have a situation in relation to corporate or computer crime where documents could be moved from one place to another in a vehicle. Once again, it would be essential to carry out a search of the vehicle to ensure that those documents, which might provide evidence of a major corporate crime, were not destroyed or in some way concealed and therefore not available as evidence. So in these ways I believe that there is full justification for the Crimes Amendment Bill.

During the second reading debate, Senator Spindler referred to a case where a person may want to make application to have seized material released in less than 60 days. He asked whether a procedure is available under another law to enable this. I am advised that there is no specified procedure, but there is nothing to stop the police from releasing it in less than 60 days where it is no longer necessary to be held for evidence. If there is any further questioning on that, no doubt I can try to answer it as long as I get a legibly written note.

I believe that this is a very important Bill. It will help the Australian Federal Police fulfil the obligations which it has to the Australian community and provides for a single regime relating to emergency search of vehicles, aircraft and vessels right across all of the State and Territory jurisdictions of Australia. I think that that is a considerable advance and it is well worth doing, quite apart from achieving the substantive change which I have commended to the chamber. I wish the Bill a successful second reading and a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not have an amendment to the Crimes Amendment Bill 1991. However, I am not entirely satisfied with the response of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) to the question I raised in the second reading debate. The Minister's response was that members of the police may release the material if they wish, but it does not enable, on the basis of that comment, the person concerned to actually make an application and to have it judged by an impartial arbiter, be it a magistrate or a judge.

SPEECH.PARA: I respectfully request that the Minister address his mind to that. If there is a procedure, he should make it known; if there is not, he should commit the Government to introduce an amendment to bring one about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Spindler; I understand his concern. I will undertake to discuss with the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police whether in fact some instruction might be made in relation to the exercise of the powers under this particular provision which would indicate those circumstances where it would be proper and, indeed, desirable that material that has been seized be returned in less than the 60-day period.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

Debate resumed from 14 August, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill 1991. This Bill presents an opportunity to remind those honourable senators in this chamber who might need reminding-I think that is very few-and those who might be either listening now or reading Hansard later of the good work that this chamber does, as opposed to that in the House of Representatives, and how long it can take for a single good idea to come to fruition.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter was referred to the relevant Senate committee, as I understand it, in November 1985. That was the first occasion on which the Senate resolved that the operation and administration of the freedom of information legislation should be looked at and that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was the relevant Committee to undertake that task.

I have not spoken to the members of the Senate who were members of the Committee at that time, but I am sure that between November 1985 and the election in June 1987 they did a considerable amount of work. Of course, the dissolution of Parliament in 1987 meant that the Committee and the reference basically disappeared. Not long after the Parliament resumed in September 1987 the Senate appointed the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee and again referred to it the review of the operation of the Act. It did not take long from that date in 1987, only till December 1987, for a report recommending a very large number of changes-nearly 200, I think-to be made both in the sense of legislative amendments and in the sense of administrative changes.

In 1985 someone had the idea that this Act should be looked at. But we had to wait until December 1987, with some intervening elections, before a number of the contributions of honourable senators for the improvement of freedom of information could be taken into account.

It is probably worth mentioning that those honourable senators include the now Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, who is in the chamber; Senator Bolkus; Senator Robert Hill, from my State; Senator Richard Alston; Senator Cooney, who of course is now Chairman of the Committee; Senator Alan Missen, who, sadly, died a number of years ago; Senator Puplick; and Senator Margaret Reynolds. Prior to that the members of the Committee included Senator Stone, Senator Schacht, Senator Powell and Senator Giles-the others have already been mentioned. There was some overlapping between the two committees.

The Committee produced a very substantive report with, I think, 34 or 35 pages of recommendations. That is not to say that length alone is any indicator of value, but it is an indicator of the time and effort taken. Some 126 recommendations were made; that is where we got to between 1985 and 1987.

As I understand it, very early in June 1989-about 18 months later-the Government finally responded to the Committee's report and indicated that it approved of a very substantial number of the recommendations, but not all of them. The Government did not accept five or six of the recommendations out of the 100 or so but we really could not expect to win them all. The Committee, no doubt, was happy to achieve what it achieved. That was in June 1989, as I said, some 18 months after the report was tabled in this place.

At the time, the Minister-I am sorry, I cannot remember who it was-indicated that there was an expectation that legislation would be available in that year; that the Government would not only respond in 1989 but in the Budget session of 1989 something would be done about it. If there is an element of regret in improving the Freedom of Information Act it is that it has taken so long. The Government, as I said, tabled its report in June 1989 and indicated at the time that it thought something could be done-at least in that year. But it has taken up until now-1991-to get something done.

I do not know who it was who first moved the motion that the operation of the Act be looked at-they are probably long gone and possibly even deceased because they did that in 1985. I mention that not because I think we all need a history lesson but because it is pleasant every now and then to realise that although what one is doing may not be appreciated-one may feel as though one is getting nowhere-in the end there is a distinct possibility that something will be done with the work that each of us is putting into the Senate committee system.

If one wanted to go through the explanatory memorandum and highlight each occasion where the explanation on a particular clause is that it implements a Senate committee recommendation, I do not think, apart from the first page in the outline, that there is a page that does not have at least two or three highlights indicating that just about everything this Bill does is either a direct implementation of a Senate committee recommendation or a consequential amendment flowing from it. As I understand it, we will have the second reading of this Bill today and handle the committee stage at another time. Therefore, it is probably appropriate to say that any remarks with respect to particular clauses will be left until that later date.

In conclusion, I wish to refer to a couple of things this Bill does. It primarily seeks to streamline and simplify the freedom of information procedures-and none of us could argue sensibly that that would be a bad thing-for making a request for access to documents; to provide that a person's right of access is not affected by his or her reasons for seeking access; to allow companies as well as private individuals to have access under the Act to documents that were in existence five years prior to the commencement of the Act; to provide that agency employees be required to use internal agency procedures; and to seek access to personal records before seeking access under the Act. We might query widening the scope of refusal of requests for access to documents where the processing of requests would involve a substantial or unreasonable diversion of agency resources.

For those who have an interest in freedom of information matters, one can understand a natural tendency to say, `Hold on. That is just going to be used by the bureaucracy as a means of not providing the information sought, to make a claim that it will unreasonably divert the agency's resources'. That is a natural inclination. But we can say in response that there are remedies for doubting an agency's claim, if there is that doubt. We can additionally say that, just because we support the principle of freedom of information, it does not follow that we support any person seeking whatever range of information he or she might be interested in at the expense of everyone else. There has to be some sensible limitation on what is sought.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except at Estimates.

—I am sorry, but I did not catch the Minister's interjection. He might discuss it with me at another time. I raise that point to indicate that I do understand some people having concern about widening the scope for refusal of access to documents.

SPEECH.PARA: The interpretation provisions in the Act which exempt documents from public disclosure have been clarified. In relation to personal information there is now an opportunity to make an amendment or annotation to one's file in specified circumstances. There is a provision that relates to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The AAT has powers to review a decision by an agency or Minister and makes its own fresh decisions about access. Provisions allowing review by the AAT of decisions made by government agencies on requests for access to documents are clarified, and new guidelines have been inserted to better define the circumstances in which such a review will be available. They are the main matters that I care to mention today.

Last, but not least, I remind the Senate of the whole point that I have tried to make in speaking to this Bill-that is, that someone in 1985 thought something should be done and here we are in 1991 finally seeing the results of all the work that has been put in, and the delays that have taken place, in the meantime. The person concerned probably does not realise the contribution he or she made in setting this work in train. All those who contributed to this task are to be congratulated. It is not often enough that after legislation is passed a proper review of its operation is undertaken, and it is not often enough that, as a consequence of that review, some legislative and administrative change is implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Freedom of Information Amendment Bill 1991 contains some 100 changes to the freedom of information legislation. As Senator Vanstone has said, most of these are the result of recommendations by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Being a member of that Committee, I have a great deal of confidence in its work. It is tempting to say, `Well, if it has been recommended by the Committee, there probably is not a lot wrong with it'.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I believe that freedom of information is an extremely important area in the fabric of our society. It was a great advance on the basis of civil liberties as well as people's participation in the government process, and I believe that it should not be treated cavalierly. The somewhat unseemly haste with which this Bill was dumped on the Senate, together with a batch of other legal Bills, leads me to the request, which I have made to the Government, that we confine ourselves today to the second reading debate and do not proceed to the committee stage. We wish to subject a number of questions to some further scrutiny and take some advice before we proceed to the next stage. There may well be amendments arising out of some of our concerns.

I will mention one or two of our concerns. In clause 10, for instance, we find the provision that, before an agency employee may make a freedom of information request, he or she is required to use internal agency procedures to obtain the required information. It is quite possible that such a person would find himself or herself in a situation within that agency where even the very request for certain information might cause difficulties. As I said before, I would like to investigate this matter a little further to see what, if any, amendments should be made.

Clause 14 implements once again a recommendation of the Senate Committee that an agency should not refuse access to a document on the ground that the document is misleading, but that an agency should be able to delete material from documents on the ground that the material is irrelevant. I find that somewhat extraordinary. Who decides what is irrelevant and to what extent the applicant can get redress when someone else decides that certain material can simply be excluded because the recipient of the request considers it irrelevant?

Finally, I briefly advert to clause 15, a matter to which Senator Vanstone also adverted. It concerns the permission that is given an agency to refuse a request on the basis that it would involve a substantial and unreasonable diversion of the agency's resources. I consider that an extremely dangerous clause, because once again we have a decision by the agency rather than the person requiring information, who is without any obvious recourse. A request could be refused entirely within the purview of the agency from whom information is sought. There are a number of other areas of concern. However, I will not detain the Senate at this stage, but will leave them for discussion at the committee stage of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment to the Freedom of Information Act 1982 is one of a number of measures that this Parliament has brought in over the last couple of decades to enable citizens to have more knowledge of what goes on in government. Such legislation has been brought in by governments of both political persuasions. The Act itself was brought in under Mr Fraser and I think it is worth while reading out its objectives, as they are very noble objectives indeed. The Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: The object of this Act is to extend as far as possible the right of the Australian community to access to information in the possession of the Government of the Commonwealth by-

(a) making available to the public information about the operations of departments and public authorities and, in particular, ensuring that rules and practices affecting members of the public in their dealings with departments and public authorities are readily available to persons affected by those rules and practices;

In other words, it is a means whereby a person who is governed by the Federal Parliament can get a look at the mechanisms by which he or she is governed and, if necessary, do something about it. The Act continues:

(b) creating a general right of access to information in documentary form in the possession of Ministers, departments and public authorities, limited only by exceptions and exemptions necessary for the protection of essential public interests and the private and business affairs of persons in respect of whom information is collected and held by departments and public authorities.

So the objective is to make government more open and more transparent and, therefore, make it better, thus enabling the citizen to have a greater say over the processes that affect his or her life. Therefore, it is a great piece of legislation.

I think it has to be looked at together with other legislation, such as that which brought in the Ombudsman, set up the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and which gave the Federal Court the power to see whether the processes that government is meant to undertake-that is, government through the Minister or through public servants-are properly undertaken. So it is a great piece of legislation amongst plenty of other legislation.

The Freedom of Information Amendment Bill 1991 arises out of a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. This inquiry began under Senator Tate-now the very eminent Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, who I see is in the chamber and who will speak after me. He was raised to the Ministry in the course of that inquiry which, ultimately, ended in a report. Senator Bolkus, now the Minister for Administrative Services, took over as Chairman of the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not nearly so distinguished!

—He is very distinguished. Senator Vanstone was a member of the Committee in those days. Unfortunately, we did not have Senator Michael Baume on the Committee, but he is always welcome. That Committee made 126 recommendations. The Government has taken up many of those in this legislation and the Minister will speak about that.

SPEECH.PARA: In this area, there is always a need to examine and re-examine legislation such as this when it is put forward. Legislation such as this operates beneficially to the community, but some problems always arise and no doubt matters will arise out of the present amendments which the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee will want to look at later. I mention some issues which may give rise to some problems later. In my next few remarks, I owe much to Peter Bayne from the Australian National University. The Minister, who will be speaking after me, will also acknowledge the great work that Peter Bayne has done in this area.

Some things are or may become matters of concern. A new definition has been brought in by this legislation as to what is constituted by personal information. A decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in 1988 in the case of the Department of Social Security v. Dyrenfurth stated that personal information did not include information about how a selection within the Australian Public Service was made for the purposes of promotion. In other words, this decision said that the Act, in referring to personal information, did not mean information dealing with the way promotions were made or the way that a particular Minister or a person in the Public Service went about promoting somebody else.

With the new definition that has been brought in, the guidelines have been expanded and it may well be that the effect of Dyrenfurth's case has been overcome so that what will now happen is that a public servant will be able to go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to have the process by which he or she was selected or not selected looked at. Indeed, under part V of the Act, a person may be able to have the documents corrected.

On the face of it, that may seem to be a good thing. But, in my view, it would be of some concern if the AAT were used to settle or to continue what was, in effect, an industrial dispute. Just as I am concerned that sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act are used out of context to deal with industrial relations, I would be concerned if the new definition that has been given to the phrase `personal information' were to so affect the operation of part V as to enable it to be used to have what was, in effect, an industrial dispute decided by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Even though it may be to the benefit of the employee, I think, to be consistent, all matters dealing with employment should be dealt with in the proper context of an industrial relations commission or an industrial relations court.

It may well be that that will not happen, but the definition now given to the phrase is certainly capable of leading to that result. Personal information previously talked about matters that were much more confined than that. The new definition of personal information may also make the matters that can be exempt under the Act wider than they were previously.

There is one further matter that I wish to raise. The Federal Court in Corrs Parvey Whiting and Byrne v. the Collector of Customs spoke about section 45 (1) of the Act and gave a meaning to the term `breach of confidence', which meant that the exemption was much wider under that Act than was intended. I think that has been cured under the new legislation, but in a way that may make the matter a little more uncertain to people reading it. It may make them resort to lawyers to find out what it means. I think it is a good thing that people resort to lawyers, but it would also be a good thing if the legislation were made a bit clearer. Generally this is a great reform. I congratulate the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, on originally chairing the Committee that initiated these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank those honourable senators-Senator Vanstone for the Opposition, Senator Spindler for the Australian Democrats and Senator Barney Cooney from my own Party-who have indicated their support for the Freedom of Information Bill. I also commend them for their very real interest in the work of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and for taking a particular interest in ensuring that there is widespread support in this chamber for the objectives of the FOI Act in general and for the amendments which are before the chamber this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in carrying out its review of the operation of the Act undertook a monumental task. I recall many of the hearings and, although the report was made after I was elevated to the Ministry, I remember seeing the final conclusions and recommendations of that report as a major vindication of the original decision to implement this sort of legislation against a tremendous body of inertia, and even hostility, in the Commonwealth bureaucracy, not least led by-and I am sure he would not mind my saying this-the former Secretary to the Treasury and former senator, John Stone, who was most vehement in his protests at the impact which this legislation would have on the conduct of government business.

The majority of the provisions in this Bill are aimed at trying to simplify the process by which requests are dealt with by government agencies. The procedures are streamlined and the steps which agencies must follow in imposing charges for access are being simplified. I believe that, in so far as there is a necessity to ensure that business, State and Territory governments and private individuals do not have matters disclosed that might offend their interests as described in the Bill, the process for consultation with them needed clarification and simplification. That also is being undertaken. In regard to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, provisions dealing with that matter are also being clarified.

There are questions to do with resources and the need for a provision that ensures that a particular agency is not over-burdened by having unreasonably to divert resources to answer an FOI request. If substantial and unreasonable diversion of resources is required, the Bill certainly acknowledges that can create a problem. In terms of this amendment it requires that very proper and extensive consultation take place with the applicant to help narrow the requests to manageable proportions. I think that is the quid pro quo for this sort of legislation, and a quite proper one.

There are also provisions dealing with the question of the sort of information that might be subject to a prohibition on public disclosure. Obviously this Parliament, as we have seen in relation to committees of the Parliament, has a particular role when it determines that there should be a privacy provision in a Bill. It is concerned to see that it be properly related to this other legislation, namely, the freedom of information legislation. There is no doubt that this is a matter of great concern to the chamber. In many respects-whether as members of committees or as senators with an interest in freedom of information matters, or as senators voting for legislation which contains secrecy provisions-we need to try to get a coordinated and principled approach to the way in which all these matters can be interrelated. I believe that this set of amendments attempts in the schedule of the Bill to deal with those matters according to a set of reasonable criteria.

I believe that on the whole the Senate Committee recommendations which have been accepted by the Government are important improvements in this regime. I recognise the work of others outside this chamber in the committee process, such as Mr Peter Bayne, who has already been acknowledged by Senator Cooney and who has made a valuable contribution to reflection on the FOI Act. This is an important piece of amending legislation and I commend the second reading to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of this Bill in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 December 1989, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —If my notes are correct, the Senate (Quorum) Bill 1989 [1990] was last called on on 7 December 1989. It is known in some quarters as the `desperation Bill'. When the Government runs out of business it rustles around and finds the quorum Bill. I remember that on one occasion last year it practically got on. But now that the Government has properly run out of business, the chances are that it will now be debated to its finality.
—What other business have you got-none!
—Wrong!
—Order! Senator Hill is doing quite nicely without assistance from both sides.

—It is an unruly government discomforted by its lack of business. From the Opposition's point of view, there is to be a free vote on the Bill. The Senate (Quorum) Bill arises from the report of the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures which was presented to the Senate on 1 December 1988. It was this Bill, in fact, that led to the introduction of changes to Senate procedures to facilitate the reference of Bills to committees. I am pleased to say that proceeded much further than the debate on whether the Senate should change its quorum. I might say in passing that I think it is working well. In fact, it has now reached the stage where its operation is going to be the subject of an evaluation by the Procedure Committee. So there we have an ongoing process that came out of that 1988 report. But the Committee made recommendations on the quorum for the Senate and that has been the subject of debate from time to time since 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: Under section 22 of the Constitution, the presence of at least one-third of the whole number of senators is necessary to constitute a quorum until the Parliament otherwise provides. The report of the Senate Select Committee on Legislation Procedures recommended that the quorum of the Senate be changed from one-third of the senators to one-quarter-that is, the current requirement of 26 senators should be reduced to 19. The purpose of this Bill is to implement that recommendation.

This would have the evident advantage for the Government that some or all of the Ministers in the Senate would be excused from the responsibility of assisting to form the quorum. I am reminded that Senator Ray in his second reading speech pointed out that Ministers have substantial demands on their time and that they should be able to carry out their activities without frequent and unnecessary disruptions. That makes sense to me.In fact, somebody said a little earlier in the afternoon when we became aware that this Bill might come on that, as we are now closer to government than ever before, we should refocus on this quorum Bill and perhaps approach it from the perspective of Senator Ray rather than the perspective of Opposition senators.

On the other hand, a well-known former Opposition Senator, Senator Puplick, who spoke in the debate back in December 1989-he was then acting in the capacity of Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate-argued that the necessity of attending a quorum is a discipline imposed on the Government to ensure that it does not bring about a situation in which the Opposition is forced to call quorums in order to make political points. That discipline ought to be imposed on Ministers regardless of which political party they are drawn from. Odgers notes that, although it is often maintained that it is the responsibility of the Government to maintain a quorum, it is, in fact, the responsibility of the Senate-something that I have been reminded of from time to time. Sometimes late at night in difficult quorum situations that argument has come forth. The House of Representatives quorum has been reduced from one-third to one-fifth.

A perusal of Parliaments of the World, a comparative reference compendium prepared by the International Centre for Parliamentary Documentation of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, reveals that most parliaments require a quorum of at least half the membership. Of 82 countries surveyed, four countries require a quorum of two-thirds of the membership; 48 require a quorum of half the membership or more; and 11 require one-third of the membership.

I will look very briefly at a couple of examples. In the United States the quorum for the Senate is an absolute majority of members; in Austria the quorum for the Federal Council is one-third of the membership; in Belgium a quorum for the Senate is a majority of the membership; in Brazil the quorum for the Federal Senate varies according to the type of Bill, but is usually an absolute majority of members; in France the quorum of both the Senate and the National Assembly is an absolute majority of members; and in the Netherlands the quorum of both the First and Second chambers is an absolute majority of members.

It seems therefore that, if we look to precedent, precedent tends to favour a quorum of at least the number that we presently have, if not more. I readily concede that this is a judgment that is not necessarily easy to make. There is no precise figure; there is not a black and white test that need be passed. On the one hand, there are the arguments-good arguments-put by Senator Ray and similar arguments put by former Senator Hamer and, on the other hand, as I mentioned, there is the argument put by my former colleague Senator Puplick.

On balance, I have to say that I have not been persuaded that there is a need to reduce the quorum. I do not think that it is unduly onerous. I say that not being one that particularly thinks of it in terms of a discipline imposed upon the Government, but rather as a discipline imposed upon the Senate as a whole and upon the Senate as an institution. I do not think it is unreasonable that one-third of senators should be on call and be prepared to meet the bells on the call of a quorum. I therefore do not see that there would be any substantive advantage gained by the reform that our committee, and the committee of which I am now a member, recommends. Therefore on balance I have decided, as one senator, that I will vote against this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill has already referred to the antiquity of this piece of legislation and to the frequency with which we have been threatened with this debate. I had to scramble to the bottom of a recently reorganised drawer to find a permanently installed folder with which I had rushed into this chamber many times to acquaint myself. I really cannot believe that we are actually debating the Senate (Quorum) Bill 1989 [1990]. We last felt it was coming very close on 7 September 1990. I will refer to an action I had prepared at that stage in a minute. As Senator Hill has said, the purpose of this Bill is to reduce the quorum of the Senate from one-third of its members to one-quarter-that is, to 19 rather than the 26 which is currently required.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government put forward a number of arguments for this move, including a reference to the work of honourable senators in the committee system. Since the Minister's second reading speech, which put down that reason, we have involved ourselves in yet another dimension of Senate committee work which is taking the time of honourable senators. In most cases that is very productive work. It is true that the Senate does have a fine tradition of very effective and very important committee work. We must bear that in mind when we are addressing the question of a quorum in this chamber. I accept that that is one of the dimensions of what we are being asked to consider in this legislation.

Senator Hill referred to the work of Ministers and to the Government's view that to have a smaller quorum would be of advantage to that particular group of senators-those who are Ministers. There are, indeed, many calls on their time and, of course, there are other calls on the time of all honourable senators. When introducing this legislation, the Minister's second reading speech referred to the increasing volume of correspondence that all honourable senators get and the representations, the delegations, the visits and so on.

At this point it is interesting to reflect on what members of the general public feel about attendance in the chamber. The people who have come to the public gallery today are seeing a remarkably full Senate chamber for this hour on a Wednesday afternoon. The attendance here at this time is very high, particularly for this type of legislation. Normally, a routine piece of legislation at this hour on a Wednesday afternoon, might see only four or five people in the chamber, if that.

Today we have a considerable number of vitally interested senators in the chamber. The fact that before we began this debate the bells rang indicating that a quorum was required might have something to do with it. Some people may have considered that they needed a rest before they went back to their offices in the long, distant, corridors of this massive building. It is important simply to make the point that if honourable senators are not in this chamber, it does not mean that they are not doing productive work representing their constituents-whether it is by handling correspondence, by promoting the work they are doing, by meeting delegations or whatever. The work of a parliamentarian goes far beyond this chamber.
I was interested in the following statement in the Minister's second reading speech:
Attendance in the Senate and participation in its deliberations will still remain the most important role that senators perform.

When I read that sentence, my first response was that I wished that were the case for every individual senator. Senator Hill has made the point that this particular piece of legislation will be dealt with by a conscience vote by members of the Opposition. This is rare in this context.

It is well-known that we in the Australian Democrats believe that there ought to be more ability for all parliamentarians to exercise their own consciences on a range of legislation-debates would be more relevant, more interesting and of a great deal more significance-rather than the practice which is most often the case where party lines are adhered to, often quite reluctantly, by people on both sides of the chamber.

There are a number of reasons why, from time to time, there are more or fewer people in the chamber. Some were listed by the Minister in his second reading speech-he talked about the level of importance, the controversy and the nature of the debate. Another reason that has not been mentioned is that often the lateness of the hour and the lack of alternative entertainment can draw people into this chamber. Mr Acting Deputy President, I can remember sitting in your position in the old place and wishing that people would find their entertainment elsewhere in the later hours of the evening. It is important that we are here in this chamber as often as we can be to carry out our duties, when it is not necessary for us to be elsewhere to do so.

It is interesting to note that this proposition is to reduce the quorum of the Senate to one-quarter. The House of Representatives quorum has been reduced from one-third to one-fifth. Even with the passage of this legislation, the proportion of honourable senators required for a quorum will still be higher than that in the other place.

I would like to conclude with a couple of remarks about the use of the quorum. It is somewhat ironic that the first comment I was going to make has already been demonstrated this afternoon. A problem with quorums concerns their use, and I do have a few concerns in that regard. As we all know, and as we have seen this afternoon, a quorum is often used to call speakers in when they are not here at their allotted time because the Whips have not managed to get them here for one reason or another.

I believe they are also used from time to time to disconcert speakers-to put them off their stride-and that is an unfortunate misuse of the quorum. Sometimes a quorum is used because a speaker might be rather indignant that the relevant Minister is not in the chamber to hear the deep and meaningful remarks that are being made about a piece of legislation, and a quorum is called in order to bring the Minister into the chamber.

Quorums are sometimes used simply to interrupt speakers when what they are saying is annoying those present or when those views are disagreed with. I have to say that-not in this parliamentary session thus far, but in the past-I can remember many experiences where that has happened to Democrat colleagues and particularly to Senator Vallentine. I want to put on record that I believe that to be a misuse of the quorum. People may not want to hear alternative views but they will hear them for as long as I and my colleagues, Senator Vallentine and others are here.

The final point I want to make is that this is a mischievous use of a quorum-very much so because, while the quorum is being filled, the clock continues to run against the speaker, whose time can be used up. Regrettably, there have been many occasions in the past when a speaker's due time has not been available to that speaker because of the use of a quorum. Therefore, while supporting this legislation, I advise that tomorrow morning I will give notice of my intention on the next day of sitting to move the following amendment to the Standing Orders:
That Standing Order 189 be amended by adding the following new paragraph:

``(5) When the speech of a Senator is interrupted by attention being drawn to the absence of a quorum, the time allowed for the Senator's speech shall not be reduced by any time which elapses after the speech is interrupted and before it is resumed.''.

Tomorrow I will take the opportunity that this legislation presents to put before the Senate the proposition that that somewhat mischievous use of a quorum should no longer be available to us, and that the freedom of speech-which is held so dear by all in this chamber-is not lost to any speaker simply because what is being said might not be accepted by, agreed with or pleasant for others present in the chamber. I will be seriously putting before the Senate the proposition that when a quorum is called a speaker's time is not eaten up. However, I do support this piece of legislation. I think it is appropriate to the effective running of the chamber-picking up Senator Hill's point-on behalf of all of us as senators, not necessarily only for a government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Senate (Quorum) Bill 1989 [1990] which, I understand, has also been called the Robert Ray heart protection Bill-to save him the problem of having to come from the Cabinet room into this chamber. This Bill stems from a report of the Select Committee on Legislative Procedures which was presented to the Senate on 1 December 1988-a long time ago. The Bill, as has been pointed out by previous speakers, seeks to reduce the Senate quorum from one-third to one-quarter of honourable senators. In effect, this would reduce the number of honourable senators required for a quorum from 26 to 19 and would effectively exempt almost all Government Ministers from attending quorum calls. I notice that Senator Robert Ray is nodding in agreement with that point.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators are aware, the Constitution currently provides for one-third of senators to constitute a quorum, and this can only be changed by legislation, which is now before the chamber. As Senator Hill said in his remarks, the Government clearly does not have a great deal of interest in this Bill. In fact, it is before the chamber because the Government has run out of other business. Even on the odd occasion when the Bill has been on the Notice Paper, it normally has such a low priority that invariably it never gets debated. I guess that this is what makes this day particularly special.

Like the Government, I have a complete lack of enthusiasm for this Bill. However, unlike the Government, my enthusiasm is lacking so much that I will be voting against the change which I believe, in contrast to Senator Powell's remarks, would be to the detriment of Senate procedures. The issue of quorum numbers was extensively canvassed in this chamber when the report of the Select Committee was presented in December 1989. Senator Ray suggested that there were two reasons for altering the numbers required for a quorum. We can summarise these two reasons as the vegetable argument and the geographical argument. First, let us look at the vegetable argument. In Senator Ray's matchless words, the argument ran as follows:
When the [Procedures] Committee was moving the turkey around the plate between the Opposition side and the Government side it found the Government side a little deficient . . .
Does Senator Ray remember those words? He continued:
. . . and added a few vegetables-the quorum proposal-just to balance up the overall approach so that no side could be seen to be having a win.

This, in my view, is a poor argument. The quorum proposal does not stand up in its own right, but is merely a so-called face-saving proposal on behalf of the Government; it is the vegetables being moved around the plate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It means I can never cut a deal with you without your ratting on it.
—I shall return to the vegetable argument presently. There was no deal with me. I was not in the chamber. I was not in the Senate at that time.
—Most of the other speakers were the vegetables on the plate; you weren't even on the plate.

—I am glad that Senator Faulkner raises the issue of vegetables because it applies so often to the rather mindless comments he makes in this chamber. The second argument relates to geography. According to Senator Ray, Ministers have a three-minute walk to and from the chamber. This can be very disruptive to their timetable, according to Senator Ray. I have problems with this argument.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first place, it is important to note that we are not setting up rules for particular governments but for all governments regardless of their political complexion. To use Senator Ray's metaphor, the additional vegetables which may have been used to garnish the Labor dish will equally be on the dish for any other government, including a coalition government.

My experience, as a relatively new senator, is that Senate procedures are so heavily weighed in favour of the Government that we should be very cautious in further disadvantaging an Opposition. The calling of quorums is one of the few tactics available to an Opposition to draw attention to perceived shortcomings in the Government's own behaviour or in the behaviour of certain speakers in the chamber. This is an effective tactic.

My views therefore differ from some of the arguments that Senator Powell put forward. She mentioned, for example, what happened to Senator Vallentine. I think it is an effective use of the quorum when someone gets up very late at night, at 11.30 p.m.-and Senator Jones I am sure would agree with this-and then proceeds to read a speech at great speed for the full time which is allotted, that is, half an hour. I think it is appropriate in those cases where someone has not been prepared to attend the chamber to make contributions to other debates but feels that he or she may come in very late at night and read a speech which, I suspect, has been prepared for him or her. I differ from Senator Powell on this issue. I think it is an appropriate tactic.

Likewise, when a senator is being particularly offensive in a speech, a quorum is one of the weapons in the armoury. Senator Faulkner could use it to call in more people. Senator Powell interprets each of those in a very negative light. They can be interpreted in that way, but they can also have advantages. I am sorry that she did not mention those in her contribution. It is worth mentioning that quorum calls have been used with great circumspection since I came to this chamber, anyway. They are comparatively rarely used and, when they are used, from what I have seen for the most part they have some merit.

Senator Ray used the change in the geography of the chambers and the Cabinet room in the new Parliament House as the second leg to his argument. The three-minute walk hardly seems a sufficient change in geography to alter a longstanding Senate practice. Indeed, the extra exercise, minimal though it may well be, would be to the benefit of Ministers' health.

Senator Ray's Bill would exempt most Ministers from answering a quorum bell. They would not suffer the inconvenience of a three-minute walk. I agree with the comment of the former Senator Puplick, which was referred to by Senator Hill, when he addressed this matter. He said that discipline ought to be imposed on Ministers.
