Even Senator Ray was not entirely convinced by his vegetable argument or by the geographical argument. He therefore gave us another pearl. He may remember this. He seemed to argue that discipline would be even tighter with fewer honourable senators being required to answer the quorums because Ministers would be excluded. I recall that Senator Ray said:
I will tell those opposite how to punish them-
meaning the Ministers-
by exempting them from coming in and telling the back bench to come.
That would apparently impose an even tighter discipline on Ministers. He went on to say:
The backbenchers will exert discipline over Ministers much quicker than if the Ministers have to turn up.

Senator Ray would therefore have us believe that this Bill is the best of all possible worlds, that there would be no costs imposed by agreeing to the Bill and that it would address the concern of many people that we should have a tighter discipline in this chamber from time to time. I say to Senator Ray, `Nice try, but it doesn't convince me'.

Not only does this Bill have no intellectual foundation but it also exacerbates one of the problems of modern parliamentary practice. On this occasion I endorse the comments from Senator Powell about the very poor attendance in this chamber. Those of us who came in here this morning and looked across to the Labor side just after prayers would have counted three people. One of my overriding impressions as a comparatively new boy in this chamber is the appalling performance of most Labor Party people in attending this chamber. That reason, and that reason alone, would be sufficient justification in my case to oppose a Bill which would occasionally encourage Labor Party people to come into this chamber.
For all the reasons I have stated, when the vote is called on this Bill, I shall be joining with my colleagues Senator Hill and, I suspect, Senator Crichton-Browne and I shall be opposing this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to record my opposition to the Senate (Quorum) Bill. The arguments I would have put have already been put very briskly, articulately and persuasively by my two colleagues Senators Kemp and Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Come outside and back it up.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I hope I am not interrupting this challenge of another kind.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If you want to make derogatory remarks, why don't you back yourself up? If I can't put you away in the second, I'll do it in the third.
—Order! There are too many interjections from both sides.
—Does anyone want an adjournment while we sort out these problems?
—You make a challenge. I will choose the competition-the 100-yard sprint.
—Senator Crichton-Browne, I suggest you not be distracted, but continue with your speech.

—I do not propose to retrace the historic relevance of a quorum. However, its intrinsic virtue is to provide that at any one time there are a minimum number of people required to contemplate deliberations in the chamber. That is not a unreasonable proposition. As with any meeting procedures, from time to time we can suspend what is proper and what is necessary and we will get by with a short cut. However, proper processes have their place, and once we dilute basic standards we will quickly find that the process will begin to collapse.

SPEECH.PARA: My essential objection to this Bill-besides the fact that it reduces the figure required for a quorum to an absurd number-is that it breaks the nexus between the Executive and the Parliament. If we are to say that one-quarter of all senators is an adequate number, why not make it one-tenth? Why not make it the same as that required for a division-that is, two? If there is no intrinsic virtue in having a responsible and respectable number of senators in the chamber, there is no argument beyond having only one or two senators present. But my objection is that this Bill does break the nexus between the Executive and the Parliament. I say this as somebody who has been looking forward for some time to attaining government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might not be here.
—I am not coming up next time, unlike Senator Powell. Is Senator Powell coming up next time?
—Yes.

—Senator Powell is coming up next time. This Bill would mean ultimately that the Senate is maintained by the back bench of the Government and nobody else. The Opposition is not required to maintain it; the Executive is not required to maintain it. It is simply the back bench of the Government that would keep the Parliament functioning. In my mind, the breaking of that nexus really destroys the integrity of the chamber. The Executive and the Ministers are part of the Parliament and they ought to carry out their responsibilities, as should everybody else. Otherwise, as Senator Robert Ray knows, none of the Ministers will be required to attend the chamber for a quorum. Of course, that is the purpose of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill touched upon the circumstances which apply in parliaments in many other countries. With modest exceptions, at least one-third of a parliament's membership is required for a quorum. I think the United States Senate requires possibly an absolute majority-but certainly more than half. I do not suggest that we ought to be looking to other people's decisions to enable us to arrive at our own decision. I raise that point because I noticed that Senator Ray in his second reading speech referred to the fact that the figure required for a quorum in the House of Representatives has been reduced to one-fifth of the total number of members of Parliament. I suppose Senator Ray makes mention of that fact as some sort of supporting argument in his second reading speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am saying it is one-fifth. I do not say it is appropriate here.

—I guess the figure of one-fifth has been raised as some sort of argument for reducing the figure required in the Senate even further. It seems to me that the object of the exercise in the House of Representatives was the same as that which is proposed now in the Senate-that is, to reduce the quorum below the threshold level required to attract Ministers when a quorum is called. That is what this Bill is all about.
—I have said it straight up; I am not being devious.

—I am not suggesting that Senator Ray has been devious. For the reasons that have been given previously and for the reasons that I have touched upon, I will oppose this Bill. As Senator Kemp said, a quorum is for all governments. It is not some machiavellian tactic that suits the convenience of this Government or any other government.
—Why don't we link up attendance at quorums with pay?
—Another perk for the Government, for those in power.
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne has the call.
—Senator Austin Lewis put a proposal to me a while ago that if the Senate is counted out we perhaps ought to adjourn for an hour or for a lesser time--
—Ten minutes.
—That is what the Reps did. You don't want to follow them.

—We do not want to follow them, because that takes away the sanction. Who cares if one misses out on the quorum? There is a 10-minute tea break and we are back in business again. I countered that proposition by saying to Senator Lewis that in the event of a quorum being called perhaps only those who attend get paid. As Senator Ray says, it is the old--
—No show, no pay.
—No show, no dough.
—There would be a lot more speeches from Senator Vallentine on the adjournment then.

—Senator Faulkner is right. But the quorum is a useful mechanism for the Parliament. It is not meant as some sort of device to frustrate the deliberations of any particular government. It is an appropriate method of maintaining a sense of credibility and respectability in the Senate. I believe that the figure of one-third that we presently have should remain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am totally opposed to the Senate (Quorum) Bill 1989. I am totally opposed to meddling with the quorum of the Senate. The principle that must be retained in this chamber is that the Executive, the Ministers, are responsible to the Parliament and are to attend the Parliament, especially when there is a call for a quorum, at Question Time and when there is a division. If we were to allow a deterioration of this principle, which the Senate has held for 90 years, we would be taking away the sense of responsibility and accountability of Government Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: I say this with Senator Ray and his colleagues presently occupying the front bench on the Government side of the Senate chamber. I am very confident that there will be a change in the seating of the Senate whenever there is an election. That is very clear from the conduct of debate, the confidence here on this side of the chamber compared with the quietness and dispirited approaches on the Government benches. It is already evident from the way the public understands what is going on in this country, reflected in various public opinion polls.

I want my own colleagues-even myself, should I be invited to serve in that capacity-to be responsible to this Parliament and to ensure that for the rest of the decade, indeed into the new century, senators in this chamber are responsible, accountable and responsive to the business of this chamber. As I see it, only two reasons have been put forward for lowering the number of senators required for a quorum from 26 to 19. The principal reason is that this would no longer lead to an inconvenience on Government Ministers' time; they could conduct their interviews and other business in their own rooms here in Parliament House without the distraction from time to time of having to attend this chamber to answer a quorum call.

The second reason is that the figure required for the House of Representatives quorum has recently been reduced from one-third to one-fifth. That is no precedent for the Senate chamber to follow. Rather, we should understand-much more clearly than appears to be understood in the House of Representatives-that the Executive is responsible to the elected Parliament and it is to be responsive at the time of a quorum call.

The purpose of my speaking, frankly, is to alert all those honourable senators who are listening in their rooms-and I would ask their staff to alert them-that there will be a division in this chamber in a matter of a few minutes in which there is a free vote. Honourable senators will have to make up their own minds as to whether or not there ought to be a change to the quorum requirement that has held for 90 years in this place. It is actually spelt out in the Australian Constitution when it defines the Senate and then defines a quorum in attendance at the Senate as being one-third of the members.

I am confident that my colleagues in the Opposition will oppose this measure, that they will oppose any dilution of the quorum requirements of the Senate, but I appeal to all those honourable senators from the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Independents to take full weight of this debate. I appeal to them to note that the overwhelming majority of speakers have opposed this legislation and have not wanted to toady to the convenience of the Ministers of the present Government by making it possible for them to avoid the discipline of being responsive to this House.

Let me say one more thing: whenever the Senate is sitting there is the possibility of a division at any time. There may be a procedural motion; there may even be a vote of no confidence in a ruling from the President; and, of course, there may be a vote on a Bill. For those divisions, there is no question that Ministers of the Government-indeed, all senators-must be in a position to attend the chamber. As it is clear that a division can occur at any time, so a quorum call can occur at any time. I believe that there should be a continuing responsibility for Government Ministers, along with other honourable senators, to respond to the quorum call.

I am totally opposed to this legislation. I notice that it was first proposed on 1 December 1988. It has been a long time coming. Even in the present Ministry I think there is now great diffidence. We will hear from Senator Ray in a moment, but I urge all of my colleagues in the Senate to come into the chamber to vote against this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of an aside in the chamber that I had with Senator Ray, I am obligated to express a few words about this subject. There was a time when I would have supported the Senate (Quorum) Bill--
—When you thought you were going to be a Minister-be honest.

—There may be some merit in that. I would not argue against it. I do think attending quorums is quite onerous for Ministers, especially in this place. But the reason I am now not prepared to support this Bill-and I say this honestly to Senator Ray-is, quite frankly, the performance of the Labor Party back bench senators in government.
—They're hopeless.

—They are quite hopeless. When we were in government Labor Party senators used to attend because they were attacking us in government, but since they have been in government the Labor Party attendance has been absolutely appalling. The Labor Party is continually having meetings throughout every day of the sitting. Today I have been attempting to contact one of the Labor Party senators, who is a member of a committee I serve on. I have tried all day to contact that person but he has not been available in his office. At one stage I was told that his Whip did not know where he was, that the Whip's clerk did not know where he was, and that his secretary did not know where he was because he had so many meetings on. I tried to contact him not less than 15 minutes ago and was told that he has at least three meetings to attend between 5 o'clock and 6.30 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with the Labor Party is that it is quite clearly demonstrating that it would like Australia to be a one-party state, like some of our Asian neighbours, whereby everybody belongs to the one party, meets secretly, makes decisions in secret, and then comes into the Parliament and utters a few words for the sake of the media.

TALK.START.PARA: —But only the Ministers utter the words.

—Only the Ministers utter the words, and no contrary point is put. It is the Labor Party's miserable performance in government that has caused me to say that we cannot afford to change the quorum situation, because that would be going down the wrong road.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I understand some of the arguments that have been put here today against the Senate (Quorum) Bill; that is, the conservative argument that what has been thus always should be. I respect that as an argument.
—Ha!

—Senator Walters can chortle away but this was one of the arguments put by Senator Crichton-Browne and by some of Senator Walters's other colleagues. I accept that argument, because it is a philosophy of life that people feel safe and sound with. What I do object to is Senator Kemp and others half telling the reasons and distorting them. Senator Kemp is learning to do that very well in this chamber. It will not earn him any credit because if he is not careful he will end up being another Senator Michael Baume. Senator Kemp asks how I dared say in my earlier contribution that this was part of an arrangement. It was. When Senator Teague says that he is not in favour of toadying to Ministers, he should understand that many Ministers went a long way to improve the procedures of this chamber through a lot of extra time and effort on their behalf and on behalf of their staff. There was a bit of argy-bargy as to how the procedures of this place would be affected and that was reflected-and I will come back to this-in the vote on the matter on principle when it was taken on 5 December 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: I made no real assertion that because the House of Representatives changed it must necessarily occur here. What I have stressed is that the House of Representatives changed its quorum requirement to one-fifth of its members, which is a very significant drop from one-third. What we are proposing here is one-quarter. What has always been should not always continue. The founding fathers recognised that, and if they had not recognised it they would not have nominated a one-third quorum, subject to change by the Parliament. They recognised that they had probably picked an arbitrary figure. It must be remembered that in 1901 one-third of the Senate was 12 senators because we had 36 senators when this place was established. We now have 76 senators. The nature and tasks of MPs have changed in that time; so have the nature and tasks of the Executive.

It has been said by Senator Kemp that the real reason is geography and that I do not want to walk for three minutes. That really is a puerile suggestion. There is only one former Minister on the Opposition benches now, so those opposite do not know the experience-but they will one day-of having people come from all around Australia to meet with one for an hour. It certainly happened to me on two occasions when I was immigration Minister, and we had four quorum calls in that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might have merited four quorums. It's very rarely used.

—I will come back to the use of quorums. But that is terribly disruptive of government. With the Senate now sitting here for 23 weeks a year, it is not possible to schedule all my appointments with visiting CDFs, defence Ministers, ambassadors, et cetera away from this place and away from sitting times. One simply has to have those meetings here.

SPEECH.PARA: I admit that it is grossly embarrassing when one has a visiting defence Minister with all his staff in one's office and a red bell rings-if it is a division we cop it-and one has to come down here for a quorum three or four times in an hour. I also put on the record that I do not believe the calling of quorums in this chamber has been abused in the last year or two; I make no such assertion. But what is magic about one-third compared with one-quarter? There is absolutely nothing magic about it.

Senator Kemp summarised my argument and made the `sizest' comment that I cannot be bothered walking for 3 minutes. He should grow up and approach these things in a little more rational way than that. It is simply a matter of how often this country embarrasses visitors by Ministers having to get up in the middle of a conversation three or four times in an hour when these things occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said it's rarely used. You agreed it's rarely used.

—I did not say it is rarely used. I said it is rarely abused, which is a separate matter again. One does not know that a quorum is being called to get a speaker here when one is in the middle of a meeting. One has to come, irrespective of what one is doing. When we were in the old House-and I am sure Senator Kemp went there a few times as a visitor-the Ministers' offices were about a maximum of a minute from the chamber. So one-third as a quorum was suitable. Cabinet Ministers just came out and then went back quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, when Donald Grimes, John Button and co. were in Government in the old House, it took 20 seconds to get to the chamber. Now it averages about 3 minutes. We do not complain about the Cabinet room. From the Cabinet room is the quickest walk that we ever have. It is out the back door and we are here in 20 seconds. Honourable senators will have noticed that, when quorums are called and Cabinet is sitting, we are the first here; we beat everyone in.
Senator Kemp also apparently wants us to come here for prayers. Religion is a matter for someone's own view. If people want to turn up to prayers--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I didn't say prayers. I was very careful with that. You read Hansard.

—All right. If Senator Kemp is being very careful with it, I will not pursue the matter. As long as it was not implied that people have to turn up for prayers. That is up to the individual. When we last considered this, it was interesting to see, in terms of a free vote, what motivated people. Former Senator Chaney supported us. Senator Lewis supported us, but has had a rethink. Senator Patterson, former Senator Hamer, Senator Reid, Senator Short, Senator Tambling and Senator Watson voted on the merits of the argument on that occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: But we all know that, on this occasion, no matter how inspiring the oratory is-probably people are not listening out there-honourable senators will come in and vote by peer group pressure rather than anything else. I was asked by way of interjection whether the Labor Party has a policy on this. No, we do not on Standing Orders. We do not have a binding vote on Standing Orders. If Opposition senators want to continually accuse us of doing so, maybe we will look at it and have one, but we do not.

I remember when former Senator Ryan and Senator Gareth Evans voted with some of the others about the reading of speeches. In light of the fact that they read more speeches in the chamber than anyone else, it incensed me that they would do that, but they did, and I might add that not everyone had their education.

I am not trying to put or say that this legislation is a matter of high principle. It is a matter of practicality. It is a matter of reform of procedures in this chamber. It is essentially to exempt Ministers from quorums. The question is often asked: how does one then discipline Ministers when they play up? If Ministers play up and then force backbenchers alone to come into this chamber when quorums are called, the ministry will be disciplined more quickly than anyone else by the same back bench, and that is a reality. Too often though, these sorts of standing order matters--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why doesn't the Whip leave you alone and make all the rest come? Why doesn't he say, `The Minister has an important delegation and he need not come; everyone else can.'?

—Would Senator Walters let me put something else on the record so it is on the record. On very important occasions, even when all the pairs are out, Senator Reid and her colleagues, I graciously acknowledge, will grant an extra pair. I must put on the record the cooperation we get. But one cannot do that for every visitor. One really has to measure off the really important ones to ask for that, but that is a fact.
—What I am saying is that you only need your Whip to whip the back bench to come in on time.

—Senator Walters says, `The back bench'. Let me tell the senator how many there are on the back bench. There are 22 and a quorum is 26. On any one day three or four people are away sick or overseas, especially in September-October. That is when the European parliamentary trip, the IPU and sometimes the CPA occur. So then we can be down to 18 or 17. Therefore, it is not quite so simple that we can say that these others are exempted. If this Bill is carried, it will not be that all the Ministers are exempted but Cabinet Ministers will be. Non-Cabinet Ministers would still have to attend quorums.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not a matter I feel passionately about. I believe it would improve performance of government if it was adopted. If it is not, it is not the end of the world. If we had more people opposite who had been put in the same position, we would probably get a little more sympathy towards the particular problems that the geography of this building creates. It is a different geography from that in the previous building. The Bill seeks to deal with constant interruptions to the regular program of executive government on the days on which we have outbreaks of quorums-and I acknowledge they are not that regular.

I have not tried to dress it up in any other principle or anything else. I would urge all honourable senators to support the legislation. The fact that it has hung around for two years is basically because we have always managed to come up, as we have today. Awaiting the disposal of this matter, there is further legislation that will be brought on immediately after the conclusion of this Bill.
Question put:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INSURANCE LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1991LIFE INSURANCE POLICY HOLDERS' PROTECTION LEVIES BILL 1991LIFE INSURANCE POLICY HOLDERS' PROTECTION LEVIES COLLECTION BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That these Bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
INSURANCE LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1991

The former Treasurer foreshadowed in announcements on 6 November 1990, 21 January 1991 and 11 February 1991 that the Government would be implementing a range of measures to provide financial support to policy holders of Occidental Life Insurance Company of Australia Limited and Regal Life Insurance Limited, and to increase the general level of prudential protection provided to life and general insurance policy holders.
This Bill, together with five other companion Bills, gives legislative effect to the measures outlined in those announcements. The five companion Bills are:
* The Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991;
* The Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill 1991;
* The Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill 1991;
* The Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991; and
* The General Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991.
Taken together, this package of Bills will:
* Improve the financial and prudential standards which must be satisfied by life and general insurance companies;
* Provide a mechanism for the prior screening of changes to the ownership and control of life and general insurance companies;
* Put in place levy arrangements which will ensure that an appropriate degree of protection is provided to policy holders of Occidental Life and Regal Life; and

* Allow for the recovery of costs arising from additional resources provided to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, for the purpose of improved industry supervision, through an increase in the life and general insurance supervisory levies.

The measures have been developed in liaison with senior representatives of the life and general insurance industry associations. In this respect, I would like to place on record the Government's appreciation for the constructive comments and advice received from the industry associations and underwriters during this process. This co-operation demonstrates the industries' understanding of the need for soundly based and well directed supervisory legislation.

Mr President, the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1991 effects a number of amendments to the Insurance Act 1973 and the Life Insurance Act 1945 to strengthen and improve the effectiveness of the existing supervisory arrangements.

The Government is introducing these measures to overcome a number of deficiencies in the two Acts which became evident during the investigation into the affairs of Occidental Life and Regal Life at the end of last year, and as a result of other developments in the life and general insurance industries.

The measures in some cases represent a bringing forward of proposals from the current review of the Life Insurance Act 1945. This review, which involves a number of detailed and complex technical issues relating to the solvency standards to be observed by life offices and the controls which should apply in relation to new and innovative life products, is expected to result in further amendments to the Life Insurance Act in 1992.
This Bill is structured in three parts.
Part I provides necessary formal short title and commencement provisions.
Part II amends the Insurance Act 1973 to:

* Increase the minimum capital and solvency requirements for authorised general insurers and introduce an additional solvency requirement based on the level of a company's outstanding claims provisions (phasing-in provisions are to apply to existing authorised companies);

* Give the Commissioner, rather than the Treasurer, the discretion to exempt companies carrying on limited forms of insurance on a very small scale from such provisions of the Act as may be determined;
* Effect a number of minor amendments to the description of accounts and statements required to be lodged with the Commissioner;

* Permit the Commissioner to direct an authorised insurance company to have an actuary, who is not an officer of the company, carry out a review of its outstanding claims provisions and for the Commissioner to receive a copy of the actuary's report;
* Enhance the provisions dealing with investigations, appointment of inspectors and the giving of directions to authorised insurance companies;

* Provide measures to disqualify a person who has been bankrupt, or convicted of an offence relating to insurance or dishonest conduct, from appointment as a director or to a senior management position; and
* Enable the public disclosure of information additional to that which is already available from statutory returns lodged with the Commissioner by general insurers.
Part III amends the Life Insurance Act 1945 to:

* Increase the minimum paid-up capital requirement applying to registered life offices which have a share capital, and to require all registered life offices to maintain an excess of non-statutory fund assets over non-statutory fund liabilities (phasing-in provisions are to apply to existing registered life offices);

* Increase the frequency of actuarial investigations to be made into the financial condition of a registered life office by an appointed actuary (the increase will bring the requirement into line with current practice);
* Reduce certain periods specified in the Act for the lodging of annual statutory returns by registered life offices;
* Enhance the provisions dealing with investigations, appointment of inspectors and giving of directions to registered life insurance offices; and

* Provide measures to disqualify a person who has been bankrupt, or convicted of an offence relating to insurance or dishonest conduct, from appointment as a director, to a senior management position, or to the position of appointed actuary.
I would now like to address some of the more significant provisions of the Bill.
Minimum Capital and Solvency Requirements

The Bill proposes that the minimum paid-up share capital requirement for a company seeking authorisation to conduct general insurance business be increased from $500,000 to $2 million, and that the minimum amount by which the company's assets are to exceed its liabilities be increased, from $1 million to $2 million.

The Bill also provides for similar amendments to the minimum capital and solvency requirements which must be maintained at all times by authorised general insurers. The effect of the new solvency arrangements, which apply to all business of Australian incorporated companies and to the Australian business of overseas incorporated companies, will be that the value by which an authorised insurer's assets must exceed its liabilities will, subject to transitional provisions, be the greatest of:
- $2 million (increased from $1 million);
- 20 per cent of its premium income in its last preceding financial year (the existing requirement is unchanged); or
- 15 per cent of its outstanding claims provision as at the end of its last preceding financial year (this is a new requirement).

The minimum capital and solvency requirements of the insurance Act have remained unchanged since 1984. The increase in the minimum monetary amounts is therefore a measure to bring the requirements up to date and more into line with present conditions.

The proposed additional solvency requirement, equal to 15 per cent of outstanding claims provision, will ensure that the minimum required solvency margin better reflects the circumstances of insurers with large outstanding claims provisions.

The present solvency margin, which has regard to the level of a company's premium income, has proved to be deficient in cases where companies with very large outstanding claims provisions suffer a decline in premium income. The Bill ensures that an appropriate degree of protection is provided to policy holders in such circumstances.

The Life Insurance Act 1945 currently provides that, where a company seeking registration has a share capital, it must have a minimum $2 million paid-up capital and share premium account balance. No similar obligation is placed on non-share capital companies (mutual companies) seeking registration and there is no requirement for branches of overseas insurers to maintain funds in Australia.

The Bill provides for an increase from $2 million to $10 million in the minimum capital requirement imposed under the Act. This will apply to all companies with a share capital on a continuing basis. It also imposes a requirement on companies without share capital to maintain assets of $10 million, and for foreign companies to maintain assets of $10 million in Australia. These assets must be held outside the statutory funds.

In addition to the existing requirements which deal with the solvency of individual statutory funds, registered life offices will now be required to maintain an excess of $5 million of assets over liabilities, to be held outside of the statutory funds.

The requirement to also hold funds outside the statutory funds will ensure that proprietors maintain a financial commitment to the effective operation of the life office and that additional support is ultimately available to the statutory funds should this prove to be necessary.
Investigation Provisions

During the investigation into the affairs of Occidental Life and Regal Life, it was found that the existing provisions of the Life Insurance Act 1945 relating to investigations and the issue of directions restricted the ability of the Commissioner to act to protect the interests of policy holders in a timely manner.

In particular, the Commissioner was not able to issue directions concerning the business of the company until after his investigation had been completed. There was no scope, as is the case with the Insurance Act 1973, for the issue of interim directions in circumstances where it has become clear that these are justified but the overall investigation is not yet completed.

This is an issue which is of considerable concern to the Government, as it is possible for circumstances to prevail where the position of policy holders could be severely compromised by the inability of the Commissioner to respond in a timely fashion.

As a result, the Government is moving to ensure greater consistency between the provisions of the two Acts relating to the conduct of investigations and the issue of directions. The amendments proposed in the Bill draw upon the stronger features of the relevant provisions in each of the Acts.

The Bill therefore amends the Life Insurance Act 1945 to provide that the Commissioner may issue directions during the course of an investigation, and prevent a life office dealing with certain of its assets. The Insurance Act 1973 is amended to provide that the Commissioner, rather than the Treasurer, can appoint an inspector to undertake an investigation into the affairs of an insurer, and give directions to a company pursuant to such an investigation.
Disqualification of Certain Persons

The Government has had concerns for some time that the safeguards in the insurance supervisory system are not sufficient to exclude from key positions in insurance companies, people who have been convicted of dishonest conduct.

The Bill therefore provides that an insurance company will be prohibited from appointing to certain positions a person who has been found guilty of an offence in respect of insurance or dishonest conduct. It also provides a similar prohibition in respect of persons who are, or have been, bankrupt or insolvent.

The positions to which this disqualification will relate are Director or Principal Executive Officer of an Australian company, and local executive officer of a foreign company. The provision will also apply to the appointed actuary under the Life Insurance Act 1945.
Provisions have been included in the Bill to provide a defence against prosecution where the defendant company shows that it did not know or suspect that an appointee was disqualified.
Actuarial Investigations
The Bill introduces new provisions into the Insurance Act 1973 which enable the Commissioner to direct an authorised insurer to have an actuary carry out a review of its outstanding claims provision.

The outstanding claims provision is almost invariably the largest liability of a general insurance company. Significant delays can occur, even in respect of well managed companies, in the reporting and settlement of claims, particularly in the liability classes of insurance business, including workers' compensation and public liability business.

The outstanding claims provision of a general insurance company is determined on the basis of a process involving statistical and actuarial estimation. The proposed measure will enable the Commissioner to have the company's estimations independently verified where this is considered to be appropriate.

The Bill also includes provisions to bring the Life Insurance Act into line with current practice by requiring an investigation into the financial condition of registered life offices to be carried out annually by the company's appointed actuary rather than at five-yearly intervals.
Financial Implications

The measures contained in this Bill to increase the prudential protection available to insurance policy holders, together with those contained in the Companion Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991, will result in additional supervisory costs being incurred by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.
The additional resources needed to give effect to these measures have been estimated at $510,000 in 1990-91, $785,000 in 1991-92 and $410,000 in both 1992-93 and 1993-94.

These additional costs will be fully recovered through the life insurance and general insurance supervisory levies. It is for this purpose that the Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991 and the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991 are included in the package of Bills before the House.
I commend the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1991 to the Senate and present the related explanatory memorandum.
LIFE INSURANCE POLICY HOLDERS' PROTECTION LEVIES BILL 1991

The Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill 1991 and its companion Bill (the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill 1991) introduce measures to enable a levy to be imposed on life insurers to assist policy holders of Occidental Life Insurance Company of Australia Limited and Regal Life Insurance Limited.
These Bills form part of a package of six cognate Bills dealing with insurance matters. Taken together, the six Bills introduce measures to provide:
* Financial assistance to the policy holders of Occidental Life and Regal Life;
* Machinery for screening changes in ownership and control of both life and general insurance companies; and,
* A range of other improvements which will generally strengthen existing insurance supervisory arrangements.

As honourable senators will be aware, a judicial manager was appointed to take control of the business of Occidental Life and Regal Life on 7 November 1990. This followed the attempted sale of the two companies in September last year and the subsequent revelation that $65 million of statutory fund moneys of the companies had been misused. Under the Life Insurance Act, all policy holders' funds must be held in statutory funds which may only be applied to meet liabilities and expenses applicable to those funds.

Investigations by the judicial manager have indicated that there is a potential significant shortfall in the major statutory funds of the two companies and that the amount of the shortfall is dependent on the outcome of various legal and other proceedings.

Against the background of the significant implications of these events for affected policy holders and on the life insurance industry generally, the industry devoted a considerable amount of time and effort in attempting to develop voluntary support arrangements to provide assistance to the policy holders involved.
Notwithstanding the goodwill and assistance shown by the industry, it was found that significant legal and technical difficulties stood in the way of an effective industry approach.

This led to the Government announcing on 21 January 1991 that it would introduce legislation to provide for one-off levy arrangements similar to those which were proposed under the industry voluntary support arrangements.
This Bill and the associated Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill give effect to the announced arrangements.

In developing these arrangements, the Government had particular regard to the importance of the life insurance industry to the Australian economy as a repository of long term personal and retirement savings. It also had regard to the special and unusual circumstances involving the unauthorised dealing in statutory funds moneys which led to the potential for serious loss on the part of policy holders, and the need to carefully balance the interests of those policy holders and the interests of policy holders generally.

A key component of the Bill is that it will permit the making of regulations to impose one or more levies on the Australian proportion of the value of the statutory fund assets of a life insurance company for purposes of ensuring that up to 90 per cent of policy holders' claims against Occidental Life and Regal Life are satisfied.

In line with the Government's announcement of 11 February 1991 concerning the proposed levy arrangements, the Bill also contains provisions which will limit the total amount of levy collected under the legislation to $65 million.

Other provisions in the Bill, and in the companion collection Bill, provide for safeguards which prevent the levy arrangements from applying unless the insurance and superannuation commissioner is satisfied that the financial position of Occidental Life or Regal Life, particularly in relation to availability of assets, is such as to warrant resort to the levy process.

The two Bills have been developed in consultation with the senior representatives of the life insurance industry. In addition, a committee of senior industry representatives has been established to assist the insurance and superannuation Commissioner in the implementation of the levy arrangements. It is envisaged that the Commissioner, and this Committee, will be working closely with the judicial manager (or liquidator) of Occidental Life and Regal Life in this process.

The Bills complement court and other actions which have been set in train by the judicial manager in an endeavour to recover statutory fund moneys due to the two companies. It is also relevant that investigations to ensure the prosecution of persons who may be guilty of offences relating to the circumstances of the two companies are continuing.

In concluding this outline of the Bill, I should emphasise that it is the clear intention of the Government to do all it reasonably can to prevent the kind of problems that have emerged as a result of the attempted sale of Occidental Life and Regal Life.

It is for this reason that the Government attaches considerable importance to the other measures, such as those dealing with prior screening of changes of ownership and control of insurers and improved capital standards and prudential requirements, being brought forward in this package of Bills.
I commend the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill 1991 to the Senate and present the related Explanatory Memorandum.
LIFE INSURANCE POLICY HOLDERS' PROTECTION LEVIES COLLECTION BILL 1991

The Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill 1991 and its companion Bill (the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill 1991) introduce measures to enable a levy to be imposed on life insurers to provide an appropriate level of protection for the policy holders of Occidental Life Insurance Company of Australia Limited and Regal Life Insurance Limited.

These Bills form part of a package of six cognate Bills which also deal with a range of other insurance matters, including minimum capital standards and other prudential requirements and machinery for screening changes in ownership and control of both life and general insurance companies.

In the second reading speech on the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill 1991 the background and other considerations were outlined which have led to the development of the levy arrangements provided for in these two Bills.

In broad terms, the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill is concerned with establishing the detailed machinery relating to the collection and application of levies imposed for the purpose of providing financial assistance to policy holders of Occidental Life and Regal Life.
Under the provisions in part 3 of the Bill, a special trust account, the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Fund, is established to receive levy moneys paid by life offices.
The Bill also provides in part 4:

* For the grant of financial assistance from the fund, on request from the judicial manager (or liquidator), where the commissioner is satisfied that the financial position of Occidental Life or Regal Life, particularly in relation to availability of assets, is such as to warrant resort to the levy process;
* That a grant is subject to the condition that it will only be used to pay up to 90 per cent of each policy holder claim, and related administrative expenses; and

* That the commissioner may impose other specified conditions including that grant moneys not be applied to the benefit of persons who may have contributed to the difficulties of Occidental Life or Regal Life. He may also impose additional conditions in a grant determination where this is appropriate.
Part 5 of the Bill deals with the repayment of grants of financial assistance. In particular, the part provides for:

* The recovery of grant moneys from the judicial manager (or liquidator) where conditions to which the grant is subject are breached or in circumstances such as where the judicial manager (or liquidator) obtains settlement of debts;
* Grant repayments to have priority over most other debts of Occidental Life and Regal Life; and
* Repayment of any surplus levy moneys to the insurers who paid the levies.

The Bill also contains a number of additional safeguards to protect the interests of insurers subject to the levy and the policy holders of Occidental Life and Regal Life. These provisions will ensure that grants paid, and their application in accordance with the conditions attached to the grant, will be under the control of the judicial manager (or liquidator) who in turn is subject to the control of the court. The provisions also establish arrangements for the review of key decisions under the legislation and regular reporting to the commissioner and the parliament.

In summary, therefore, this Bill, and the companion Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Bill, provide for the imposition of one-off levy arrangements to assist policy holders who may be affected by the events which led to the appointment of a judicial manager to Occidental Life and Regal Life.

The broader measures included in the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill and the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill will ensure that policy holders generally will, in future, be better protected from events such as those which led to the imposition of this levy.
I commend the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Bill 1991 to the Senate and present the related explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LIFE INSURANCE SUPERVISORY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1991GENERAL INSURANCE SUPERVISORY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That these Bills may proceed without formalities and may be taken together.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
That these Bills be now read a first time.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 6 June, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1991. This Bill will allow the Commonwealth to hold goods, animals, plants, embryos, et cetera, which have been in quarantine until payment of expenses incurred in such quarantine has been made or suitable arrangements for payment have been made. It also allows, as a last resort, the Commonwealth to sell the goods and apply the proceeds of the sale to debt.

SPEECH.PARA: The Quarantine Act 1908 provides that the expense of keeping goods in quarantine for the time necessary to be assured that the risk of diseases and pests is minimal is a legal charge against the goods. However, if the payment is not made, it is not clear whether the goods can be sold to recoup the costs or whether they must be surrendered to their owners. The Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) in the other place in his second reading speech gave an example of a recent case where valuable animals had undergone extensive quarantine but had to be released with the owner owing the Commonwealth $1.5m. The Commonwealth is now suing for recovery, but with little likelihood of recovering the full amount.

Another example the Minister quoted in his second reading speech involves a program where a large number of animals held in quarantine for many years to address the risk of scrapie is coming to an end early next year. While the Commonwealth claims it has subsidised the seven-year care of these animals, charges will be up to $900,000. The importers have disputed the outstanding debt.

This Bill will give the Commonwealth the power to hold the goods until payment or an arrangement for payment has been made. If this does not happen, it gives the Commonwealth power to sell the goods and apply the proceeds of the sale to the debt owing to the Commonwealth. To protect the right of owners, the Commonwealth must serve a notice advising that if at the end of 30 days any expenses relating to quarantine are still outstanding the goods may be sold.

Since the passing of this legislation through the House of Representatives, the shadow Minister for primary industry, Mr Bruce Lloyd, has been contacted by various industry organisations and, in particular, by goat owners who have had goats under quarantine for some years that are due for release early next year. The Minister in his second reading speech mentioned that there was a $930,000 bill due early in the new year and that, as there was doubt about payment, this legislation would allow the Government to sell this valuable stock in order to recover the debt.

However, the Minister did not say that when these goat breeders contracted with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service they were advised it would cost $50 a head per year for the goats. This was agreed to and the goats arrived. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is alleged to have fed them on whole wheat and they died. These goats were replaced. Later, the goats owners agreed to an increase to $75 a head per year.

Costs have dramatically increased since then. In 1987, Minister Kerin made a counter offer to set the annual fee at $311 a head, together with what the goat breeders have indicated was a rather nebulous plan of acquisition by government agencies of an unspecified share of each of the syndicate's genetic material. This was considered unacceptable. The current fee per goat is $410 a head per year, which is a rise of more than 800 per cent since 1984.

The increase in payments to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has been done without consultation with the goat owners. The owners claim that legal action against AQIS is pending and are worried that this legislation could result in them losing their goats before they have had their day in court. This is an issue that I know has certainly been brought to the attention of many of my coalition colleagues, who realise that it is a major problem for not only goat breeders but also any other people wishing to import plants, animals, genetic material and other goods. They recognise that is it is simply not workable to legislate for a contract.

We have had representations obviously in connection with the goat issue but also on a broader sphere from the Cattle Council of Australia. The representations made by that important organisation have centred on the major concerns that are basically set out in two major issues. There is nothing in the proposed legislation that precludes its application in a retrospective nature. The legislation in its present form could be inferred to apply to existing arrangements between clients of AQIS and the service. This sets an extremely dangerous precedent and should be resisted.

The monopolistic powers of AQIS remain in its ability to set fees in the absence of real and effective consultation with the client. The ability remains for AQIS to set such additional fees during an ongoing contract. During the committee stage of this legislation, I will certainly ask the Minister to substantiate the criteria that he would wish to see applied by AQIS, particularly with regard to matters affecting the duration of quarantine, fees at the commencement of service and the acceptance of fee fluctuations not to exceed the consumer price index over the corresponding period. There needs to be a clearly established relationship which sets out with the intending client a clear and agreed set of criteria in respect of conditions that would prevail throughout the agreed service period. I will certainly ask the Minister to give consideration to this matter and for those organisations that have dealings with AQIS to have a watertight contract.

Whilst the debate on this issue has certainly focused on issues relating to the goat industry, it will also focus on a number of other industries that I am sure other honourable senators will want to canvass in more and particular detail. I have certainly had representations in the Northern Territory with regard to the operations of AQIS that affect horticulture and, particularly, tropical horticulture and exotic plants that are being imported and are now taking on quite a major significance as a special market in northern Australia.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you would be well aware that the sociology and, to a certain extent, demography of northern Australia has changed very dramatically in the last few years with the immigration and acceptance into our community of a large number of Asian residents. This has brought about a very differing pattern of horticulture in northern Australia, both in the exploitation of the horticultural industry and its development, and in many of the issues relating to the way in which plant products that affect the important horticulture industries of northern Australia in particular are brought in and then handled by AQIS.

This raises a number of particular issues. There is the ongoing debate amongst bureaucrats in Canberra and northern Australia and new horticulturalists of a new industry who are unable to solicit from the Canberra bureaucracy a proper and decent understanding of this very important new horticultural industry in northern Australia. The typical Canberra mindsets have flowed through to the AQIS operations, be they at a quarantine house and how that needs to operate, the fees and charges that need to be in for the alternate processing, and the very different systems that need to be adopted, particularly as they apply to plant products and genetic materials in northern Australia.

The imposition of a 100 per cent cost recovery program raises quite significant issues for this new industry in the Northern Territory. We need to ask very seriously how and what subsequent effects with regard to quarantine could be passed on elsewhere. The matter has raged in the media of the Northern Territory for some time now. I hope that the Minister will be in a position in his response to address a number of these issues that have been raised with him, Minister Collins, who is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia, and with the Federal member for the Northern Territory, Mr Warren Snowdon.

I would like to take a few moments of the Senate's time to read into the record an editorial which appeared in the Northern Territory News on Saturday, 6 July 1991. It is headed `Quarantine killing local horticulture' and reads:
Top End horticulturalists do have a point in what they say about the Australian Quarantine Service in Darwin.
Their complaints essentially have to do with two things: exorbitant charges and inadequate facilities which kill newly imported plants.
There is no criticism of the local officers in the service who, according to most growers, are doing a good job with what they have.
Nor is it their fault or the Territory Government's that the charges are so high. Those are set from Canberra.
The fault lies in a system which allows the expedient policy of cost recovery to triumph over long-term investment while denying proper training and facilities in the field.
The evidence says the horticulturalists are correct. Being hit with a bill of many thousands of dollars for a quarantine treatment which has actually killed your expensive imports is a disgrace.
But it is also a disgrace to suggest, as some growers did yesterday, that the way out for a few would be to smuggle in new varieties of plants and trees.

That is the best way to ensure the demise of an industry which should yield great profits in the future. There is nothing more certain than that the illegal import of genetic material would also result in the importation of exotic diseases.

It does not seem to make a lot of sense to save a few thousand dollars on the one hand, only to see a whole industry wiped out overnight. Which brings us to something of a dilemma. Horticulture is the fastest growing sector in the Territory's primary industries.
Value of production was $18.4 million in 1989/90, an astonishing increase of 40 per cent over the previous year's. An estimated 81 per cent of production was exported interstate or overseas.
It has huge potential because the Top End enjoys certain comparative advantages through its capacity to supply early-season and out-of-season southern markets in a range of products.
The people who have chosen horticulture tend to be very hard working and innovative, two virtues bound to pay off in the future.
But they are under threat by a short-sighted federal policy which actively operates against the best interests of growers.

They are made to pay through the nose for their attempts to improve the variety and genetic strains of fruit here, and they are lucky if they are able to collect a small percentage of their imports after they have been through quarantine.
In other words, Top End horticulturalists suffer the worst of both worlds-high charges for very little return.
It is a classic Australian story. Here is a handful of people trying to make a go of a tough industry and clearly succeeding against very difficult odds.

And there is officialdom fully supported by remote politicians trying to stifle their initiative. The ``clever country'' at work-although horticulturalists could be forgiven for thinking it is not particularly clever.

Whether it is the goat industry, or whether it is the horticulture industry of the Northern Territory or northern Australia, we do need to be very mindful of the changes that are necessary. This Bill will need to be very carefully scrutinised in the committee stage.
In conclusion, I give notice that the Liberal and National parties will be moving amendments to the Quarantine Amendment Bill in the committee stage. The first amendment reads as follows:
1. After clause 3, page 2, insert the following clause:

``3A The amendment of the Principal Act effected by section 3 does not apply to expenses incurred in respect of any animals, embryos, gametes or other genetic material, plants or goods first detained in quarantine before 1 September 1991.''.
The second amendment reads:
2. After clause 4, page 3, add the following clause:

``5. The amendment of the Principal Act effected by section 4 does not apply to expenses incurred in respect of any animals, embryos, gametes or other genetic material, plants or goods first detained in quarantine before 1 September 1991.''.

I understand that these amendments have been circulated to the chamber and I certainly commend them to the Senate. This is a most important issue; it is one that has wide ranging ramifications throughout Australia and one that needs very serious consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Quarantine Amendment Bill 1991 which the Senate is dealing with today amends the Quarantine Act 1908 and commences on 1 September this year. In speaking briefly to the Bill I would like to outline some of the major parts of it and then make some general comments about quarantine.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, the Bill. Clause 3 of the Bill amends section 64 of the principal Act relating to quarantine expenses in the case of animals and plants. This clause allows the Director of Animal and Plant Quarantine to direct that animals and goods must not be released from quarantine until expenses relating to the quarantine have been paid or until the owner has entered into some agreement for payment. The Bill provides that under any such agreement the payment of interest must not exceed the rate of 20 per cent per year and/or the giving of a security.

Clause 4 of the Bill concerns the sale of animals, plants or goods to recover quarantine expenses. This clause is effected by inserting a new section in part VI after current section 66. This new clause makes it possible to sell animals, plants or goods in order to recover the expenses of quarantine. The owner has to be given notice in writing of the proposed sale which can then take place 30 days after notification. If the sale proceeds, with the Commonwealth recovering quarantine moneys owed plus the costs involved in the sale, any surplus is then paid to the owner.

These changes go to remedy a difficulty which has existed for some time now in relation to the recovery of money from the users of the quarantine service. The parent Act, which goes back virtually to the start of the century, covered the fact that the costs of quarantine are a charge against the quarantine goods. What the Act did not provide for adequately was the situation where the money was not forthcoming from the commercial importer before the goods concerned had to be surrendered to the owner or importer. This amendment will remedy that situation.

The Opposition has no objection to that at all, but we see the need-and the amendments referred to by my colleague Senator Tambling, who proceeded me on the speakers list, deal with this-to amend the Bill to provide that it is not retrospective in its activities. As the Bill stands at the present time, anyone who is in debt for quarantine services prior to 1 September 1991 will be liable to have those goods sold.

In at least one case that I know of there is quite a high liability and it is worth spending a few minutes detailing that liability as an example of the situation that might exist. I am not aware of any case other than this one, but there could be others out there. This case relates to the importation of goats. There is a bill in excess of $1m for quarantine fees for the quarantine services provided by the Commonwealth for the importation of those animals. That bill is about 800 per cent higher than the breeders anticipated when they imported the goats.

That came about because the original charge is higher and the period over which the charge is levied is much longer than they anticipated. They responded to advice from the Department of Health in 1983 to the effect that the quarantine fees would be $50 per goat per year. The cost today is $410 per goat, which is very much higher. Furthermore, they were told that the quarantine service would take only five years and I think it ended up taking eight years-or some years longer than they had budgeted for.

In those circumstances, it is hardly fair or reasonable to expect the breeders to pay that bill. They entered into a business undertaking with the Commonwealth in the light of information supplied to them by the Commonwealth. They acted on that information in good faith, and now they find that their liabilities have blown out to more than $1m. I do not know the value of imported goats, but I doubt very much whether that is a commercially recoverable cost in the marketplace if they sell them for stud or breeding purposes. The goats certainly will not pay for themselves in the wool they yield-presuming they are one of the wool producing breeds.

Because of that, the Opposition is moving amendments to stop the Government being able to sell any animals that were in quarantine before 1 September this year. As the Bill stands, anyone who is in dispute with the Commonwealth is liable to have his goods seized if they have not been already handed over and sold to recover the debts. We fully support the concept that from now on it will be desirable for the Commonwealth to have the capacity to collect money owing to it because quarantine services are very expensive to maintain for the Commonwealth. I do not know what it cost to install the facilities in the Cocos Islands and the other quarantine facilities for animals and plant species around the country, but a great deal of money is involved in capital cost and in maintaining such facilities. It is quite obvious that any quarantine facility has to maintain maximum security to prevent the import of stock, whether animal or vegetable, carrying parasites or diseases which can move out into the Australian community.

The Australian quarantine requirements have a proud record of achievement, being based on scientific fact. We have never used quarantine requirements in this country as a non-tariff barrier against imports in the way a number of countries have. Australia has had to work with and respect the quarantine restrictions of other countries because we export material. We expect those countries which export to Australia and those Australians who are importing from other countries similarly to respect our quarantine laws. The quarantine laws are fundamental to the health not only of primary industry but also of the human community in Australia. They are designed for the good of Australia and to ensure that we do not import exotic pests or diseases which would affect the health of our rural industries.

Those industries are vulnerable in two ways. First, there is the loss of production and, secondly, there is the loss of markets. There are countries which simply would not accept products from us if we were known to possess certain diseases and parasites. The effect in commercial terms is enormous and difficult to quantify. Quarantine policies are about managing risk, making an initial assessment of that risk and then taking the appropriate procedures on the importation of the stock, whether animal or vegetable, to ensure that what is being imported is absolutely free of contamination.

The long term viability of our industries depends on maintaining those barriers. As well as maintaining those barriers in the form of the quarantine services, we have to have another arm, a reaction service, within the country so that if anything does escape the quarantine barrier we can deal with it. That depends on having adequate facilities to detect the presence of pathogens or parasites that have come into the country from overseas by escaping the quarantine barrier. The Customs Service provides part of the surveillance in respect of humans, and the Department of Health and the Australian Quarantine Service, in their checks, provide part of the surveillance.

As well as the surveillance side, we need a reactive capability in the form of destroying or inoculating against the pests when they are detected. It is one of the great tragedies of modern Australia that at the start of this decade we built the Animal Health Laboratory in Victoria for the development of vaccines and other procedures against parasites and infections in large animals. Industry was taken over, particularly the beef industry, by a wave of both ignorance and fear. The marvellous facility that we built, which I have visited, never reached its full development. The development of the Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong was a great credit to those people in Australia who were involved with its design and construction. What was involved was the construction of a completely viral-proof establishment with airlocks, decontamination chambers, controlled air supplies, quarantine and all the rest of it. It was principally, but not exclusively, concerned with parasites and infections in the large animal field, principally the beef industry.

The purpose of such a laboratory was to identify organisms such as the foot and mouth disease organism. If such a disease had been detected in Australia and if it could have been rapidly identified rather than having to send samples to laboratories in the United Kingdom, the continents of Europe or North America, and if we could have developed and manufactured vaccines, outbreaks could have been controlled and inoculations could have taken place immediately. Unfortunately, the community reaction based on a mixture of fear and ignorance, was such that even though this was the most modern and absolutely secure environment, the necessary vaccines needed to be kept in order to do the phage typing and all the rest of it for identification of the particular strain of the organism was not permitted. It is important from the quarantine point of view not only to have the barriers and assess what is coming in, but to have the detection facilities for those breaches that inevitably occur in the system and to be able to have the capability of reacting to them.

But I am digressing from the Bill. I think that we can take a great deal of pride in the success of quarantine services in the past. We have preserved in Australia an environment that is relatively free of some of the major destructive infections and pathogens for both the plant and animal kingdoms. We have earned a great deal of money from that, and it has been reflected in the high standard of living that this country has enjoyed this century. With the qualification that we will seek to amend the retrospective elements of this Bill, we wish it speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Quarantine Amendment Bill is proposed to ensure that charges accumulated by people who use quarantine facilities in Australia are paid before goods are discharged and, in the event that the charges are not paid, this legislation gives authority for the quarantine services to sell the goods to recoup costs.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Opposition signalled in the House of Representatives when this legislation was rushed through that place in the closing days of the last session, we are not opposing the legislation, but I have some grave concerns about several aspects of it. When we talk about goods in quarantine, to all intents and purposes we mean animals, whether they be on the ground or in an embryonic stage. The goods may also be horticultural, although I suspect that the costs that this legislation has necessitated would usually apply to animals.

Australia's quarantine record is one of which Australia can be justly proud. I, like every other Australian, would not wish that standard of control and surveillance to be lowered at any time. In recent years there have been increased demands on our quarantine services as Australian cattle, sheep and goat producers have increased imports of animals from a great number of overseas countries. They have done this because of the necessity to increase the genetic pool in order to increase production and to improve performance of their herd or flock.

The result has been an expanded gene pool and significant advances in the numbers and the variety of sheep, cattle and goats. One has only to look at the developments in British breeds of cattle such as the Poll Hereford to realise the important contribution that US and Canadian imports have had on that breed.

We have seen in recent months the importation of the Japanese Wahgu heifer. In recent years we have had the Piedmontese cattle from Italy, the Belgian Blue cattle and Pinzgauer cattle from Europe, and the Dexter cattle from the United Kingdom. There are sheep and goats presently in quarantine and I understand they will never be allowed out of quarantine because of the risk of scrapie. Some goats have been in quarantine for years and it is only the fourth or more generation that will actually be released onto Australian farms.

The importers of these animals obviously knew that they would be liable for considerable costs when they decided to import them and were aware of the longevity of the exercise. However, I wonder whether they realised the extent of their investment in terms of lag time before any dividend could be realised. I wonder whether they were able to negotiate a price for the agistment of their stock in quarantine. I would doubt that they were allowed to negotiate any price that was not the one given to them. Indeed, the price they were given at the start of the exercise has, over a series of press releases, gone completely through the roof. It is that aspect of this legislation that concerns me most. What opportunity has the importer to determine a fair and equitable price for the cost of boarding the animals? What opportunity has the importer of entering into a contract with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service over the costs?

If we look at the Budget that came down last night, we find that the Government has slugged people in rural areas to the hilt. Obviously this Government does not really care about country people. I do not think it understands the problems that country people or farmers have in importing some of these animals. I do not think that they have an opportunity to negotiate a fair price. Maybe the Minister will be able to explain that at the committee stage.

In the event of a dispute, who actually will be the arbiter? There seems to be no system for a firm contract, no system for an appeal or examination of the fees charged, and I believe that is unfair for the importers. On the Government's side, what is to stop an importer running up a large bill and then, anticipating that the price at the subsequent auction of the livestock might be less than the import bills, waiting for the auction and paying the lower price? I have no objection to the Government trying to ensure the user pays principle is applied but, at a time like this-and we saw this, as I said, in the Budget last night-to really slug rural people again is a bit inhumane of the Government.

Another area of the Bill that concerns me is that those who import the livestock are going to be at the mercy of whatever fees the Government chooses to levy. That is precisely what has happened here. In respect of the interest charged, the fee, at 20 per cent, is savage. The same Government has just finished telling us that interest rates are coming down, so why is the rate set at 20 per cent? I do not believe that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service ought to be attempting to run at a profit. A more realistic interest rate would be fairer.

In respect of the starting date of this Bill, the first question any importer will ask is whether the new fee payment arrangements will apply for any goods quarantined after 1 September, or merely that the rules will change with effect from 1 September. I believe it is patently unfair to change the rules for goods received before the legislation is in place. Retrospectivity in any legislation is bad and not sustainable morally or legally.

People who import plants or animals into Australia are contributing to the overall wealth of this country, in attempting to provide better genetic material, and I do not believe they ought to be unfairly discriminated against by the application of excessive quarantine fees. If fees are to be charged and pressed for without exception, and I stress I have no objection to governments obtaining a fee for service on a user pays principle-if there is competition, of course-I hope that the Government intends to ensure that people get value for their money and that the service is efficient and affordable. I question whether it is, and whether it can be when there is no choice. Monopolies tend not to create an atmosphere of affordability or equity.

I hope this legislation will be applied equitably and, where the Government decides to press for payment, that the negotiations are handled fairly and reasonably, taking into consideration the ability to pay what could be quite large accounts. The Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), in his second reading speech in the other place, cited the example of an account of over $1.5m, and Senator MacGibbon alluded to that earlier this evening. That is not a small amount of money to be met on top of the costs of purchase and transport. Obviously, while the animals are in quarantine they are not earning any money for the importer. I question why the amount has been disputed and whether the Bill was accumulated on charges that were levied without consultation with the importer. I suspect they were.

I support the amendments to be moved by Senator Tambling in this place on behalf of the Opposition and I urge the Government to ensure, for the sake of Australian agriculture, that its departments provide quality service and not treat every government function as a revenue raiser to prop up a sick economy-a sick economy that this Hawke-Keating-Kerin Labor Government has inflicted on Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only a few comments to add to those that have been made by previous speakers because, in essence, I agree with much of what has been said by Senator Tambling, Senator MacGibbon and Senator Brownhill. The concept in the Quarantine Amendment Bill of tidying up the regulations and introducing the principle of user pays is acceptable and should be endorsed.
