The concerns that have been expressed, especially those regarding the retrospectivity which would ensue under this Bill if it were passed as is, are ones which the Australian Democrats share. I give notice now that we will be supporting the amendments which the National Party proposes to move at the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: On looking at the Bills Digest dealing with this Bill, I found that the explanation given of the main provisions of the Bill was that clause 3 provides that the Director of Animal and Plant Quarantine may, where expenses are payable in respect of quarantined animals, plants or goods, direct that they may not be released from quarantine until the expenses are paid or an agreement for payment of the expenses has been entered into. There are two things that I think are very important to consider and they have already been alluded to by previous speakers. Firstly, the amount of the expenses and, secondly, an agreement for payment can certainly be placed under question. We are told that in this situation an agreement will be reached after there has been a dispute and until then the goods are not to be released from quarantine. Surely if it is possible to come to some sort of agreement when there is a dispute, logic would have it that one should look at an agreement in the first instance. The first instance is when the proposition is put that certain animals need to be placed in quarantine.

It concerns me that in considering this Bill I have received several different sets of communications. Within those communications there were several different case histories. In each one of those case histories we were able to see that there was a great deal of uncertainty about the sort of arrangement that was being entered into by both the importer and the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and about the expenses that would accrue from this arrangement. I shall outline one of the case histories. It will not take long, and I think it is worth hearing.

It comes from a communication that I received from a pastoral company in Keith in South Australia, where I am told that on 1 April 1984-perhaps that is a salutary date for the people who got involved in this arrangement-the people who were intending to import, following an advertisement asking for expressions of interest in the importation of North American goat stock, in the first correspondence had fees quoted to them of $50 per annum. The advertisement stated in part that the anticipated cost would be of the order of $4,500 per imported animal for all agency fees, testing and freight costs with the major variable being freight, which is related to the number of animals in the shipment, plus-this is the important point-$50 per year per animal kept on Torrens Island. The per animal fee was for imports, progeny and recipients; in other words, regardless of whichever description fitted the animal, it would still cost $50 per animal. In addition, any specific costs for artificial insemination, ovum transplants, shearing, et cetera applicable to and requested by the importer would be charged at normal contract rates.

That is pretty plain, straightforward terminology. One would imagine that that would be acceptable and understandable to all parties concerned. But on 12 October 1984 at the first importers' seminar in Adelaide, importers were asked whether they would accept an agistment fee rise to $75 per animal per year. The importers-I suggest quite naturally-agreed to this rise. It also took into account consumer price index increases each financial year.

Again, it seems quite reasonable so far; but on 18 September 1986 the fees were lifted from $75 to $311. No prior notice was given. Importers first read about this in the press and were not consulted. Soon afterwards, on 13 November 1986, importers received correspondence advising of this rise to $311. That was the confirmation. Again, though, there was no opportunity for consultation on this matter. On 16 October the following year, another fee rise to $340 was approved and then a further rise took the fee to $360, in line with the CPI, the following financial year, and similarly each subsequent year. As we have already heard, the fee is now in excess of $400 per annum per animal.

This reads as a recipe for disaster for someone who had entered into what seemed to be a fairly straightforward arrangement. As one of the previous speakers mentioned, it seemed a monopolistic situation also, for these people were over a barrel. There was very little they could do to say no or to question. There was very little opportunity-in fact, I can see no opportunity-for them to do any negotiating. As has already been asked-and I agree entirely-where was the opportunity for arbitration and the opportunity to negotiate?

One can understand the frustration of those who are involved in this industry being put in such a position, where they have very little opportunity to address the financial situation that they got themselves into. What is even worse is that in the Bills Digest on the proposed legislation we are told:

Clause 4 provides that where animals, plants or goods are being held in quarantine for the purpose of recovering quarantine expenses, the Director may give their owner a notice advising them that if, at the end of 30 days from receipt of the notice, quarantine expenses remain payable, the animals, plants or goods may be sold. At the expiration of the 30 day period the Commonwealth may sell the animals, plants or goods. The proceeds of sale are to be used only to meet the expenses payable, and any surplus is to be paid to the owner.

It sounds reasonable enough, but it is not because the owner's interest in those animals would be considerably in excess of what their auction price would bring. The investment would include not only the period during which the animals have been in quarantine-the lag time-but also what could be called the opportunity cost. This is not just a case of importing a few animals. It is usually a case of importing animals with the prospect of establishing a stud or breeding program. That is the purpose of introducing the animals to start with. That is what this is all about.

Importers are not going through such an exercise just to add a few numbers to a flock; they are looking at an entirely different sort of flock. Those who believe that importers are content to make that investment and have the Commonwealth receive the auction price, with the few dollars that may be in excess being returned to the original owner, just do not understand the reason for importing stock. I see that as being evidence of a misunderstanding of what importation programs are about. The other aspect which will be the subject of amendment illustrates the lack of understanding of the concerns about retrospectivity.

The fact that this Bill contemplates applying these rules or fees now to existing arrangements reveals the Government's attitude to importers. I have described part of a case history in which the importers' interests were not considered, in which the importers were not consulted before rule changes were made. Here we have a further example. Here we have the idea that we can ride roughshod over the existing arrangements; apply fees or rule changes in the middle of the deal, if you like; change the rules of the game while the game is in progress. The fact that the Government was willing to do this, and is being prevented from doing so only by the proposed National Party amendment, illustrates its attitude that it will ride roughshod over the importers without consultation, not willing to pay any regard to the principles of what I expect ordinary people would see as fair play.

For that reason I have no qualms in supporting the forthcoming amendment to be moved by the coalition. I am particularly concerned that we have been unable to draft an amendment which would ensure that there could be a clear and agreed set of criteria in respect of the conditions that could prevail through the agreed service period. Those were the words of the Cattle Council of Australia in a communication I received asking whether such an amendment could be incorporated in the Bill. It is with great frustration that I find that we are unable to do that because, apparently, such an arrangement would create a precedent for other primary industries.

I would hope that the special nature of the importing industry itself, and the special conditions which apply to such an industry, would be worthy of the attention of the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) to such an extent that he might be able to understand how important it is for people entering into arrangements to know what they are letting themselves in for before the final commitment is made. In this case history that I read to the Senate, I would have thought that the initial correspondence laid it out fairly clearly, but once the animals are in quarantine, the importer has very little option but to go along with any changes which occur. I hope that somehow or other we can address that situation.

There is the folklore warning that you do not buy a pig in a poke, where you cannot see what you are letting yourself in for-or a goat in a poke, or a goat on an island, or a goat in a monopolistic situation where you, the owner, can be exploited further down the track. Whatever way one describes it, the situation is inequitable for the importer. I sincerely hope that we can address that situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleagues have said, the Opposition generally supports the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1991, except for its retrospective aspects. My colleagues have mentioned that as well. I am very pleased to note that the Australian Democrats also are opposed to that retrospectivity. I know that my colleague on the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, Senator Bourne, and the other Committee members, are always concerned about any aspect of retrospectivity. It is indeed good to note that in this instance the Australian Democrats will support the amendments that we will be proposing to negative the retrospective elements of this Bill. I am pleased to note that. I urge the Government also to support those amendments in order to get rid of that retrospectivity.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally speaking, we support the provisions of this Bill which provide for the Commonwealth to hold goods-animals, plants, embryos, et cetera-which have been in quarantine until the expenses incurred in that quarantine have been paid for or until suitable arrangements for payment have been made. As a last resort, the Bill also allows the Commonwealth to sell the goods after suitable notice has been given and to apply the proceeds of sale to the outstanding debt.

Whilst talking about the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, I also wish to raise the position of the stone fruits industry in the granite belt in the State of Queensland and, particularly, matters relating to the importation of bud wood for the stone fruits. I have three worries: first of all, the importation of plant material disease into the granite belt area; secondly, the importation of exotic plants on illegal plant material; and, thirdly, the importation of exotic plant disease on legally imported fruit and vegetables.

As I understand the process with stone fruits, if someone wants to import bud wood into Australia, it can be done through the Australian Customs Service. The bud wood for a new species or a new variety is released to plant breeders in overseas countries, usually in December in the northern hemisphere. This bud cannot be grafted in Australia until the following spring because of our differing seasons.

The bud wood is sent by air to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service for the specific nurseryman who is importing it. These buds are then grafted and tested for parasites and diseases by AQIS. One year later they are regrafted in quarantine and the original plants are then destroyed. There are then further checks for parasites and diseases and, if all is well, these small plants are released to the nurseryman after the fees are paid. The legislation that we are talking about today is relevant to that aspect.

Three years after the commercial release of this variety overseas, the Australian nurseryman, for the first time, begins to produce these trees. Two years then elapse before there are sufficient trees available for sale, and a further two to three years are required before fruit is available for the Australian export market. So it is approximately six years after the release of the variety to most other parts of the world-that is, the people that we compete with in the export of these fruits-that Australians can begin producing the fruit for the home market and the export market.

Plant variety rights are available in Australia, but a variety is ineligible for protection under PVR if it has been commercially available anywhere in the world for six years. Therefore, PVRs are of little use under Australian conditions and do little to encourage the importation of new, improved varieties. This long delay has a down side in that it encourages the illegal importation of plant material which can be budded immediately and which will produce trees years before the same variety can be brought in legally. That is a real problem. It has been a problem in the Stanthorpe area. It is brought about because of this very long process that is necessary to bring overseas new varieties legally into the country.

I believe that there is quite a large trade in the illegal importation of deciduous fruit bud wood. I can say this because of recent investigations I have done in Stanthorpe and discussions I have had with people in the industry in that area. This has some unfortunate effects. With that sort of importation can come exotic plant diseases, for example, ring spot virus disease in paw paws, which has been rampant in the paw paw growing areas of my State for some time.

Technology now exists for the early detection of plant diseases at the bud wood stage, and this could be done either in the sending country or on arrival. If this proved negative, the buds could be multiplied under quarantine using agriculture departments' facilities, for release in bulk years before it is now available. I suggest that we can test for early detection of these plant diseases at the bud wood stage using the technology that now exists. Regrettably, some of the rules that we work under at the present time were promulgated many years ago-in fact, decades ago-when the technology was not available for this early detection. It is now available, but apparently is not being used.

If, when a plant comes in, there is no evidence of plant disease at the bud wood stage, my suggestion is that the agriculture departments in the various States could be used for bulk release of this bud wood. This process would largely negate the present illegal importation of bud wood, with its risk of the importation of exotic parasites and diseases. Another paradox is that the plant diseases already in Australia are subject to quarantine of imported plant material.

There is another side of the coin which should be looked at. I mention these points because I think it is time for a review of the Quarantine Act, particularly as it relates to this issue. The other side of the coin is the legal importation of fruit and vegetables. The Australian Quarantine Service at present is proposing to allow the importation into this country of fruit and vegetables from countries and areas which are affected by plant diseases not presently in Australia.

For example, the apple disease, fireblight, is present in New Zealand. The Australian Quarantine Service may allow New Zealand apples to be imported into Australia if they come from trees no less than 500 metres from infected trees. This is a ludicrous proposition. There can be apple trees in New Zealand infected with fireblight, but trees which come from no less than 500 metres away from them are apparently allowed into Australia. If the disease gets into Australia, it may affect Australian apple trees and completely ruin an industry. That does not seem to me to be right, but that is what I am told happens. Bud wood material inevitably comes in on such fruit and, from time to time, it has been illegally used by Australian fruit growers to produce trees of the imported varieties and this creates that danger to local industries that I speak of.

There is another aspect: spray is not allowed to be used in Australia. For example, antibiotic sprays which are banned in Australia are available in other countries and are able to be used to control bacterial spot in stone fruit. That fruit is then allowed to be sold in competition with our fruit, which is antibiotic-free fruit. That seems to me to be silly. I understand that we ban these sprays because we Australians do not want to eat the antibiotic spray on these fruits because it would build up our resistance to antibiotics. So we ban the use of these sprays in Australia, but we allow other countries that do use them to export to Australia fruit which competes with our fruit.

It seems to be okay if we eat the overseas fruit which has this antibiotic spray on it, yet we are not allowed to have this spray on our own fruit. That does not seem to me to be right. There is a length of time during which the spray is supposed to break down and not pose a danger. It seems very silly to me that we make our farmers compete without using those antibiotic sprays and we allow the importation of overseas fruit which does have those sprays on it.

Some aspects of the matters that I have mentioned do require further attention and further investigation. This whole question of quarantine, particularly in the stone fruit area and as it relates to the granite belt of my home State of Queensland, really needs to be looked at closely in order to get rid of some of these anomalies which appear to exist. If there is a review of those matters, we should consider at that time whether the AQIS should be subject to competition from people who are properly licensed and who have the proper qualifications which enable them to do the right thing with plant quarantine. Perhaps then some of the costs that are quite often argued about-and there is often a lot of dismay about the extent of charges by AQIS-could be brought into line with the current culture of user-pays. As we all know, competition brings better service and reduced prices.

The whole Act, particularly as it relates to the matters that I have been talking about, needs review. In the course of that review, we should look at whether it is feasible to introduce some competition to the services provided by AQIS.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1991. As honourable senators have already heard from my colleagues, the coalition is seeking to amend this Bill because of the very basic principle that the Hawke Labor Government has broken. We uphold the right of Australians who enter into financial agreements with government and its agencies not to be subjected to retrospective rule changes and the use of this Parliament to validate the Government's position. We are only told a selected version of the facts in the second reading speech of the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) by reference to the lost Commonwealth revenue caused by owners and importers `not paying their lawful debts for quarantine services'.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition supports both the just payment of debts and the user-pays principle, as my colleague Senator Macdonald just outlined. We do not support the practice of governments changing the rules as they go along, breaking agreements and then attempting to resolve the ensuing disputes by legislating themselves an advantage. The whole point of our contention is this is not fair and we will not support this retrospective element. That is exactly what occurred in the case of those goat breeders who responded to the 1983 offer by the then Department of Health to participate in the scrapie eradication program whereby imported goats would be kept for a minimum of five years in order to breed out the disease.

The cost agreed upon then was $50 per animal per year. In November 1984 the importers reluctantly agreed to raising this fee to $75 when it was stated by the animal quarantine branch of the Department of Health that full cost recovery would constitute a `prohibitive' cost to the importer. So far, well and good, but then in 1987 the Hawke Labor Government broke the agreement by deciding to demand full cost recovery. At the same time, importers were alleging that stock losses had been high at the Torrens Island quarantine facility because of lack of appropriate management experience and of facilities not being ready on time. The annual fee was then set at $311 per animal per year. Whatever its cost justification, the importers had reason to believe that they had an agreement whereby arrangements would not be changed in this arbitrary manner.

The cost demand by the Government on importers has risen from $50 to $410 per animal, an increase of 820 per cent. A major Western Australian importer with 200 animals at Torrens Island is faced with a bill of $320,000 rather than the $45,000 originally agreed to, and originally budgeted for. While these animals remain in the possession of the Commonwealth, they cannot be insured and thus cannot be forward sold. Once again, this Labor Government proceeds blindly on a course of cost recovery without recognising that farm incomes are in a parlous state, even affecting these larger importers.

The Senate is being asked to approve this Bill to enable the Commonwealth to retain possession of the animals and to `ensure that the Commonwealth's bargaining position over payment of the debt is not weakened'. That is the most outrageous statement in this economic time that we could imagine. The Government has simply lost touch with reality and the whole rural sector.

Rather than submit to any court decision or negotiate with the importers on the basis of the facts outlined, the Hawke Labor Government prefers confiscation that ensures that its demands will be met. This tactic does not even give the importers the opportunity to pay the bill through future breeding from the stock. It is an absolute cut-off for these people. It is significant that the Government has not sought to introduce a firm dispute settling procedure in this Bill. Importers will continue to be at a disadvantage in any future dispute with the Government.

The coalition will be moving an amendment to prevent the Government from selling any animals in quarantine before 1 September 1991. We are not disputing the need for the Government to protect and recover its costs in the future. What we do oppose is, in effect, the conferring of a retrospective advantage to the Government in a dispute where the importers present a strong case for the upholding of the agreement made with this very same Government in 1984. It is not just a matter of protecting a small number of importers from injustice, bearing in mind that these are enterprising rural producers who entered into a long term project for improved and disease-free stock.

This amendment is about honesty in government. It may not be a spectacular case, but private citizens in legitimate dispute with an agency of the Federal Government have the right to seek its resolution by negotiation or through the courts, without having the rules changed by administrative or legislative action. We in the coalition will simply not be a party to that. At the very least, the Senate should not be an accomplice to one party in a dispute. We should all remember the cynicism held by so many Australians as to the fairness of public institutions.

Public confidence in Government diminishes that one little bit more if responsible Australian rural producers are able to state that not only were they misled by the Government and its agencies, but also that their case was destroyed by legislative action. Consequently, I commend the coalition amendment as a necessary exercise to ensure some fairness in this dispute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments before the Parliament are required by the Government to clarify an existing power and to ensure that the Commonwealth revenue is protected. The present section 64(1) of the Quarantine Act creates a legal charge on any goods undergoing quarantine in respect of which fees are outstanding.
—There is no argument against that.

—I am delighted to hear it. There is nothing in section 64 which precludes the enforcement of the charge with respect to expenses due to the Commonwealth prior to the expiration of the quarantine period. The Bill is silent, however, on how the legal charge is to be enforced. The new provisions enable the Commonwealth to enforce the legal charge by retaining possession of the goods until either the debt is paid or arrangements for payment are negotiated without expensive litigation against owners or importers.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments will apply to all goods in quarantine on and from 1 September, including those animals in the SFAP, as some members of the SFAP are not paying charges lawfully imposed. We understand that the Opposition will be opposing the Quarantine Amendment Bill on the grounds that it should not be apply to the SFAP which is scheduled to be completed by February 1992. The outstanding debt for those syndicates still on Torrens Island is of the order of $900,000 and is the subject of dispute with the syndicate owners and the Ombudsman's office.

The present section 64(1) of the Quarantine Act 1908 creates a legal charge over any animals undergoing quarantine in respect of which fees are outstanding. This charge can be enforced by seeking an order from a court of appropriate jurisdiction to allow a receiver to be appointed to retain custody of the animals. The SFAP has to date involved an effective Commonwealth subsidy of around $1.6m. The amendments proposed will apply to any goods undergoing quarantine now or in the future. Importantly, however, the amendments will provide flexibility for the owners to enter into arrangements with the Commonwealth for the payment of any debts. The Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) recently met with a number of the syndicates involved in the SFAP. Without the amendment the Minister will be left with no option but to use the existing section 64 provisions. This obviously would not be in the best interests of the owners.

The importance of an effective and efficient quarantine service for this country cannot be overstated. Australia is absolutely and utterly in the hands of an efficient quarantine service in terms of the essential protection of this country's vital primary industries. It is in the interests of all Australians that that service be given the necessary legislative support which it needs to do its job efficiently. I wish to indicate the appreciation of the Government for the expressions of support that have been indicated by Opposition senators in the course of this debate.

I indicate in conclusion, to soothe the troubled breast of Senator Tambling, that the Democrats have indicated to me their intention to support Senator Tambling's amendments. We will not be moving to the committee stage of the Bill tonight. The reason, quite simply, is that Senator Tambling has indicated-as indeed is his right-that he wishes to pursue a number of specific quarantine issues during the committee stage more exhaustively than he has so far canvassed them in his second reading contribution. I believe it is the intention of the Minister responsible for the Act to be in the chamber during the committee stage to assist Senator Tambling in that process. It is for that reason alone that we will not be proceeding with the committee stage of this legislation this evening.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Committee Consideration
Motion by (Senator Collins) proposed:
That consideration of the Bill in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the motion before the Chair, I draw attention to the fact that we were prepared to continue with the debate on the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1991, and to conclude it as part of an agreement to satisfy the legislative requirements and programming of the Government. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will be aware that this legislation was brought on for debate, by consent and outside of today's routine agenda, specifically to deal with the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bell had clearly indicated in his comments that the Australian Democrats basically supported both the thrust of the legislation and the amendments that the Opposition had put forward. I believe that any debate and discussion on this matter could have been concluded. I do not find it an appropriate excuse that the legislation should not now proceed because the appropriate Minister is not at the table.

If the Labor Party has problems in managing its appropriate portfolio responsibilities because of Caucus commitments of the Ministers, I do not believe that is appropriate to the Senate or to the Parliament. The Minister's first responsibility on all occasions such as this is to present himself when his legislation has been brought on at the Government's behest, out of order, for special consideration in order to conclude it.

I wish to hear from the Democrats that they are in no way compromising their position. We are well aware that in the past when legislation has been deferred for consideration by the Senate for a considerable time, particularly on matters affecting primary industry, the Democrats have either caved in, done deals or made special arrangements with the Government. I am certainly aware that the Minister acknowledged that Senator Bell had made his point--

TALK.START.PARA: —I'd quit while I was ahead, if I were you!

—I do not believe that the legislation should be reviewed on the basis of what Senator Collins might consider to be comments relating to the program of the Senate. If the Democrats are changing their position because of that, I am just drawing the Senate's attention to the important issues that are before us, to the special consideration that the Senate has given this matter, and to the fact that the Government itself is seeking to change the legislation and complicate the program for tomorrow.
—If they change their minds you will know who to blame!

—No, it had better not be a matter of blame, or comments of this nature. That would certainly not augur well for the Democrats in the rural constituency, reflecting the comments they have made this evening. We are certainly opposed to the postponement of further consideration of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With such an invitation I feel that I have to respond. One could possibly be forgiven for being influenced by the threats that have been sent concerning this matter, particularly in my direction, and say, `Be shot with the lot of you'. The suggestions that have been made are not relevant at all to the legislation at hand. During my speech in the second reading debate I said quite clearly, `We have full support for the National Party's proposed amendments. The coalition has our support on this'. The receipt of such untoward and unjustified insults would perhaps change spots on some leopards.

SPEECH.PARA: I guarantee that we are not intimidated by such threats. I am not impressed by them, so they will have no effect whatsoever on my regard for the amendments that are being proposed. They will be supported. Having said that, it is appropriate to say that to some extent I may have to take the blame for this rescheduling. I gave the parliamentary liaison officer to understand that I wanted to speak later in the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was explained to Senator Tambling by your Whip.

—I thank Senator Collins. It was, certainly. I had asked to speak later in the debate because I wished to hear the full explanation of the reasons for the amendments so that I could agree with them. Having asked to speak late in the debate, to be listed late on the speakers list, perhaps that was misunderstood to mean tomorrow morning-I do not know. Whatever the reason was, it was interpreted to mean that we were not quite ready tonight. That is not the fact. I was prepared to follow this Bill through the committee stage and to support the proposed amendments. I am still prepared to do that. But if the Minister understood my request for being later on the list to mean that we were not quite ready and that therefore he would not need to be in the chamber, I do not think it is my fault; nor do I think it is the Democrats' fault. In fact, I do not even think it is the Minister's fault. It certainly does not matter because the end result will be--
—It's 10 minutes before the adjournment.

—That is correct. The end result will be that these proposed amendments will be supported by us. Whether they are supported by the Government tomorrow morning will only be the icing on the cake, if you like. The tactic employed recently by Senator Tambling adds a sour note to that icing on the cake, and I do not appreciate it in any way whatsoever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek the leave of the Senate to make a very brief response to Senator Tambling's statement.
—You would be able to respond by closing the debate if you wish.
—I have already done so, on the second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I thank the Australian Democrats for correcting the parliamentary record in this respect. I cannot allow Senator Tambling's comments to pass. They do him no credit. They were a piece of absolute pedantry which, even politically, astonished me and potentially put at risk-which is not my problem-the support that he was given in good faith and in my presence by the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: The slurs that he cast on them are not what I have got up to talk about. I have got up to talk about the criticism that has been made of the responsible Minister, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, of which Senator Tambling was made personally aware five minutes before he got to his feet by the Democrats Whip.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is more important-parliament or a caucus meeting?

—Senator Knowles should wait for the explanation. The facts are that I was the duty Minister at 6.30 p.m. Senator Cook's office was advised in good faith, as Senator McLean confirmed, at the time that it was the intent not to proceed with the committee stage of this legislation this evening but to finish the debate on the second reading. The normal practice, as Senator Tambling knows full well, other than the hypocritical cant he delivered--
—We were never advised.
—It is normal practice for the duty Minister to be in the chamber during the second reading stage of the debate.
—We were not advised.
—What is more important-parliament or a caucus meeting?

—I can answer Senator Knowles' question. As far as Senator Cook-and I know I speak on his behalf-and I are concerned, it is the Parliament that has precedence. Senator Cook was advised and the Parliamentary Liaison Officer subsequently advised me that that was the intent.
—Why weren't we advised?
—I cannot answer that question. Senator Tambling was advised personally by the Democrats Whip that that was the situation.
—But we weren't advised of that.

—I point out to Senator Tambling, with respect, that that does not warrant his totally opportunistic political slur on the Minister. Had the Minister been aware that the committee stage of this debate was to proceed this evening-he was advised of precisely the opposite-the Minister himself would have been here.
—Bolkus brought the Bill on.
—I beg your pardon?
—Bolkus brought the Bill on.
—Senator Bolkus to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot help but respond to the comments made by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins). We have now actually found out the facts of the matter on this issue.
—You weren't even involved in the conversation!

—That is exactly right. I am glad the Minister has made the comment that I was not involved in the conversation because, as the Whip on duty, I should have been involved. But the Minister did not have the courtesy to advise the shadow Minister who has carriage of this legislation and he did not advise the Whips in the Opposition. The Government did not advise us. I am very pleased that Senator Collins made the comments that he did. The message that I got some 25 or 26 minutes ago was that Senator Cook could not come into the chamber because he was locked up in a caucus meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why I interjected earlier: what is more important to the Labor Government? Is it the Parliament or a caucus meeting? Clearly, when I was informed 28 minutes ago that it was a caucus meeting, I already had my answer. If the Government had given us the courtesy that it obviously extended, quite properly, to the Australian Democrats but not to the Opposition, which was improper, we would not be having this disagreement now. Once again, we have bad manners being displayed on this issue by the Government. If we are kept informed, we are more than likely prepared to go along with it. But the Government has run out of business. The Minister knows it and he is now clawing at the door trying to find something else to get thrown into this Senate. The Government brought us back early. It has no business to carry on with. It is a typical case of the Government's mismanagement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I might say something briefly about this rather unnecessary and overblown debate, this is the third occasion we have had today on which honourable senators have sought to make mountains sometimes out of molehills and sometimes out of non-existent molehills about their enthusiasm concerning the Senate program. After 25 minutes of notices of motion this morning, Senator Michael Baume got up and complained about the delay in getting on with the business.
—At Question Time, where every question was twice as long as any answer given.
—That is exactly right.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not complaining about it. I am commenting on the efficient use of the Senate's time. We then had the long overdue debate on the Senate (Quorum) Bill. Honourable senators will find that that was not just put in there to fill in time. A series of things has happened and will happen during the early part of this session to clear up longstanding matters on the Notice Paper: for example, the Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Zone, which has been on there for about a year and which has now been cleaned up thanks to the cooperation of the other parties; the Senate (Quorum) Bill, which has now been dealt with; and other matters with which we propose to deal similarly. SPEECH.PARA: What disappoints me is that we have had, with the cooperation of the Opposition Whip and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) and the Australian Democrat Whip and Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Coulter), what I thought and understood was a very cooperative working arrangement about how we are going to manage the business of the Senate this session. —Why didn't Cook come here?

—I assume that was not the reason. I am concerned that we did have that reasonable working arrangement. The Leader of the Opposition and the Opposition Whip entered into it in good faith and I am sure they will set out to implement it. The reason I was reviewing it was that we had an agreement at that time that if we fell behind we would call a meeting of the Whips and Leaders at the end of the fourth week to review what we would do about that. SPEECH.PARA: We are proceeding with the legislation in accordance with the list circulated to the Opposition and the Democrats before we started, other than the three pieces of legislation which have been sent to committees-the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Bill, and the Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill. Apart from that, we are exactly where we said we would be at this stage. All this hyperbole about the program must be only to enable people to make some points later on in the session, about which I am concerned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the President advised the Senate that the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff was negotiating to provide the Parliament with the Cable News Network service. The service is now available on channel 23 of the House monitoring system. It will be available for one month only, commencing today.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 pm, I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, in answer to a question from Senator Hill, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, made a statement which relates to the practice of recognising states and governments. I wish to take a few moments to reflect on his comments because, I think, the events of the last twenty-four hours are quite significant in this regard. Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is, of course, not Australian practice now to do other than to recognise states. We do not recognise or de-recognise governments.

The statement of policy was enunciated in January 1988 when the Australian Government said that it would not extend formal recognition whether de jure or de facto to new governments. Instead, it would replace that recognition by the conduct of its relation with regimes, `to the extent and in the manner which may be required in the circumstances of each case'.

That policy was clearly designed to give the Australian Government a certain degree of leeway in situations where there may be a change of government as a result of an overthrow or coup or where there may be some moves to self-determination in a particular territory.

I believe the time has come for Australia to give serious consideration both to recognition of the Baltic states and also a suitable conduct of relations with the existing governments of those states, the duly elected governments of those states, which would show to the rest of the world that we in Australia are unwilling to let the power of the gun barrel dictate the lives of thousands of people whose aspirations are for democracy. The events which I have witnessed on television this evening remind me of one thing, and one thing alone, and that is the events in Tiananmen Square in June 1989. My heart was filled with the same sadness tonight that it was filled with in June two years ago.

I do not want to see the world stand by while democracy is crushed in the Soviet Union and in the Baltic states. I have reflected today on the conduct of Mr Yeltsin and wondered how many of us in this Parliament would have the courage to stand up to a military dictatorship, to rally the people to stand for freedom and democracy, albeit at the very real risk of our own life.

I believe that the least we can do in this Parliament, as individual parliamentarians concerned with freedom, democracy and self-determination, is to make a stand and say that we believe in democracy and we do not believe the Australian Government should, by relations or conduct or any such things, give succour and comfort to a dictatorship in the Soviet Union which clearly contravenes United Nations principles of self-determination and which, arguably, seized power from President Gorbachev and prevent him signing the union treaty and, therefore, giving the Baltic states, among others, a greater claim to autonomy and recognition in their own right.

For these reasons, I urge Senator Evans, and all of those within the Government, to choose to recognise the Baltic states as states and to conduct our relations in accordance with the 1988 declaration in such a way as to show that we believe the elected governments of those states are the only governments that are entitled to speak on behalf of those people and that we will not tolerate tyranny in the Soviet Union or the Baltic states.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.35 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any of the recommendations in the Auditor-General's report No. 9 1989-90, Department of Defence Post Separation Employment been adopted; if so, which ones and if not, why not.
(2) Of the recommendations adopted, what is the current situation regarding the implementation of each.
(3) How many employees have left the (a) Department of Defence; and (b) the Australian Defence Force (ADF), and taken up private employment in related industry during 1988-89 and 1989-90.
(4) Has the Defence Industry Committee looked at the question of personnel moving from the Defence Department to Defence Industry; if so, in what capacity or depth and if not, why not.

(5) How many ex Department of Defence employees are now engaged as Department of Defence consultants. Please list his/her former position/job and salary in the department or the ADF and his/her current consultancy position/engagement and current salary or contract length and value.
(6) Were any of the former employees listed in (5) paid redundancy packages; if so, which ones and what was the value of the redundancy package.

(7) Did any of the former employees listed in (5) receive any other form of financial benefit when finalising employment with the Department of Defence; if so, what benefits and for what reason and what was the financial value of each.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) All the recommendations of the Auditor-General's report No. 9 Department of Defence Post Separation Report have been adopted with the exception of recommendations 3, 7, 8 and 11 for the following reasons:

(a) With regard to Recommendation 3 it is considered that the existing arrangements are adequate for the task. All civilian application records are centrally colocated. A database has been created to keep track of ongoing cases, and will provide a means of providing disaggregated statistical information as required. Service records of Post Separation Employment (PSE) cases are similarly kept by the Director General of Service Personnel Policy (DGSPP);
(b) While the Department agrees in-principle with Recommendation 7, in practice senior management has determined all cases; and

(c) With respect to Recommendation 8 consistency of approach, where appropriate, has been achieved through liaison arrangements between the civilian and ADF policy areas and a separate review is not considered necessary.

(d) With respect to Recommendation 11, current Defence processes and arrangements now in place take account of the Defence Industry Committee considerations. Therefore, it has not been necessary to formally raise PSE policy issues at meetings of the Committee since December 1988.
(2) Of the recommendations adopted the status of each is as follows:

(a) (Recommendation 1) The Department's policy on PSE has been widely circulated via Departmental Personnel Instruction No. 4/89 which was published on 10 August 1989, and in Defence Instruction (General) 25-1 which was published on 1 March 1990. These instructions, in addition to being a statement of Defence policy, are also considered to be a basic educative tool for use by managers in explaining the obligations imposed by this policy on individuals.

In an effort to generally improve staff knowledge of PSE obligations, this matter is one of several topics discussed in an ethics booklet which has been prepared by the Inspector-General Division for widespread use by service and civilian personnel throughout the Department and the Australian Defence Force.

Additionally, a section dealing with PSE has been included in the recently published civilian Induction Handbook, thereby alerting all inductees to the Department of the obligations they must meet when separating from APS employment.
Other instructions/handbooks will also be framed in the knowledge of the PSE requirements and incorporated into those instructions etc. where appropriate.

(b) (Recommendation 2) The final entitlement notice sent to civilian staff who are leaving Commonwealth employment has been substantially revised to reflect the contents of DPI No. 4/89. The revised notice takes into account the special circumstance of staff who retire under s76R and s76W (retirements other than age retirements) provisions of the Public Service Act.

(c) (Recommendation 4) The Department has achieved this by providing written advice to staff (DPI No. 4/89 and DI(G) 25-1), and by preparing the ethics booklet sponsored by the Inspector-General's organisation.
(d) (Recommendation 5) This has also been achieved by providing written advice to staff (DPI No. 4/89 and DI(G) 25-1).

(e) (Recommendation 6) The database referred to in response No. 1 (a) should make access to this form of information relatively easy. As to assessing identified cases which have by-passed the assent procedures, Personnel Policy Branch would seek to counsel these staff of their rights and obligations.

(f) (Recommendation 9) A review of the roles of the Inspector-General Division, Human Resources &Management Division and ADF in implementation of revised PSE policy has been undertaken, culminating in the issuing of the civilian and Service instructions DPI No. 4/89 and DI(G) 25-1. Responsibility for prime carriage of the PSE function has been vested in DGSPP for Service members and the Assistant Secretary Personnel Policy for civilian staff.

(g) (Recommendation 10) Actions resulting from the Auditor General's recommendations have been addressed. The matter of PSE was last addressed in the September 1990 quarterly return to the Minister for Finance. The Department has not been required to report on it since that time. The issue of updated instructions is seen as implementing the revised policy initiatives.

(3) During 1988-89 and 1989-90, based on available records, the number of Defence employees who left the Department to commence private employment in related industry totalled 16 and 18 respectively. The number of ADF personnel who left for the same purpose during this period totalled 6 and 11 respectively.

(4) At a meeting in December 1988 the Defence Industry Committee considered and provided views on Defence arrangements and processes for personnel moving from the Department to Defence Industry. The Defence Industry Committee was invited to consider the arrangements because of its role as the advisory body on Defence matters involving industry. Current Defence processes and arrangements now in place take account of the Defence Industry Committee considerations.
(5) A total number of 8 previous employees are now engaged as Departmental consultants. These are listed in the attached table.

(6) Only one person received a redundancy package, all others left the Department on normal resignation or retirement grounds. That person received a standard redundancy payment in accordance with the Australian Public Service Redeployment and Retirement (Redundancy) Award 1987.

(7) The financial payments received by the remainder of the employees listed in Question 5 were the standard entitlements available to staff on resignation or age retirement and covered payment in lieu of accrued leave entitlements and refund of superannuation contributions (where applicable).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 13 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the details of the evidence where there have been occasions of a corruptive influence, or any allegations of there being a corruptive influence, in the conduct of any State or Federal election in Australia and which can be attributed in any way to the use of radio or television.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In his report on the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption's investigation into North Coast Development in 1990 Assistant Commissioner Adrian Roden QC identified a number of alleged corrupt and improper practices including the offering and taking of bribes, involving a number of elected and unelected public officials.
Assistant Commissioner Roden in this report stated:

`With the mounting cost of campaign advertising, parties must be increasingly vulnerable to attempts by substantial donors to exert influence. It appears that the parties are themselves aware of this, and various proposals for increased public funding, limits on allowable spending, free television time, and bans on television advertising, have all been mooted'.
The Commissioner also said:
`Whether the parties intend to allow the donations to influence them or not, they are unlikely to react to them in a manner that will chase the benefactors away'.
I refer the abovementioned report to Senator Archer regarding evidence of corruption and undue influence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 28 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a permitted use of official postage entitlements for a Member and/or office holder of the Parliament to distribute (a) letters soliciting financial donations for his/her political party or its endorsed candidates; (b) letters recruiting workers and assistants for his/her political party or its endorsed candidates; (c) notices of meetings of his/her political party; (d) minutes of meetings of his/her political party; (e) political party promotions material; or (f) how-to-vote material for himself/herself or candidates of his/her political party.
(2) Is it permissible for a Member to give stamps provided under an official allowance to an endorsed candidate of his/her political party or to a third party.
(3) Is it permissible for a Member to allow the use by another Member of Parliament of his/her bulk postage entitlement.
(4) Is it permissible for a Member to mail another Member's mail or the mail of a candidate of his/her political party on his/her bulk postage entitlement.

(5) Is it permissible for a Member to use his/her stationery allowance to produce (a) fund raising letters or campaign worker recruiting letters for his/her political party or its endorsed candidates; or
(b) how-to-vote material for him or herself or candidates of his/her political party.
(6) What are the guidelines for the use of departmental postage, including stamps, franking machine and bulk postage facilities, including Australia Post credit cards, by Ministers.
(7) Can an assurance be given that these guidelines have not been broken by any Minister of the Hawke Government.
(8) Can an undertaking be given to investigate any possible breach of a prima facie case.
(9) What have been the guidelines for the allocation of ministerial offices since the election of the Hawke Labor Government.
(10) Which Ministers have located ministerial offices in their electorates.

(11) Is it permissible for Ministers to use departmental resources and facilities for (a) parliamentary purposes; (b) electorate purposes; or (c) support of political parties and their endorsed candidates.
(12) In the last Parliament, which Ministers located ministerial offices in their electorates.

(13) What resources, in terms of staff and office equipment, and specifically, postage facilities, including stamps, franking machines and Australia Post credit cards, were provided for use in those offices.
(14) What were the identifying numbers on any franking machines issued to those offices.
(15) What telephone facilities are provided to Members, and for what purposes are these facilities provided.

(16) Is it permitted to connect equipment to officially provided telephone equipment that has not been officially supplied to the Member, such as modems, direct dialling equipment and equipment associated with tele-marketing and telephone opinion research operations.

(17) Are Members permitted to allow members of the public or political party workers to use or charge to a Member's official telephone, costs associated with tele-marketing or telephone opinion research.

(18) Has the Department of Administrative Services identified any overexpenditure of entitlements provided either by the Remuneration Tribunal, the Department of Administrative Services, the Parliament or its department or a Government, to Members and Senators during the last Parliament; if so, for each case, please provide full and complete details of the overexpenditure, including (a) details of the entitlement; (b) the nature and amount of the overexpenditure; (c) the name of the Member or Senator and, if applicable, the electoral division involved; (d) any action initiated to recover the overexpenditure and the result of the action initiated; and (e) the status of the recovery action or an explanation as to why no action has been taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The postage entitlement available to Senators and Members states that postage at official expense is for parliamentary and electorate business only. Party political business is excluded. Certain Office Holders of the Parliament and Ministers have an additional entitlement to the cost of postage in relation to their official business. Entitlees are required to exercise their judgment when utilising their postage entitlements having regard to the purposes for which the material is to be utilised. Consequently, it is not possible to make a categorical statement about the types of material covered by the question without sighting the material referred to.

(2) Senators and Members are provided with a limited entitlement to stamps by the Parliamentary Departments. Those stamps are for use by the entitlee and can be used for parliamentary and electorate business only. Party political business is excluded.
(3) Senators and Members are entitled to utilise the bulk postage service provided by Australia Post. The facility is available for use by the entitlee.
(4) See answer to (3) above.

(5) The guidelines on the use of personalised letterhead are administered by the Presiding Officers. My Department supplements the entitlements of Members of the House of Representatives to bring it up to that provided by the Department of the Senate to Honourable Senators. Stationery items provided by my Department, such as plain paper, envelopes etc. are subject to the same guidelines which apply to postage. These are outlined at (1) above.

(6) The Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990 provides for individual Departments to meet the cost of a Minister's postage expenditure in relation to official business. `Official business' covers business on behalf of the Government and the portfolio.

(7) The postage entitlement for Ministers is supplied and administered by the individual Departments. The honourable Senator may wish to raise the matter with each Minister. No evidence has been adduced to me as to a breach.
(8) My Department would examine any `prima facie' evidence in areas within its responsibility.

(9) It has been the practice of successive Governments, including the current Government, that, in addition to the back-bench entitlement to an electorate office, Ministers and Opposition Officeholders may establish Ministerial/Office-holder offices in the capital city of their home State. Alternatively, Ministers/Office-holders may upgrade their electorate offices to combined Ministerial/Office-holder/electorate offices.
Ministers' departments may also make Ministerial office accommodation available within departmental holdings.

(18) I am advised that identification of all instances where overexpenditure on entitlements has occurred during the life of the Thirty-Fifth Parliament would require the Department of Administrative Services to perform a full examination of all payments associated with entitlements between July 1987 and March 1990. I am not prepared to direct that my Department expend the resources required to undertake such an examination.
I am advised that my Department is not aware of overexpenditure of entitlements of Senators and Members by other bodies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 30 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the now-postponed Indian elections, and particularly to the use of a campaign tool known as `video chariots' which are mobile bans broadcasting video promotions on behalf of parties and candidates:
(1) Was the issue of `video chariots' drawn to the Minister's attention during consideration of the "Political Broadcasts and Disclosures Bill".
(2) If the Government's legislation is passed, will such forms of communication become the only way for Australian political parties to take their message directly to the people.
(3) Would the costs of this form of communication (each `video chariot' costs over $1000 to hire) expose Australian political parties to the risk of corrupt influence.
(4) Would the Minister consider the use of `video chariots' as `bought speech' which must be banned by the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) No. The only means of communication which is restricted by the proposed Bill is the broadcasting of advertisements containing political matter as defined. News and current affairs programs will not be affected. Nor will talkback radio programs. The print media is not affected by the Bill and all other campaign methods will be unaffected.

(3 and 4) The future use of `video chariots' by political parties in Australia is not quantifiable. What has been recorded however since 1984 is the level of expenditure by political parties on broadcasting and the print media for the purpose of campaign advertising. The Australian Electoral Commission figures reveal that expenditure on broadcast advertising by the four major political parties (The Labor, Liberal and National parties and the Australian Democrats) has risen from $5,907,015 for the 1984 election to $15,523,582 for the 1990 election. Over the same period print advertising expenditure by the same four parties rose from $2,901,173 in 1984 to $7,041,812 in 1990.
Use by the major political parties of broadcast advertising represents just under 50% of the total campaign expenditure.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 19 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Federal Airports Corporation stated, in its Strategy Plan for Sydney Airport, that aircraft larger than a Boeing 747 must use Badgerys Creek Airport if they are to regularly serve Sydney.

(2) As Boeing and Airbus Industries state that aircraft about 50 per cent larger than a 747 will be in service `early next century' (Australian Financial Review, 14 June 1991, page 43), if the third runway is built at Sydney Airport, what arrangements will be in place to cater for these new- generation aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Draft Planning Strategy assumes some use by aircraft larger than a Boeing 747. The time horizon of the Draft Planning Strategy is to year 2010 by which time the new generation aircraft will still be in a minority and will be able to be accommodated on Sydney Airport runways and terminals in common with other existing international airports around the world. In the longer term, Badgerys Creek could be developed for such aircraft.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Civil Aviation Authority: Capacity Enhancement Unit

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice on 21 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the `Financial Review' article of 6 June 1991 entitled `AWC accused of fiddling numbers to suit Government Case':
(1) Has the Government put any pressure on the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) to support the Government's proposal for a 15 per cent tax on wool.
(2) Will the Minister release details of the projections and assumptions it used in its formula for a 15 per cent tax.

(3) Is the $200 million interest-free loan to the AWC to be a grant or was the Government offering to pay only the interest on $200 million of the Corporation's debt, as reported in the Financial Review article.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Government's economic analysis of alternative proposals with regards to the wool tax rate for 1991-92 was undertaken by the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics (ABARE). The analysis was based on maximising the returns to the wool industry, after taking account of stock holding, interest and administrative costs, from alternative stock release, debt repayment and tax rate strategies. Consideration was also given to the effects of these strategies on farm cash operating surplus (total cash receipts less total cash costs) for the major broadacre industries, including sheep specialists. ABARE is intending to release a Technical Paper in August 1991 which contains a discussion of the general issues involved in comparing alternative strategies and an analytical framework for considering optimal stock release strategies.

(3) When the Government established the Australian Wool Realisation Commission (AWRC) for the purpose of managing the industry's debt and wool stockpile, it was decided a $200 million interest free loan over two years should be facilitated as an advance on the sale of property assets. This would enable the industry to maximise the return from property sales.
Under this arrangement the interest subsidy would have been paid as the AWRC took out loans which were part of the $200 million.

However when the Government was required to accept a tax rate of 12 per cent, a decision was taken to provide the annual interest payment as a grant. This is, in effect, equivalent to the AWRC receiving an additional one percentage point of tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-On 19 December 1990 (Hansard, page 6001) Senator Spindler asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning bank interest rate margins over the last few years.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
The honourable senator suggested that banks have been `recouping the losses caused by their own bad decisions by profiteering ... at the expense of Australian families'.
Analytical work carried out by the Reserve Bank suggests that this is not the case. The Bank has estimated that, for the major banks:
the return on shareholders' funds fell from 16 per cent in the first half of the 1980s to 13 per cent in the second half;
the corresponding notional figures for charges to profit for bad debts relative to shareholders' funds were 2.4 and 5.1 per cent (ie, an increase of 2.7 percentage points).
In other words, at least for the major banks, their profits over the 1980s fell by more than their costs of bad debts had risen.

A similar picture of falling profitability emerges in recent years when the bulk of the increase in bad debt costs occurred. This is illustrated in the following table which shows the sources of the major banks' profits in 1989 and 1990 (as percentages of their total assets):
Net interest income 3.3 3.2
Fees and other income 1.7 1.7
Operating costs 3.1 3.1
Bad debt costs 0.5 0.9
Pre-tax profit 1.4 0.9
Taxes 0.5 0.3
After-tax profit 0.9 0.6

The honourable senator also suggested that banks' interest rate margins have doubled in the past few years. There are various ways of measuring margins, all of which have limitations. However, in its recent and publicly available submission to the Martin Committee of Inquiry into banking, the Reserve Bank found on the basis of its assessment of the evidence that margins in fact fell over the 1980s. One measure it looked at was net interest income as a proportion of assets. The above table shows on this basis that the major banks' margins fell slightly over 1989 and 1990.

Measuring banks' margins as the difference between an interest rate on a particular type of retail loan and the cost of one particular source of funds to banks ignores many factors which are important in determining the behaviour of banks' margins, including:
changes in the relative proportions of low- interest and high-interest deposits, which can change the average cost of deposits to banks even in the absence of changes in quoted interest rates;

lags in the effect of changes in quoted deposit interest rates on the average rates paid by banks on term deposits and longer-term certificates of deposit and bills. Depending on the average maturity of these liabilities, it can take many months for banks to reap the full benefit of a fall in quoted deposit rates;

lags in the effect of quoted loan interest rates on the average rates received by banks. A large part of banks' loans is at fixed interest rates, and margins on these loans do not respond to changes in indicator lending rates until the loans are rolled over or re-negotiated. Many of the loans are initially made for three or five-year terms, but in some cases they can be for much longer;
changes in the proportion of banks' loans which are non-performing, ie, earning little or no interest; and

changes in the composition of banks' assets between loans and interest-bearing investments which often have lower interest returns than loans, eg, Commonwealth Government securities held to satisfy the Prime Assets Requirement.

Each of these factors can cause movements in banks' margins in the absence of changes in quoted interest rates. The first point has been particularly important in recent years: between 1989 and 1990, the average proportion of high-cost deposits rosefrom 47 per cent to 56 per cent. This would have reduced margins by about 0.5 percentage
points if there were no corresponding changes to lending rates.

Increased non-performing loans have also been important in 1990; the cost to banks was equivalent to a reduction in average margins by about 0.3 of a percentage point. This factor was relevant to the temporary widening of bank margins for a time in rates.

None of this is to deny that banks have been reviewing the credit standing of individual borrowers and that some face increases in their interest rates vis-a-vis banks' indicator rates. Information available to the Reserve Bank indicates that banks have not increased their margins across the board--in fact, any increase in average margins resulting from this process has been small.

The Government will continue to press the banks to pass on to their borrowers the full benefits of reductions in their deposit costs consequent upon the relaxation of monetary policy that has taken place in recent times.
